title: Prince v. Beaufort Memorial Hospital
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT
  BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Danny R.
      Prince, Respondent,
				v.
				Beaufort Memorial Hospital and its Employees, Servants and Agents, Appellants.
			
		
	


Appeal From Beaufort County
Â Alexander S. Macaulay, Circuit Court
  Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-139
Heard January 8, 2008 â€“ Filed March 3,
  2008
REVERSED AND REMANDED


	
		
			
				Mary Bass Lohr, of Beaufort, for Appellant.
				T. Wayne Yarbrough, of Bluffton, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â 
  In this personal injury action, Beaufort Memorial Hospital (Hospital) appeals the
  grant of a new trial to Danny R. Prince on the ground that its Quality
  Assurance Committee file should have been made available to Prince during the
  prior trial.Â  We reverse and remand.
FACTS AND PROCEDURAL HISTORY
On February 13, 1999, Hospital admitted Prince
  into a fourth-floor room for treatment of job-related injuries.Â  Initially, Prince
  was a compliant patient and exhibited no signs of psychotic behavior.Â  Sometime
  after 10:30 p.m. on February 17, 1999, however, Prince apparently experienced a
  psychotic hallucination in his hospital room and was found by Hospital staff at
  11:20 p.m. on the roof of a lower floor with injuries to his ankles and head.Â 
  Although Prince did not remember anything from the incident, the window in his
  room appeared to have been forced open.Â   
On
  February 15, 2001, Prince brought a negligence action against Hospital and Hospitalâ€™s
  servants and agents.Â  At issue in the case was how and why Prince ended up on
  the roof and whether or not the defendants could or should have prevented the
  incident.
During discovery, Prince sought to obtain a copy of a file
  generated by Hospitalâ€™s Quality Assurance Committee pursuant to the Committeeâ€™s
  investigation of the incident.Â  Instead, however, Hospital provided a summary
  of expected witness testimony and refused to give Prince the file, claiming it
  was protected under South Carolina Code sections 40-71-10 and 40-71-20.[1]Â  Consequently, Prince filed a motion
  to compel discovery of the complete Quality Assurance Committee file.Â  The
  trial court denied the motion, and a jury ultimately returned a verdict in Hospitalâ€™s
  favor.Â   
Following the denial of his motions for
  judgment notwithstanding the verdict and a new trial, Prince appealed to this Court,
  contending the trial court erred in finding the contents of the file were not
  subject to discovery. Â In an unpublished opinion, this Court held
  that, although Hospitalâ€™s Quality Assurance Committee was within the purview of
  section 40-71-10 to the extent the Committee operated pursuant to bylaws
  approved by Hospital and the information acquired by the Committee was
  protected under section 40-71-20, â€œthe nature of the case demands an in camera
  review of the file.â€Â  Prince v. Beaufort Memâ€™l Hosp., Op. No. 05-UP-602
  (Ct. App. 2006) (S.C. Ct. App. filed April 11, 2006).Â  Accordingly, this Court
  reversed the denial of Princeâ€™s motion for a new trial and remanded the case to
  the trial court for an in camera review of the file, with the following
  instructions:

	[T]he circuit court shall conduct an in camera review of the
  committee file. Â Using its discretion, the court shall decide whether the file
  warrants confidentiality.Â  If the circuit court determines that the file
  contains relevant evidence which is not protected by the confidentiality
  statute, then it shall declare a new trial.Â  Alternatively, if the circuit
  court determines that there is no relevant evidence in the committee file or
  that the file is not entitled to protections of the confidentiality statute,
  then the original denial of the new trial and JNOV motion would be affirmed.

After the
  required in camera review of the Quality Assurance Committee file, the trial
  court found Hospital had waived the protections of section 40-71-20 and
  declared a new trial.Â  The trial court based this finding on its observation
  that Hospital â€œused certain witness statement summaries from this committee
  file in order to answer Interrogatories propounded by the Plaintiff.â€Â  Using
  the law on waiver of the attorney-client privilege as a guide, the trial court
  further held that, once the privilege is waived, â€œit is clear that it is waived
  as to all communications on the same subject matter.â€Â   
Hospital moved for reconsideration, arguing among other things Prince
  did not raise the issue of waiver in his initial appeal and the trial court
  lacked authority to raise the issue sua sponte on remand.Â  The
  trial court declined to amend its prior order.Â  As to Hospitalâ€™s argument that
  Prince failed to preserve the issue of waiver in his appeal, the trial court
  held Prince â€œraised the issue of waiver specifically several times, and, more
  importantly, . . . the issue of waiver is so intertwined with the issue of
  confidentiality of the file that it was inherently preserved for review.â€Â  This
  appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œThe decision whether to grant a new
  trial is left to the sound discretion of the trial court
  and generally will not be disturbed on appeal.â€Â  Dropkin v. Beach Villa
    Condominium Assâ€™n, 373 S.C. 360, 363, 644 S.E.2d 808, 809 (Ct. App. 2007)
  (citing Rush v. Blanchard, 310 S.C. 375, 380, 426 S.E.2d 802, 805 (1993)). Â â€œAn abuse of discretion occurs when the trial
  courtâ€™s findings are wholly unsupported by the evidence or the conclusions
  reached are controlled by an error of law.â€Â  Wright v. Craft, 372 S.C.
  1, 36, 640 S.E.2d 486, 505 (Ct. App. 2006).
LAW/ANALYSIS
1.Â  Hospital first argues
  that Prince, in his initial appeal to this court, failed to challenge the
  rejection of his argument at trial that Hospital had waived its right to assert
  the Quality Assurance Committee file was confidential under section 40-71-20
  and is therefore barred by the law of the case doctrine from a finding on
  remand that Hospital waived its right to assert that the Quality Assurance
  Committee file was confidential.Â  We agree.
As a general rule,
  an unchallenged ruling, right or wrong, is the law of the case.Â  Ex parte
    Morris, 367 S.C. 56, 65, 624 S.E.2d 649, 654 (2006).Â  â€œAny unappealed
  portion of the trial courtâ€™s judgment is law of the case and must be affirmed.â€
  Â Rumpf v. Massachusetts Mut. Life Ins. Co., 357 S.C. 386, 398, 593
  S.E.2d 183, 189 (Ct. App. 2004); see also ML-Lee Acquisition Fund,
    L.P. v. Deloitte & Touche, 327 S.C. 238, 241, 489 S.E.2d 470, 472
  (1997) (emphasizing that unappealed rulings become law of case and should not
  be reconsidered by this court).
As noted by the
  trial court on remand and acknowledged by counsel for both sides during oral
  argument for the present appeal, Prince raised the issue of waiver to the trial
  court when he sought to obtain the Quality Assurance Committee file.Â  After the
  trial, Prince appealed to this Court, raising the following five issues:
 

	(1)Â 
  Did the [trial] court err in granting the Hospital Section 40-71-10 & 20
  privileges of confidentiality regarding the incident reports without requiring
  proof that the Section applies? (2) Did the [trial] court err in denying the [Prince]
  his statement made the night of the incident?Â  (3)Â  Did the court erred [sic]
  when it found that the [Hospital] was a â€œpeerâ€ appearing before itself and
  being reviewed by itself, thereby qualifying for the privilege of
  confidentiality.Â  (4)Â  Did the [trial] court err in not reviewing the
  Hospitalâ€™s â€œallegedâ€ confidential file [i]n [c]amera to resolve
  conflicts in evidence resulting from discovery responses summarized by the
  Respondent from the alleged confidential file and witness testimony?Â  (5)Â  Did
  the trial court err in not granting the Princeâ€™s JNOV?

We do not read any of these
  issues to include an argument on the issue of waiver.Â  In addition, we have
  reviewed the brief Prince filed in the prior appeal of this case, which was
  included in the record compiled for the present appeal, and have found nothing
  that addresses the issue of waiver.Â  We therefore hold Prince failed to appeal
  the trial courtâ€™s refusal to consider his argument that Hospital had waived its
  protection under section 40-71-20.Â  See Rule 207(b)(1)(B) (â€œOrdinarily,
  no point will be considered which is not set forth in the statement of the
  issues on appeal.â€).
In making this determination, we further hold the
  trial court erred in stating the issue of waiver was â€œso
  intertwined with the issue of confidentiality of the file that it was inherently
  preserved for review.â€ Â â€œWaiver is defined as
  an intentional relinquishment of a known right.â€Â  Lawrimore v.
    American Health & Life Ins. Co., 276 S.C. 112, 114, 276 S.E.2d 296, 297
  (1981) (emphasis added).Â  It follows that one seeking to establish a waiver of
  confidentiality inherently recognizes the confidential nature of the
  information being sought.[2]Â  
 
2.Â  We further
  agree with Hospital that the trial court, in finding Hospital had waived the
  right to invoke section 40-17-20, had exceeded the scope of authority granted
  by this Court in its prior opinion.
Once
  this Court issues a mandate to a trial court, the trial court â€œis vested with
  jurisdiction only to the extent conferred by the appellate courtâ€™s opinion and
  mandate.â€ Â S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Basnight,  346 S.C. 241,
  250-251, 551 S.E.2d 274, 279 (Ct. App. 2001) (quoting 5 Am. Jur. 2d Appellate
    Review Â§ 784, at 43 (1995)).Â  â€œIt is
  the duty of the trial court to follow the decision of the appellate court.â€Â  Ackerman
    v. McMillan, 324 S.C. 440, 443, 477 S.E.2d 267, 268 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  Thus,
  it is error for a trial court to consider an issue that was not included in the
  remand instructions.Â  Id.  
Following
  a remand, the trial court acquires jurisdiction to enforce the judgment and
  take any action consistent with this Courtâ€™s ruling.Â  Id.Â  â€œMatters
  decided by the appellate court cannot be reheard, reconsidered, or relitigated
  in the trial court, even under the guise of a different form.â€Â  Id.Â  
 
In
  the present case, this Court previously concluded Hospitalâ€™s Quality Assurance
  Committee was within the purview of section 40-71-10 to the extent the
  committee operated pursuant to bylaws approved by Hospital.Â  Nevertheless, the trial court was
  specifically instructed to examine the Quality Assurance Committee file to
  determine if it â€œwarrants confidentialityâ€ and if there was â€œany evidence not
  protected by the confidentiality statute.â€ Â When conducting the in camera
  review, however, the trial court went beyond the remand instructions to find
  that Hospital â€œwaived its privilege to claim the confidentiality of the Quality
  Assurance [F[ile.â€
We recognize that this Court in its prior opinion stated that
  â€œ[i]n camera reviews should be used liberally to guard against even a mere
  possibility a miscarriage of justice will occur,â€ and directed the trial court
  to use its discretion when reviewing the file.Â  Nevertheless, for the reasons
  we stated in the preceding section of this opinion, we hold the remand
  instructions did not authorize the trial court to consider whether Hospital had
  waived its right to assert the file was confidential. Â The possibility that such
  a privilege may have been waived does not affect a determination of whether or
  not the evidence in the file was protected under section 40-71-20 in the first
  place.Â   
3.Â  In reviewing the appealed
  order in this case, we note the trial court, in addition to finding Hospital
  had waived the protections of section 40-71-20, concluded â€œthe committee file
  does contain relevant evidence that is not protected by the confidentiality
  statute.â€Â  The order, however, does not describe the evidence or explain why it
  is not protected by section 40-71-20.Â  Accordingly, we remand the matter to the
  trial court to set forth the specific portions of the Quality Assurance
  Committee file that are subject to discovery as well as the reasons these
  portions are not confidential under section 40-71-20.
4.Â  Based on our disposition
  of this appeal, we do not address Hospitalâ€™s remaining argument concerning
  whether its disclosure of certain information under Rule 33, SCRCP, in fact
  constituted a waiver of the protection of section 40-17-20.Â  See Futch
    v. McAllister Towing of Georgetown, Inc., 335 S.C. 598, 613, 518 S.E.2d
  591, 598 (1999) (ruling an appellate court need not review remaining issues
  when its determination of a prior issue is dispositive of the appeal).
CONCLUSION
We hold the trial
  court, in reviewing the Quality Assurance Committee file pursuant to this
  Courtâ€™s prior opinion, exceeded its authority in finding Hospital had waived
  its right to invoke the protections of South Carolina Code section 40-71-20.Â 
  The issue of waiver was neither raised in the prior appeal nor mentioned by
  this Court when it decided the matter.Â  Nevertheless, because the trial court
  on remand found â€œthe committee file does contain relevant evidence that is not
  protected by the confidentiality statute,â€ we again remand the matter to the
  trial court to set forth the evidence in the file that is subject to discovery
  and to explain why, consistent with the language in this Courtâ€™s prior opinion,
  this evidence â€œis not protected by the confidentiality statute.â€
REVERSED AND REMANDED.
HEARN,
  C.J., KITTREDGE and THOMAS, JJ., concur. 

[1]Â  South Carolina Code section 40-71-10 exempts members
  of certain professional committees from tort liability.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  40-71-10 (2001 and Supp. 2007).Â  Under section 40-71-20, â€œ[a]ll proceedings of and
  all data and information acquired by the committee referred to in Section
  40-71-10 in the exercise of its duties are confidential unless a respondent in
  the proceeding requests in writing that they be made public.â€Â  Id. Â§ 40-71-20(A).Â  Section 40-71-20 further provides in pertinent part that
  â€œ[t]hese proceedings and documents are not subject to discovery, subpoena, or
  introduction into evidence in any civil action except upon appeal from the
  committee action.â€Â  Id.Â  The statute further provides, however, that
  â€œ[i]nformation, documents, or records which are otherwise available from
  original sources are not immune from discovery or use in a civil action merely
  because they were presented during the committee proceedings . . . .â€Â  Id.
[2]Â  We further reject Princeâ€™s
  allegation that the judge who had presided at the trial of the matter had â€œ
  â€˜intertwinedâ€™ the waiver issue with confidentiality by denying [Princeâ€™s motion
  to compel], holding he had all ready [sic] ruled on the issue of
  confidentiality.â€Â  We have reviewed those portions of the transcript cited in
  Princeâ€™s brief to support this assertion and were unable to discern how the
  judgeâ€™s rulings could be interpreted to equate a ruling on the issue of
  confidentiality with a ruling on waiver.

title: State v. Moore
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE


THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE
  CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		State of South Carolina,  Respondent,
		v.
		Dominique Donte
      Moore, Appellant.
	


Appeal from York County
John C. Hayes, III, Circuit Court Judge 
Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-135
Submitted March 3, 2008 â€“ Filed March 4,
  2008
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				James W. Boyd, of Rock Hill, for Appellant.
				Attorney General Henry D. McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General
  John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott,
  Assistant Attorney General Christina J. Catoe, all of Columbnia; and Solicitor Kevin
  S. Brackett, of York, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER
  CURIAM:Â  Dominique Donte Moore (Moore) was convicted of possession with
  intent to distribute (PWID) crack cocaine.Â  He received a twenty-five year
  sentence and a fine of $50,000.Â  Moore argues the court erred in admitting into
  evidence money seized from his person and related testimony.Â  We affirm. [1]
FACTS
At
  2:30 AM, April 25, 2006, an officer with the Rock Hill Police Department
  stopped Mooreâ€™s vehicle for violation of a noise ordinance.Â  After exhibiting
  what the officer considered suspicious behavior, Moore was asked to step out of
  the car.Â  The officer observed Moore holding a plastic bag in his hand, which
  he dropped during a struggle.Â  The bag contained 1.07 grams of crack cocaine.Â 
  Another .06 grams were found in Mooreâ€™s back pocket.Â  No additional drugs or
  paraphernalia were found in a search of Mooreâ€™s car, but $1,362 in cash was
  seized from his person.Â  The cash consisted of six $100 bills, thirty $20
  bills, ten $10 bills, six $5 bills, and thirty-two $1 bills. Â After receiving
  his Miranda rights, Moore told the officers he did not use crack.Â  When
  asked if he sold it, Moore answered, â€œI do what I have to do to get by.â€Â  With Moore in custody, he refused to sign the money over to the police. Â He later told them the
  money was not his, though he refused to say to whom it belonged.Â  Later still,
  he said it was his motherâ€™s money.Â  The State then listed her name on the
  consent order of forfeiture.
In a
  pretrial motion to suppress, Moore contended the money should not be admitted
  because (1) no evidence linked or traced it to any illegal drug activity; (2)
  assuming the money was traceable to illegal drug activity, no evidence traced
  it to the particular drugs in this case; and (3) the State, by naming Mooreâ€™s
  mother the owner in the consent order for forfeiture, was collaterally estopped
  from arguing the money belonged to Moore.Â   
In
  support of the admission of the money, the State presented evidence that crack
  cocaine is typically sold in $20 rocks, though sales may be in larger amounts
  for more money.Â  Additionally, the State asserted the evidence was more
  relevant because of Mooreâ€™s unemployment.Â  The State argued the consent order
  was irrelevant to the case and unrelated to any connection between the money
  and drugs.  
The
  trial judge ruled the evidence of the $20 bills would be admissible if an
  officer testified a single crack cocaine rock typically sells for $20.Â  Without
  further testimony, however, the other money did not constitute circumstantial
  evidence and would not be admitted.Â  Concerning the forfeiture order, the trial
  judge said the State would have been wise to name both the mother and Moore,
  but doing so would have gone against the motherâ€™s consent.Â  From the record, it
  appears the mother claimed she loaned the money to Moore.Â  Because the mother
  â€œdidnâ€™t completely say it was her money,â€ the trial judge reasoned it was Mooreâ€™s money but subject to repayment.Â  Neither party made further motions at the
  suppression hearing.Â  At trial, an officer submitted that crack cocaine rocks
  usually sell for $20 and, over Mooreâ€™s objections, the officer told of the $20
  bills found during the arrest.Â  After the close of the Stateâ€™s evidence, the
  court denied Mooreâ€™s directed verdict motion.
STANDARD
  OF REVIEW
In criminal cases,
  the appellate court sits to review errors of law only.Â  State v. Wilson,
  345 S.C. 1, 545 S.E.2d 827 (2001); State v. Wood, 362 S.C. 520, 608
  S.E.2d 435 (Ct. App. 2004); State v. Mattison, 352 S.C. 577, 575 S.E.2d
  852 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  This court is bound by the trial courtâ€™s factual findings
  in determining the admissibility of certain evidence in criminal cases.Â  Wilson, 345 S.C. at 6, 545 S.E.2d at 829.Â  The admission of evidence is within the
  discretion of the trial court and will not be reversed absent an abuse of
  discretion.Â  State v. Pagan, 369 S.C. 201, 207, 631 S.E.2d 262, 265
  (2006); State v. Gaster, 349 S.C. 545, 557, 564 S.E.2d 87, 93 (2002); State
    v. Cherry, 353 S.C. 263, 272-73, 577 S.E.2d 719, 723 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  An
  abuse of discretion occurs when the conclusions of the trial court either lack
  evidentiary support or are controlled by an error of law.Â  Pagan, 369
  S.C. at 208, 631 S.E.2d at 265; State v. McDonald, 343 S.C. 319, 540
  S.E.2d 464 (2000); State v. Walker, 366 S.C. 643, 623 S.E.2d 122 (Ct.
  App. 2005).Â  In order for an error of law to warrant reversal, the error must
  result in prejudice to the appellant.Â  State v. Beck, 342 S.C. 129, 536
  S.E.2d 679 (2000); State v. Wyatt, 317 S.C. 370, 453 S.E.2d 890 (1995); State
    v. Patterson, 367 S.C. 219, 625 S.E.2d 239 (Ct. App. 2006).
DISCUSSION
Moore argues the trial court erred in admitting into
  evidence money seized from his person upon arrest and related testimony because
  the money was irrelevant and prejudicial under Rule 403, SCRE.Â   
Section
  44-53-375(B) of the South Carolina Code â€œcreates a permissive inference that
  possession of more than one gram of crack cocaine constitutes possession with
  intent to distribute.â€Â  State v. Robinson, 344 S.C. 220, 223, 543 S.E.2d
  249, 250 (Ct. App. 2001); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-53-375(B) (2002).Â  â€œPossession of
  any amount of controlled substance coupled with sufficient indicia of intent to
  distribute will support a conviction for possession with intent to
  distribute.â€Â  State v. James, 362 S.C. 557, 561-62, 608 S.E.2d 455, 457
  (Ct. App. 2004), cert. dismissed, Op. No. 26393 (S.C. Sup. Ct. filed Nov. 19, 2007) (Shearouse Ad. Sh. No. 40 at 16), (quoting Matthews v. State,
  300 S.C. 238, 239, 387 S.E.2d 258, 259 (1990)).
The
  trial court based its decision to admit the evidence on State v. Cherry,
  353 S.C. 263, 577 S.E.2d 719 (Ct. App. 2001), a case where money found on the
  defendant upon arrest was relevant evidence supporting a PWID crack cocaine
  conviction.Â  Although Moore states the facts of Cherry are distinguishable
  from those in this case, there is a strong parallel.Â   
In Cherry,
  the defendant was a passenger in a car stopped for two traffic violations.Â  A
  pat-down search revealed eight crack cocaine rocks and $322.Â  Cherry was
  charged with PWID crack cocaine.Â  During an in limine motion,
  Cherry attempted to suppress the money arguing it was irrelevant.Â  The State
  countered the money was relevant to show intent to sell the crack cocaine on
  his person because it commonly sold for $20 per rock. Â The trial judge
  refrained from ruling on admissibility until hearing testimony.Â  Over Cherryâ€™s
  objection to the money testimony, the arresting officer told the court no drug
  paraphernalia was found in the car, the stop was made in a high crime area, the
  money found on Cherry was mostly $20 bills, and crack cocaine is generally sold
  in $20 rocks.Â  Â The court denied Cherryâ€™s motion for a directed verdict finding
  the evidence was sufficient to submit the case to the jury.Â  On appeal, Cherry
  complained of error in overruling his objection. Â This Court agreed with the
  State that the money was admissible instructing:

	Evidence
  is relevant, and therefore admissible, when it tends to make the existence of a
  fact in controversy more or less probable than it would be without the
  evidence.Â  Rule 401, SCRE.Â  The money was relevant to the contested question of
  whether Cherry intended to distribute the crack rocks in his possession.Â  In
  light of the officerâ€™s testimony regarding the price of crack rocks, the $322
  in mostly twenties was some indication that Cherry had sold crack earlier in
  the evening and thus, its admission into evidence tended to make the allegation
  he intended to distribute the crack in his watch pocket more probable.Â  The
  money was properly admitted.Â  

Id. at 274, 577 S.E.2d at 724.
In a divided review, this Court again affirmed Cherry's conviction
  relying, in part, on the money as supporting evidence.Â  State v. Cherry,
  348 S.C. 281, 559 S.E.2d 297 (Ct. App. 2001) (en banc), affâ€™d in
    result, 361 S.C. 588, 606 S.E.2d 475 (2004). Â â€œ[T]he majority opinion found the following evidence
  justified the trial court's decision to deny Cherry's motion for a directed
  verdict: (1) Cherry was arrested in high crime area known for violence and drug
  activity; (2) Cherry had in his possession a small bag containing eight rocks
  of crack cocaine; (3) he had no drug paraphernalia with him indicating the
  crack cocaine was for his personal consumption; (4) he had $322 in cash, in mostly twenty dollar bills; and (5) a single rock
  of crack cocaine typically sold for twenty dollars.â€Â  State v. James,
  362 S.C. 557, 564, 608 S.E.2d 455, 458 (Ct. App. 2004) (emphasis added) (citing Cherry, 348 S.C. at 285, 559 S.E.2d at 299); see also State
    v. Elmore, 368 S.C. 230, 628 S.E.2d 271 (Ct. App. 2006) cert. denied Apr. 5, 2007 (trial court properly denied directed verdict motion on charge of PWID
  marijuana where search found numerous baggies of marijuana in defendantâ€™s car,
  no marijuana residue or paraphernalia, and $653 cash on person); cf. James,
  362 S.C. 557, 608 S.E.2d 455 (Ct. App. 2004) (insufficient evidence to submit
  to jury charge of PWID crack cocaine where, inter alia, defendant
  did not have a large amount of cash on his person, and amount of crack
  speculative because bag seen only briefly by officer and never recovered for
  testing).
Moore, who carried $1,362 in
  cash consisting of six $100 bills, thirty $20 bills, ten $10 bills, six $5
  bills, and thirty-two $1 bills, claims the mixed denominations removes his case
  from the ambit of Cherry.Â  We disagree.Â  Here, Moore carried $600 in $20
  bills.Â  The relevance of this sizable amount is not diluted by the significant
  amount held in other denominations.Â  Because the money was relevant evidence,
  analysis of whether Moore was prejudiced is unwarranted.Â   
In
  his brief, Moore averred the purpose of admitting the money was to indicate Moore sold crack earlier in the evening, and prior sales would constitute other bad acts
  requiring a clear and convincing standard of proof.Â  This argument was not presented
  to the trial judge and is not preserved for our review.Â  â€œArguments not raised or
  ruled upon by the trial court are not preserved for appellate review.â€Â  State
    v. Carlson, 363 S.C. 586, 597, 611 S.E.2d 283, 288 (Ct. App. 2005); State
      v. Wise, 359 S.C. 14, 596 S.E.2d 475 (2004); State v. Perez, 334
  S.C. 563, 514 S.E.2d 754 (1999).
Moore contends the State should be collaterally estopped
  from introducing the money into evidence because
  the consent order of forfeiture named Mooreâ€™s mother as the owner. Â This
  argument fails.Â  â€œ[C]ollateral estoppel prevents a party
  from relitigating in a subsequent suit an issue actually and necessarily
  litigated and determined in a prior action.â€Â Â  Koon v. State, 358 S.C.
  359, 364-65, 595 S.E.2d 456, 459 (2004) (overruled on other grounds by State
    v. Gentry, 363 S.C. 93, 610 S.E.2d 494 (2005)) (citing Jinks v. Richland
      County, 355 S.C. 341, 585 S.E.2d 281 (2003)).Â  â€œIn order to successfully
  assert collateral estoppel, the party seeking issue preclusion must show that
  the issue was actually litigated and directly determined in the prior action,
  and that the matter or fact directly in issue was necessary to support the
  first judgment.â€Â  Town of Sullivanâ€™s Island v. Felger, 318 S.C. 340,
  344, 457 S.E.2d 626, 628 (Ct. App. 1995).Â   
Moore has
  offered no precedent showing a civil forfeiture proceeding may be defensively
  asserted to have a binding effect on a subsequent criminal trial.Â  The law of South Carolina is clear: â€œ[O]nce a person has been criminally convicted he is bound by that
  adjudication in a subsequent civil proceeding based on the same facts
  underlying the criminal conviction.â€Â  Doe v. Doe, 346 S.C. 145, 148, 551
  S.E.2d 257, 258 (2001).Â  Whereas a criminal convictionâ€™s greater degree of
  proof justifies utilization of collateral estoppel in later civil actions, the
  logic does not apply when applied in reverse.Â  â€œ[W]hen a conviction is offered
  in a civil proceeding against the party convicted, the party cannot complain of
  a difference in the degree of proof when the burden of proof in the criminal
  proceeding was much higher than the burden of proof in the present civil
  proceeding.â€Â  Id. at 149, 551 S.E.2d at 259; see also Crum
    & Forster Ins. Co. v. Goodmark Indus., Inc., 488 F.Supp.2d 241, 244
  (E.D.N.Y. 2007) (citing Gelb v. Royal Globe Ins. Co., 798 F.2d 38, 43
  (2d Cir. 1986)) (â€œThe government bears a higher burden of proof in the criminal
  than the civil context and consequently may rely on the collateral estoppel
  effect of a criminal conviction in a subsequent civil case.â€)Â   
CONCLUSION
The
  trial judge did not abuse his discretion in admitting the evidence of the $20
  bills found on Moore at the time of his arrest.Â  Accordingly, Mooreâ€™s
  conviction is
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON,
  SHORT, AND THOMAS, JJ., concur.

[1]  We decide this case without oral argument
  pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: Palmetto Bay Club Owners Association v. Brissie
text:
THIS OPINION
  HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN
  ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Palmetto Bay Club Owners Association, a South Carolina Non-Profit Corporation Administration for the Palmetto Bay Club Horizontal
      Property Regime, Respondent,
			
		
	

v.

	
		
			
				Danna Cooper
      Brissie, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Beaufort County
Â Curtis L. Coltrane, Master-in-Equity
Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-140
Heard November 6, 2007 â€“ Filed March 4,
  2008Â Â  
REVERSED and REMANDED


	
		
			
				Terry A. Finger, of Hilton Head Island, for Appellant.
				Otto W. Ferrene, Jr., of Hilton Head Island, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  Â Danna Cooper
  Brissie appeals from an order by the Master-in-Equity which, inter alia,
  granted an injunction to the Palmetto Bay Club Owners Association (Palmetto Bay).Â  We reverse.
FACTS
This matter arises out of a dispute over a condominium unit (Penthouse)
  located in the Palmetto Bay Club on Hilton Head Island, South Carolina.Â  All of the condominium units are subject to the Master
  Deed (Deed) and Bylaws of Palmetto Bay. Â Penthouse was originally designed as
  two separate condominium units, 504 and 505; however during construction,
  prospective buyers Jim and Tammy Faye Baker indicated they were interested in a
  penthouse unit combining the two condominiums.Â  As a result, Penthouse is unique
  among Palmetto Bay units, because units 504 and 505 were united when Penthouse
  was completed without a wall separating the two. Â Because it was constructed as
  separate units, Penthouse has duplicates of certain unit features, including
  two utility meters, breaker panels, mailboxes, kitchen areas, balconies, washer
  and dryer connections, water heaters, heating and air conditioning systems,
  refrigerator connections and parking spaces. Â 
Brissie
  originally purchased Penthouse from Helen Valois in 1994.Â  Brissie sold Penthouse
  to her sister in 1998 and subsequently re-purchased it in 2001.Â  During Brissieâ€™s
  first ownership period, she erected an interior wall between the two units
  comprising Penthouse. Â Brissie was notified by the property management company[1] for Palmetto Bay that under the Deed and Bylaws, her alterations to the building
  required advance approval from the Associationâ€™s Board of Directors (Board). Â Additionally,
  the management company also sent Brissie a copy of Palmetto Bayâ€™s Deed. Â Brissie dismantled the wall in June of 1997. Â 
Upon
  re-purchasing Penthouse in 2001 from her sister, Brissie sent a letter to
  Valois, who was then President of the Board, indicating Brissieâ€™s plans to
  alter the Penthouse. Â In her letter, Brissie requested Valois share her plans
  with the Board and indicated Brissie would assume alterations could be made if
  the Board did not respond within thirty days. Â When the Board did not respond,
  Brissie erected a portion of a wall and completed a second kitchen in one of
  the units of the Penthouse. Â Furthermore, Brissie replaced an existing set of
  French doors which had divided the units since the time of Valoisâ€™ ownership of
  the Penthouse, with a smaller lock-out door system, similar to those found
  between connecting hotel rooms. Â Thereafter, Palmetto Bay instructed her to
  cease alterations to Penthouse and return the Penthouse to its original
  condition. Â When Brissie refused, Palmetto Bay filed this action for an
  injunction and attorneyâ€™s fees. Â 
The master
  found an ambiguity existed in the Deed, created by the plans which were
  attached and incorporated into the Deed. Â These plans show a solid wall with no
  opening or doorway connecting the two units.Â  The master nevertheless found the
  alterations Brissie made to Penthouse violated Palmetto Bayâ€™s Deed and Bylaws.Â 
  Furthermore, the master found the letter sent to Valois from Brissie failed to
  provide the Board with adequate notice as required by the Deed and Bylaws. Â The
  issue of attorneyâ€™s fees was held in abeyance until a further hearing could be
  conducted. Â Brissie subsequently filed a motion to alter or amend which
  was denied.Â  This appeal followed.  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Whether
  the action is one at law or in equity is determined by the nature of the
  pleadings and the character of the relief sought.Â  In re Estate of Holden,
  343 S.C. 267, 278, 539 S.E.2d 703, 709 (2000).Â  The interpretation of a
  deed and an action to enforce restrictive covenants by injunction are both
  equitable matters. South Carolina Dept. of Natural Resources v. Town of
    McClellanville, 345 S.C. 617, 622, 550 S.E.2d 299, 302 (2001); Eldridge
      v. Greenwood, 331 S.C. 398, 416, 503 S.E.2d 191, 200 (Ct. App.
  1998).
In an action in equity, tried by a master without a
  jury, this court may view the evidence to determine facts in accordance with
  its own view of the preponderance of the evidence. Â McClellanville 345
  S.C. at 622, 550 S.E.2d at 302.Â  On appeal, we are to consider the equities of
  both sides, balancing the two to determine what, if any, relief to give.Â  Anderson v. Buonforte, 365 S.C. 482, 493, 617 S.E.2d 750, 755 (Ct. App. 2005).Â 
  When reviewing the findings of fact in an equitable action, this court will not
  disturb findings of fact which are sufficiently supported by the evidence. Â Parrot
    v. Dickson Hall v. Walker, 151 S.C. 114, 120, 148 S.E. 704, 706 (1929). 
 
LAW/ANALYSIS
Brissie contends
  the master erred in finding the plain and obvious purpose of the Deed was
  defeated by installing a lock-out door system in the Penthouse.Â  We agree.
In the present
  case, a document incorporated into the Deed as Exhibit B, describes the Penthouse
  as a â€œB/Câ€ unit.Â  The Deed also offers a narrative description of each unit in
  Exhibit C; however, although â€œUnit Type Bâ€, and â€œUnit Type Câ€ are each
  described separately, no explanation or description exists for a B/C unit.Â  Moreover,
  the Deed provides in Article II, Section 2, that â€œ[t]he Units are of the
  general design as graphically depicted in the certified architectâ€™s plans which
  are compiled and annexed to this Master Deed at Exhibit F.â€Â   
The master found
  that â€œthe Master Deed has an ambiguity.â€Â  He based this finding on the fact
  that, although Article II, Section 2 of the Deed states that Palmetto Bay is
  limited to a total of fifty-nine condominium units, the plans for Palmetto Bay
  attached to the Deed show Unit 504/505 being divided by a one-hour firewall.Â 
  Accordingly, the master found that â€œthe ambiguity is created by the fact that
  the drawing shows the unit as being divided by a wall.â€Â  Â No appeal was taken
  from this finding of an ambiguity; as such, it is the law of the case. Â Resolution
    Trust Corp. v. Eagle Lake & Golf Condominiums, 310 S.C. 473, 476, 427
  S.E.2d 646, 648 (1993) (the trial judgeâ€™s procedural ruling is the law of the
  case since it has not been appealed); See also Toal, Vafai, and
  Muckenfuss, Appellate Practice in South Carolina 80 (2d ed. 2002) (â€œIt is a
  fundamental rule of law that an appellate court will affirm a ruling by a lower
  court if the offended party does not challenge that rulingâ€).
Restrictive
  covenants, like the ones at issue in the Palmetto Bay Deed and Bylaws, are
  subject to the rules of contract construction. Houck v. Rivers, 316 S.C.
  414, 416, 450 S.E.2d 106, 108 (Ct. App. 1994).Â  Historically, restrictions on
  the use of property are disfavored in the law.Â  Sea Pines Plantation
    Co. v. Wells, 294 S.C. 266, 270, 363 S.E.2d 891, 893 (1987).Â  Accordingly,
  courts interpret restrictive covenants strictly and resolve any doubt or
  ambiguity in the covenants in favor of the free and unrestricted use of land.Â  Hyer
    v. McRee, 306 S.C. 210, 212, 410 S.E.2d 604, 605 (Ct. App. 1991).Â  We agree
  with the master that the Deed is ambiguous because of the drawings attached to
  it which depicted a solid wall separating unit 504 and 505.Â  However, once the
  master found an ambiguity existed, he should have construed that ambiguity in
  favor of Brissieâ€™s right to use her property without restriction.[2]
Although an
  ambiguity is found, a court should not use the rule of strict construction to
  defeat the plain and obvious purpose of the restrictive covenants.Â  Hardy v.
    Aiken, 369 S.C. 160, 166, 631 S.E.2d 539, 542 (2006).Â  Here however, both
  the Deed and the Bylaws provide procedures for the modification or alteration
  of individual units.Â  These include notice to the Board through an agent or the
  President of the Board, and provide a time period in which the Board has to
  reply. Â Therefore, construing the ambiguity before us to allow Brissie to
  replace a large set of French doors with a lock-out door system and partial
  wall to fill in the remaining space, does not defeat the plain and obvious
  purpose of the restrictive covenants.Â  Â Â 
Brissie puts forth several additional issues in her
  appeal from the masterâ€™s order, including the argument that she provided
  adequate notice to the Board of her intention to install the lock-out door in
  her letter to the Boardâ€™s president.Â  Brissie contends that when the Board did
  not respond to her letter within the applicable period, permission was granted under
  the Bylaws.Â  Because we find the
  determination of the issue above to be dispositive in the appeal before us, we
  need not review Brissieâ€™s remaining contentions.Â  See Futch v. McAllister Towing of Georgetown, Inc., 335 S.C. 598, 613, 518
    S.E.2d 591, 598 (1999) (ruling an appellate court need not review remaining issues when its determination of a prior issue
  is dispositive of the appeal).
CONCLUSION

  Based on the foregoing, we hold the master erred in granting Palmetto Bayâ€™s request for an injunction.Â  The issue of attorneyâ€™s fees is remanded to the
  master for disposition in light of our opinion.Â  The decision of the master is
  accordingly
REVERSED and
  REMANDED.
HEARN, C.J., and KITTREDGE and THOMAS, JJ., concur.


[1] Two companies, New Leaf Management Inc. and Allied
  Management Group, have served as the property manager for Palmetto Bay during the periods in which Brissie owned Penthouse. Â 
[2] It is undisputed that Brissieâ€™s installation of the
  interior lock-out door had no effect on the common areas of Palmetto Bay.

title: One Hundred Eighth Cookingham, Inc. v. Miller
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT
  BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				One Hundred
      Eighth Cookingham, Inc., Respondent,
			
		
	

v.

	
		
			
				David K.
      Miller, Julia J. Miller, Alan Fredrick Hagemaster and Andrew Lee Hagemaster, Appellants.
			
		
	


Appeal From Beaufort County
Â Curtis L. Coltrane, Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-141
Submitted February 1, 2008 â€“ Filed March
  4, 2008
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Brian Deen McDaniel, of Beaufort; Jonathan Brent Kiker, of Hilton Head Island, for Appellants.
				James M. Herring of Hilton Head Island and William Weston Jones Newton, of Bluffton, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  David
  and Julia Miller and Julia Millerâ€™s sons from a prior marriage, Alan and Andrew
  Hagemaster (collectively the Hagemasters), appeal an order setting aside certain
  property transfers as fraudulent pursuant to the Statute of Elizabeth.Â  We
  affirm.[1]
FACTS
On September 24, 2001, the Millers purchased a condominium in
  Village West in Hilton Head Island, South Carolina.Â  The purchase price for the
  condominium was $300,000, the entirety of which was paid by David Miller from
  his own funds.Â  According to the Millers, Julia Miller was to receive the
  property as compensation for relinquishing a tenured position with the University of Kansas when she married David in April 2001; however, the deed to the
  condominium listed the Millers as joint tenants with right of survivorship.
On June 27, 2002, One Hundred Eighth Cookingham, Inc., a Missouri corporation, filed a demand for arbitration against David, a Kansas resident, with
  the American Arbitration Association at its office in Kansas City, Missouri.Â  In the demand, Cookingham claimed $1,337,400 in damages for breach of a real
  estate and option contract, plus costs and expenses.Â  The date of the alleged
  breach was July 1, 1997.Â  On June 26, 2003, the arbitrator awarded Cookingham
  $789,039 plus costs, finding all issues in favor of Cookingham.
By quitclaim deed dated July 25, 2003, and recorded on July 30,
  2003, in the Office of the Register of Deeds for Beaufort County, South Carolina, David and Julia transferred the condominium to Julia for no consideration.Â 
  In addition, by deed dated July 25, 2003, and recorded July 31, 2003, Julia
  deeded the condominium to the Hagemasters for no consideration, reserving a
  life estate for herself and David.
On December 23, 2003, the arbitratorâ€™s award was enrolled in the
  circuit court of Clay County, Missouri, as a final judgment.Â  Thereafter, on
  February 16, 2005, the Missouri judgment was enrolled in the Beaufort Court of
  Common Pleas as a South Carolina judgment.
In 2005, Cookingham petitioned the Beaufort County Court of Common
  Pleas to set aside the conveyances pursuant to the Statute of Elizabeth.Â  The
  trial court set aside both the 2001 grant of a one-half interest in the
  property to Julia and Davidâ€™s subsequent conveyance in 2003 of his half
  interest in the property.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œAn
  action to set aside a transfer of land as fraudulent pursuant to the Statute of
  Elizabeth is an action in equity.â€Â  Albertson v. Robinson, 371, S.C.
  311, 315, 638 S.E.2d 81, 83 (Ct. App. 2006) (citing Future Group, II v.
    Nationsbank, 324 S.C. 89, 97 n.6, 478 S.E.2d 45, 49 n.6 (1996)).Â  In an
  action in equity tried without a reference, the appellate court may find facts
  in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence. Â Townes
    Assoc., Ltd. v. City of Greenville, 266 S.C. 81, 86, 221 S.E.2d 773, 775-76
  (1976).Â  Notwithstanding this broad scope of review, however, the appellate
  court does not disregard the findings of fact by the trial judge, â€œwho saw and heard the witnesses and was in a better
  position to evaluate their credibility.â€Â  Tiger, Inc. v. Fisher-Agro, Inc.,
  301 S.C. 229, 237, 311 S.E.2d 538, 53 (1989).
LAW/ANALYSIS
1.Â  The Millers and the
  Hagemasters argue the Statute of Elizabeth cannot be used to set aside the conveyances
  at issue because both the initial acquisition of the condominium by David and
  Julia Miller and the subsequent transfer of Davidâ€™s interest to Julia were
  supported by valuable consideration.Â  We disagree.
Under
  the Statute of Elizabeth, a transfer of real property made to prevent a
  creditor from collecting on a debt â€œmust be deemed and taken . . . to be
  clearly and utterly void, frustrate and of no effect, any pretense, color,
  feigned consideration, expressing of use, or any other matter or thing to the
  contrary notwithstanding.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 27-23-10(A) (2007).Â   
A conveyance
  may be set aside as fraudulent under the Statute of Elizabeth if it was voluntary
  or if there is actual intent to defraud the grantorâ€™s creditors.Â  Royal Z Lanes,
    Inc. v. Collins Holding Corp., 337 S.C. 592, 595, 524 S.E.2d 621, 622
  (1999).Â  A voluntary conveyance is a gratuitous transfer of property or one
  without valuable consideration.Â  Id. at 594-95, 524 S.E.2d at 622.Â  To
  set aside a voluntary conveyance, a creditor must establish the following:Â  (1)
  the grantor was indebted to the creditor at the time of the transfer; (2) the
  conveyance was voluntary; and (3) the grantor failed to retain sufficient
  property to pay the indebtedness to the creditor in full, not merely at the
  time of transfer, but in the final analysis when the creditor seeks to collect
  the debt.Â  Mathis v. Burton, 319 S.C. 261, 265, 460 S.E.2d 406, 408 (Ct.
  App. 1995).Â   
The
  Millers and the Hagemasters contend the transfers that One Hundred Eighth
  Cookingham sought to invalidate were supported by valuable consideration,
  namely, the $300,000 in income that Julia purportedly forfeited in order to
  marry David.Â  In support of their argument, they cite their uncontradicted testimony
  that (1) the sole purpose of acquiring the condominium was to induce Julia to
  marry David and to compensate her for the income she forfeited in so doing; and
  (2) the initial deed giving title to both David and Julia was an oversight and only
  Julia should have received title to the property.  
Notwithstanding
  the absence of evidence discrediting their statements, the Millers failed to
  carry their burden of establishing both valuable consideration and the bona
  fides of the transfer by clear and convincing evidence.Â  See Gardner v. Kirven, 184 S.C. 37, 41, 191 S.E. 814, 816 (1936) (â€œWhere transfers to members of the family are attacked
  either upon the ground of actual fraud or on account of their voluntary
  character, the law imposes the burden on the transferee to establish both a
  valuable consideration and the bona fides of the transaction by
  clear and convincing testimony.â€).Â  The trial court specifically found the
  Millers lacked credibility and gave sound reasons for this finding.Â  These
  reasons included the following:Â  (1) it was illogical that Julia, having been
  advised in early 2001 about her grave medical prognosis, would not make the
  certain the condominium was properly titled solely in her name in accordance
  with the purported agreement; (2) the Millersâ€™ assertion that they never
  discussed Davidâ€™s business difficulties was questionable considering their
  demonstrated â€œability and willingness to discuss potentially touchy subjects at
  some depth during their discussions about the marriageâ€ and the timing of the
  demand for arbitration vis-Ã -vis that of the arbitration hearing; (3) the
  Millersâ€™ contention that it was only when Julia learned she was cancer-free, which
  was coincidentally during the same months the arbitration proceeding was
  pending, that they realized their supposed agreement would be upset if she
  pre-deceased David; and (4) Juliaâ€™s testimony that her sons had no knowledge of
  Davidâ€™s difficulties and no knowledge of the conveyance of the condominium to
  them actually supported a finding that this subsequent conveyance was not a
  bona fide transfer.Â  These reasons also support the trial courtâ€™s finding that
  the Millers did not enter into any agreement before their marriage under which
  David was to purchase property and title it in Juliaâ€™s name as consideration
  for her loss of income from taking early retirement.
2.Â  The Millers and the Hagemasters also argue Julia was an
  innocent purchaser without knowledge of any indebtedness to Cookingham.Â  Specifically,
  they contend that â€œ[b]y accepting the deed(s) to the subject property, Julia
  Miller merely was exercising her own right to the property in accordance with
  the contract she had with her husband; a contract upon which she fully
  performed.â€Â  Because, however, we uphold the trial courtâ€™s finding that there
  was no such contract, we do not address this argument.Â  See Futch v.
    McAllister Towing of Georgetown, 335 S.C. 598, 613, 518 S.E.2d 591, 598
  (1999) (explaining an appellate court need not address remaining issues when its
  decision concerning prior issues is dispositive of the case).
3.Â  We also reject the
  contention of the Millers and the Hagemasters that David that the Statute of
  Elizabeth is inapplicable to this case because David was not a debtor of Cookingham
  at the time of the initial acquisition of the condominium.Â  The inception of
  the debt or obligation controls rather than the date of the subsequent entry of
  judgment.Â  Matthews v. Montgomery, 193 S.C. 118, 133, 7 S.E.2d 841, 848
  (1940).Â  Moreover, as the supreme court stated in Matthews, â€œIt is only
  necessary that the debt should have been in existence or the right of action
  have accrued at or before the time of the transfer. It may be reduced to
  judgment at a later date.â€ Â Id.; see also Albertson, 371
  S.C. at 317-18, 638 S.E.2d at 84 (setting aside the conveyance of a marital
  home from a debtor to his wife pursuant to the Statute of Elizabeth and holding
  the pivotal event was when the debtor breached his contract with the party
  seeking to invalidate the transfer rather than the entry of judgment against
  him). Â 
In
  the present case, David became indebted to Cookingham when he breached the
  contract in 1997.Â  The acquisition of the condominium and the transfers at
  issue here did not occur until 2001 and 2003, several years after the breach.Â 
  We therefore hold Cookingham had obtained creditorâ€™s status at the time the
  Millers first acquired the condominium.
AFFIRMED.Â   
ANDERSON and
  THOMAS, JJ., and GOOLSBY, A.J., concur.

[1]Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant
  to Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR
  RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2),
  SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Judy Anne Yown, Respondent,
			
		
	

v.

	
		
			
				William Robert Yown, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Spartanburg County
Â Georgia V. Anderson, Family Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-145
Submitted November 1, 2007 â€“ Filed March
  6, 2008Â Â Â  
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				David Michael Collins, Jr., of Spartanburg, for Appellant.
				Edward A. Lamb, Richard H. Rhodes, both of Spartanburg, for
  Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM: William
  Robert Yown (Husband) appeals from the family court order granting Judy Anne
  Yown (Wife) a divorce, arguing the family court erred in its determination of
  marital property, valuation of special equity interests, and equitable division
  of the marital estate.Â  We affirm.[1] 
 
FACTS
Husband and Wife were married on September 16, 1998.Â  At the time
  of the marriage, both parties owned a pre-marital home and other personal
  pre-marital property.Â  Approximately two years into the marriage, Husband and
  Wife purchased a marital residence and subsequently sold their non-marital
  homes.[2]Â 
  A substantial portion of Husbandâ€™s proceeds from the sale of his non-marital
  home was paid toward the mortgage on the marital home and a lot adjoining the
  marital residence, both of which were titled jointly.Â  The remaining money from
  the sale of the non-marital homes was deposited into a joint checking account.[3]
Approximately seven years into the marriage, Husband and Wife separated,
  and Wife brought a separate maintenance action seeking equitable division of
  the marital estate and attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  At the hearing, Wife moved to amend her
  complaint to request a divorce on the ground of one year continuous separation.Â  The family court granted Wifeâ€™s motion and issued an order granting a
  divorce, dividing the marital estate equally between the parties, and awarding
  each party special equity interests in certain items of the marital estate.Â  This
  appeal followed.  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The family court
  has broad discretion in determining how marital property is to be valued and
  distributed; therefore, the court may use any reasonable means to divide the
  property equitably, and its judgment will only be disturbed where an abuse of
  discretion is found.Â  LaFrance v. LaFrance, 370 S.C. 622, 650-651, 636
  S.E.2d 3, 18 (2006).Â  In reviewing the family courtâ€™s equitable apportionment
  of marital property, an appellate courtâ€™s role is to examine the fairness of
  the apportionment as a whole.Â  Id. (citing Bragg v. Bragg, 347 S.C. 16, 24, 553 S.E.2d 251, 255 (Ct. App. 2001)).Â  Generally, an appellate court will affirm the family
  court if it can be determined the judge addressed the factors under the marital
  property statute sufficiently for the appellate court to conclude the judge was
  cognizant of the statutory factors.Â  Id. (citing Jenkins v. Jenkins, 345
  S.C. 88, 100, 545 S.E.2d 531, 537 (Ct. App. 2001)); see S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-472 (1985). 
 
LAW/ANALYSIS
Property Adjoining Marital Residence and Special
  Equity Interests
Husband
  alleges the family court erred by classifying the property adjoining the
  marital residence as marital property.Â  Husband also maintains the family court
  erred in its identification and valuation of the special equity interests of
  both parties in the marital residence.Â  We disagree.Â   
Husband
  asserts the adjoining lot was nonmarital property because it was purchased with
  proceeds from the sale of his pre-marital home.Â  Husbandâ€™s home was pre-marital
  property, and, ordinarily, property acquired in exchange for pre-marital
  property is not considered marital property.Â  However:

	[i]n
  certain circumstances, nonmarital property may be transmuted into marital
  property if: (1) it becomes so commingled with marital property as to be
  untraceable; (2) it is jointly titled; or (3) it is utilized by the parties in
  support of the marriage or in some other manner so as to evidence an intent by
  the parties to make it marital property.

Greene v. Greene, 351 S.C. 329, 338, 569 S.E.2d 393, 398 (Ct. App. 2002)(internal
  citations omitted). Â The property adjoining the marital estate was titled jointly.Â 
  The parties constructed a barn on the adjoining land and used it to store
  personal property belonging to both Husband and Wife.Â  The barn was constructed
  using an equity line of credit, which was paid with funds from the couplesâ€™
  joint account.Â  For these reasons, we do not find the family court erred by
  classifying the property adjoining the marital estate as marital property.Â  Furthermore, Husband was awarded a special equity interest for funds from the sale of his pre-marital home, which he contributed to the
  adjoining lot.Â  Â Â Â Â Â 
Husband
  also claims the family court erred in its identification and valuation of the
  special equity interests of both parties in the marital residence.Â  In the
  present case, the family court considered and ruled upon the special equity
  interests of both Husband and Wife.Â  Accordingly, if Husband believed
  the family court overlooked or failed to specifically rule on some additional
  special equity interest, he had the burden of presenting this issue to the
  family court.Â  However, Husband did not file a Rule 59(e), SCRCP, motion raising
  the issue of a specific equity interest valuation to the family court, and thus,
  we find this issue is not preserved for appeal. See Wilder
    Corp. v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998); see also Halbersberg v. Berry, 302 S.C. 97, 103, 394 S.E.2d 7, 12 (1990)
  (finding the omission of the master in equity not preserved because the party
  did not bring the omission to the attention of the master through a proper
  motion).
The Division of the Marital Estate
Husband
  further alleges the family court erred in calculating the division of the
  marital estate.Â  Specifically, Husband argues the
  family court erred by counting the value of the adjoining property twice in the
  equitable division.Â  We find this issue is not preserved. Â 
After
  the family court issued its order, Husband did not file a Rule 59(e), SCRCP, motion
  raising the issue of the double-inclusion of the adjoining lot to the family
  court judge.Â  Thus, we find this issue is not preserved for appeal.Â  See Wilder, 330 S.C. at 76, 497 S.E.2d at 733; see
    also Halbersberg, 302 S.C. at 103, 394 S.E.2d at 12.
CONCLUSION
Based
  on the foregoing, we find the family court did not err in its determination of marital property,
  valuation of special equity interests, or equitable division of the marital
  estate.Â  Accordingly, the decision
  of the family court is  
AFFIRMED. 
ANDERSON, SHORT, and WILLIAMS JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] Prior to the marriage, Wife had a house, with a
  mortgage, at 106 Blueberry Lane, Inman, and Husband had a house, with a
  mortgage, at 116 Shenandoah Drive, Spartanburg.Â  After the marriage, Husband
  and Wife resided in Husbandâ€™s Shenandoah home for approximately two years until
  they moved to 221 Williams Drive, Campobello.
[3] From the beginning of their marriage, Husband and
  Wife shared a joint checking account, which was managed by Husband with the
  Wifeâ€™s consent.Â  Both incomes, which were approximately equal, went into this
  account, and all bills, including mortgages and expenses for their non-marital
  properties were paid from this account.

  rights of Father.Â  The family court found his parental rights should be
  terminated on two grounds: (1) the children have been in DSSâ€™s custody for fifteen
  of twenty-two months; and (2) the children have been out of the home for six
  months and Father has failed to remedy the conditions which led to the
  removal.Â  Additionally, the family court found termination was in the best
  interest of the children.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572 (Supp. 2006).
After a thorough
  review of the record pursuant to Ex Parte Cauthen, 291 S.C. 465, 354
  S.E.2d 381 (1987), we affirm[1] the family courtâ€™s ruling and grant counselâ€™s petition to be relieved.
AFFIRMED.

title: Martin v. Halverson
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT
  BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Donald Martin, Appellant,
				v.
				Audrey
      Halverson, Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal From Lexington County
Â Richard W. Chewning, III, Family Court
  Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-152
Submitted March 3, 2008 â€“ Filed March 10,
  2008
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				John D. Elliott, of Columbia; for Appellant.
				William E. Bird, of Columbia; for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â 
  Donald Martin appeals certain provisions of a family court order concerning his
  visitation with his daughter.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS AND PROCEDURAL HISTORY
Reilly Ann Martin
  was born to Donald Martin and Audrey Halverson on July 5, 2000, while Halverson
  was separated from her husband.Â  Although Halverson and her husband later reconciled,
  Martin visited with Reilly regularly after her birth.
In April or May of 2002,
  Halverson informed Martin she, her husband, and Reilly were moving to Newport News , Virginia.Â  Because of this development, Martin brought suit in July 2002 to
  establish his paternity and ensure continued access to the child.
At a pendente lite hearing in the Lexington County Family Court on July 19, 2002, the
  parties informed the court they had reached an agreement under which they would
  have joint custody of Reilly with Halverson having primary custodial care and
  Martin being allowed to visit with her in Virginia at his own expense and with
  proper notice.Â  They also settled the issue of child support.Â  Because,
  however, they were unable to agree on other visitation terms, the family court
  set visitation on a temporary basis, granting Martin two one-week periods in
  the Fall of 2002, and provided a guardian ad litem would be
  appointed for Reilly if Martin and Halverson could not reach a mutually
  acceptable agreement concerning visitation between Martin and Reilly.
After the temporary hearing, the parties reached
  an agreement under which Martin would see Reilly for a week at a time when his
  work schedule allowed.Â  The arrangement continued until August 2004, when Reilly,
  while visiting relatives in Michigan with Martin, fractured her arm at a fast
  food restaurant playground.Â  After this occurrence, Halverson restricted
  Martinâ€™s visitation with Reilly, prompting him to bring another lawsuit, this
  time to establish visitation rights with Reilly in accordance with her age and
  school activities and taking into account the distance between the parties.Â  
 
Although
  the parties eventually agreed on visitation terms for Thanksgiving, Christmas,
  and spring vacation, they could not agree on terms for weekends and summer
  vacation.Â  In addition, they disagreed on transportation arrangements.
After
  taking testimony, the family court issued an order on February 3, 2006, requiring
  among other things that, for any three-day weekend visit in South Carolina, Halverson
  would take Reilly to Columbia and Martin would return her to Newport News at
  the end of the visit.Â  In addition, Martin was granted three weeks of
  visitation in the summer with Reilly.
Martin
  moved to alter or amend the order, asking the family court to reconsider
  transportation arrangements and requesting additional time to visit with Reilly
  in the summer.Â  After a hearing on June 12, 2006, the family court, by order
  dated August 10, 2006, declined to change the transportation arrangements, but
  granted Martin an additional week of visitation in the summer.Â  This appeal
  followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The
  determination of visitation is within the broad discretion of the family court,
  and, unless that discretion is abused, a visitation order will not be disturbed
  on appeal.Â  Cudd v. Arline, 277 S.C. 236, 239, 285 S.E.2d 881, 883
  (1981).Â  The family court may in its discretion impose on a noncustodial parent
  such conditions and restrictions on visitation as it finds proper.Â  Frye v.
    Frye, 323 S.C. 72, 76, 448 S.E.2d 586, 588 (Ct. App. 1994).Â  â€œThe privilege of visitation must yield to the good of the
  child and may be denied or limited where the best interests of the child will
  be served thereby.â€Â  Porter v. Porter, 246 S.C. 332, 340, 143
  S.E.2d 619, 624 (1965).
LAW/ANALYSIS
1.Â  Martin first contends the
  family court should have required both parents to meet halfway for most of the
  visits.Â  We disagree.Â   
In
  support of his position, Martin cites Patel v. Patel, 359 S.C. 515, 599
  S.E.2d 114 (Ct. App. 2004), in which this Court ordered the father of three
  children to pay transportation expenses for visits between him and the partiesâ€™
  two younger children, characterizing his his move to California with their
  oldest child as â€œunilateral.â€Â  Id. at 532, 599 S.E.2d at 123.Â  Martin also
  argues the family court overlooked the facts that he is the only parent who is
  employed and he therefore does not have a flexible schedule.Â   
Although
  these arguments support Martinâ€™s desire to meet Halverson halfway to exchange
  Reilly for visits, they do not warrant reversal of the family court order.Â 
  First, Patel, the case on which Martin relies, involved the issue of
  travel expenses incurred in the exercise of out-of-state visitation, not the
  issue of inconvenience to the noncustodial parent.Â  Moreover, there is nothing
  in the record to suggest that Halverson moved to Virginia to impair Martinâ€™s
  relationship with Reilly.Â  In addition, under the terms set by the family
  court, both Martin and Halverson have to travel one time from their respective
  home states and back to transport Reilly for visitation during three-day
  weekends.Â  Finally, the arrangement Martin desires reduces neither the burden
  nor the distance for either party.Â  Under these circumstances, we find the
  family court acted within its discretion in refusing to require the parties to
  meet halfway when exchanging Reilly for visits with Martin.
2.Â  Martin also contends the
  family court granted him insufficient time with Reilly in the summer.Â  He
  points out that Reilly is now in school and has thirteen weeks of summer
  vacation.Â  Citing Arnal v. Arnal, 363 S.C. 268, 609 S.E.2d 821 (Ct. App. 2005), affâ€™d as modified on other grounds, 371 S.C. 10, 636 S.E. 864
  (2006), he emphasizes that he would be better able to learn more about Reilly
  and her needs if given more time with the child to do so.Â  We, however, find no
  abuse of discretion in the family courtâ€™s decision to limit Martin to four
  weeks of visitation in the summer with Reilly.Â  See Woodall v.
    Woodall, 322 S.C. 7, 12, 471 S.E.2d 154, 158 (1996) (stating the issue of
  visitation is within the discretion of the family court).Â   
Based
  on the evidence in the record, we find the family court fashioned a summer
  visitation schedule that was in Reillyâ€™s best interest.Â  See id. (â€œWhen awarding visitation, the controlling consideration is the welfare and
  best interest of the child.â€).Â  As Halverson noted, during extended periods of
  visitation with Reilly, Martin would have to work, which would require him to
  put Reilly in some type of childcare environment.Â  Halverson further testified
  that, the one time she attempted to enroll Reilly in daycare, Reilly became
  confrontational.Â  Moreover, Halverson indicated she is amenable to increasing the
  summer visitation when Reilly is older.Â  We therefore hold that, considering
  Martinâ€™s work schedule, Reillyâ€™s age, and other pertinent factors, the summer
  visitation granted by the family court is reasonable and in Reillyâ€™s best
  interest.[2]
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, SHORT, and THOMAS, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant
  to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]Â  Halverson requested reinstatement of the family
  courtâ€™s original order, under which Martin received only three weeks of
  visitation in the summer; however, she did not file an appellantâ€™s brief on
  this issue.Â  We therefore hold the request is not properly before this Court
  and decline to address it.Â  See Rules 208(a)(1) and (b)(1)(B), SCACR
  (setting forth deadlines requirements for the appellantâ€™s initial brief,
  including a statement of each of the issues presented for review); id. Rule 21l (stating the deadlines and requirements for final briefs); id. Rule 231 (â€œWhenever it appears that an appellant or a petitioner has failed to
  comply with the requirements of these Rules, the clerk shall issue an order of
  dismissal, which shall have the same force and effect as an order of the
  appellate court.â€).
