THIS OPINION HAS NO
  PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Portside Owners
      Association, Inc., Appellant,
			
		
	

v.

	
		
			
				South Beach
      Racquet Club, Inc., Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal From Beaufort County
Curtis L. Coltrane, Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-153
Submitted January 1, 2008 â€“ Filed March
  11, 2008
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				RobertsÂ  Vaux, of Bluffton; for Appellant.
				Drew A. Laughlin, of Hilton Head Island; for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  Portside
  Owners Association, Inc. (Portside) filed this action against South Beach
  Racquet Club, Inc. (South Beach), seeking a determination of the partiesâ€™
  rights to a tract of real property.Â  South Beach prevailed at trial, and
  Portside appeals.Â  We affirm. [1]
FACTS
In
  1985, Charles Fraser created three corporations known as Beachside-Portside,
  Inc. (Beachside), Portside, and South Beach.Â  On September 29, 1986, Fraser
  conveyed six building lots, a common area, and a 50' access easement (the 50'
  Tract) to Beachside.
On
  September 30, 1986, Beachside recorded a Declaration of Covenants, Conditions
  and Restrictions for the six lots, common area, and 50' Tract comprising
  Portside Subdivision.Â  The covenants granted to the Portside homeowners the
  right to transfer interests in the common area.Â  In the covenants, Beachside
  reserved to itself a right to exercise the powers granted to Portside without
  the Portside ownersâ€™ consent.Â  However, this right expired if Beachside no
  longer owned at least two of the six lots.Â  By December 30, 1986, Beachside had
  conveyed all six of the residential lots to third parties.  
In
  1987 or 1988, South Beach prepared to build four tennis courts.Â  At the time, Fraser
  possessed a controlling interest in South Beach.Â  On May 26, 1987, Fraser, as
  president and on behalf of Beachside, wrote a letter to South Beach acknowledging and consenting to encroachment of the tennis courts into the 50' Tract (the
  Encroachment Letter).Â  The courts were built by 1988 and encroached into the 50'
  Tract.  
On
  May 14, 1992, Beachside conveyed â€œa perpetual, non-exclusive Easement and
  right-of-way for ingress and egress on, over and across the [50' Tract]â€ to South Beach in an â€œAccess Easementâ€ (the Easement).Â  The Easement was recorded on October
  30, 1992.Â  In addition to the rights of ingress and egress, the Easement stated
  South Beach â€œshall have the right to maintain such portions thereof as Grantee
  is presently maintaining for use as parking and landscaped areas, including the
  right, at the sole cost and expense of Grantee, to install such paving,
  curbing, drainage and irrigation facilities, and other similar or related improvements
  as Grantee shall require.â€  
Beachside
  conveyed the 50' Tract to Portside in a quit-claim deed, dated May 1, 1992, and
  recorded on November 6, 1992.Â  The deed states on its face that it is subject
  to â€œan easement for ingress and egress and parking reserved to South Beach
  Racquet Club, Inc. in that certain document entitled Access Easement, dated May
  14, 1992, by and between Grantor and South Beach Racquet Club, Inc.â€  
Approximately
  twelve years later, Portside filed this action on February 20, 2004, alleging the
  Easement and Encroachment Letter are invalid, thus South Beachâ€™s use of the
  Tract constitutes trespass.Â  Portside also sought declaratory relief.Â  The
  trial court found if Portsideâ€™s action against South Beachâ€™s use of the Tract
  is based on a breach of covenants, it is barred by the three year statute of
  limitations.Â  The trial court further found if the action is characterized as
  one for the recovery of real property, it is barred by the ten year statute of
  limitations for the recovery of real property.Â  The trial court also found,
  with respect to the tennis court encroachments, South Beach proved its claim
  for adverse possession.Â  Portside appeals.Â  Â 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œA
  suit for declaratory judgment is neither legal nor equitable, but is determined
  by the nature of the underlying issue.Â  An issue, essentially one at law, will
  not be transformed into one in equity simply because declaratory relief is
  sought.â€ Â Felts v. Richland County, 303 S.C. 354, 356, 400 S.E.2d 781, 782 (1991).Â  The character of an action as
  legal or equitable is determined by the main purpose of the complaint, the
  nature of the issues as raised by the pleadings or the pleadings and proof, and
  the character of the relief sought under them.Â  Ins. Fin. Servs., Inc. v. S.C.
    Ins. Co., 271 S.C. 289, 293, 247 S.E.2d 315, 318 (1978).  
The
  issue of title is legal in nature. Getsinger v. Midlands Orthopaedic Profit
    Sharing Plan, 327 S.C. 424, 428, 489 S.E.2d 223, 224 (Ct. App. 1997). â€œAn
  action brought for the primary purpose of determining title to a disputed land
  is in the nature of a trespass action to try title, which is an action at law.â€Â  Watson v. Suggs, 313 S.C. 291, 293, 437 S.E.2d 172, 173 (Ct.
  App. 1993).Â  An adverse possession claim is an action at law.Â  Clark v. Hargrave, 323 S.C. 84, 87, 473 S.E.2d 474, 476 (Ct. App. 1996).
In
  an action at law, on appeal of a case tried without a jury, we may not disturb
  the circuit courtâ€™s findings of fact unless they are unsupported by the
  evidence or controlled by error of law.Â  Auto Owners Ins. Co. v. Langford, 330 S.C. 578, 581, 500 S.E.2d 496, 498 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  
 
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.
  Â The Statutes of Limitations
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Portside initially argues
  its claims are not barred by the applicable statutes of limitations because it
  consented to South Beachâ€™s use of the 50' Tract until October 24, 2003, so that the applicable limitation periods for the
  actions for breach of the covenants and the recovery of real property did not
  commence until that date.Â  Thus, Portside argues, the action was initiated
  within the applicable statutory period of three years for breach of covenants and
  ten years for the action to recover real property. Â See S.C. Code Ann.
  Â§Â§ 15-3-340 & 15-3-530 (2005).Â   
A. Recovery of Real Property
We
  find Portsideâ€™s action is essentially an action for the recovery of real
  property and is barred by the ten year statute of limitations.Â  In determining
  whether a proceeding is an action for the recovery of real property within the
  meaning of the statute of limitations, the pleadings as a whole must be
  considered.Â  Winn v. Grantham, 263 S.C. 368, 371, 210 S.E.2d 602,
  603 (1974). Â â€œThe character of an
  action is not to be determined by the terminology which the pleaders may chance
  to give to it.â€ Â Walsh v. Evans, 112 S.C. 131,
  136, 99 S.E. 546, 548 (1919). Â â€œ[W]hen
  a defendantâ€™s right to property is attacked and in his answer he raises the
  â€˜flag of dominionâ€™ the issue of recovery has been established.â€Â  Winn,
  263 S.C. at 372, 210 S.E.2d at 604.Â  Â Â 
The gravamen
  of Portsideâ€™s complaint is to remove any cloud on its title in the 50' Tract and affirm its exclusive right to
  possession of the property. Â Portside attacked South Beachâ€™s use of the
  property as a violation of Portsideâ€™s exclusive rights.Â  As an action for the
  recovery of real property, the action is governed by section 15-3-340, which states
  that an action for the recovery of real property may not be maintained â€œunless
  it appears that the plaintiff, his ancestor, predecessor, or grantor, was
  seized or possessed of the premises in question within ten years before the
  commencement of the action.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-3-340 (2005).Â  Portside
  commenced this action to recover its exclusive rights in the property by filing
  its summons and complaint on February 20, 2004.Â  Therefore, under section
  15-3-340, Portsideâ€™s action may only be maintained if it was possessed of those
  exclusive rights to the 50' Tract within ten years
  of February 20, 2004, i.e., at any time after February 20, 1994.Â   
South Beach encroached on the property by building tennis courts in 1988 and received the
  Easement for ingress and egress in 1992, both more than ten years prior to the
  filing of this action.Â  To avoid the application of the statute, Portside
  argues it consented to South Beachâ€™s encroachment and use until 2003.Â Â   
B.  Consent
Portside argues it
  consented to South Beachâ€™s use of the property until October 24, 2003, the date
  it alleges it revoked its consent and thus, the statute of limitations did not
  begin to run until that date.Â  We disagree.Â Â Â   
We
  find evidence in the record to support the finding that Portside did not
  consent to South Beachâ€™s use of the 50' Tract.Â  The circuit courtâ€™s order does not specifically state that Portside did
  not consent.Â  However, the court stated that Portside â€œsuffered South Beach to use and maintain the encroachments, and to occupy the [50' Tract] in a manner consistent with the written
  easement for a period of more than ten years prior to bringing this action.â€ Â The
  South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure require that â€œ[i]n all actions tried
  upon the facts without a jury or with an advisory jury, the court shall find
  the facts specially and state separately its conclusions of law thereon.â€ Rule
  52(a), SCRCP. The rule is directorial in nature so â€œwhere a trial court 
substantially complies with Rule 52(a) and
    adequately states the basis for the result it reaches, the
  appellate court should not vacate the trial courtâ€™s judgment for lack of an
  explicit or specific factual finding.â€ Â Noisette v. Ismail, 304
  S.C. 56, 57, 403 S.E.2d 122, 123-24 (1991).Â   
We
  find substantial compliance by the circuit court in making its findings, and
  evidence to support the finding that Portside did not consent to the
  encroachments.Â  See Kirkland v. Gross, 286 S.C. 193, 198,
  332 S.E.2d 546, 549 (Ct. App. 1985), receded from on other grounds by Boyd
    v. Hyatt, 294 S.C. 360, 364 S.E.2d 478 (Ct. App. 1988) (finding the
  question of acquiescence in an action for adverse possession is generally a
  question of fact).Â  See also Townes Assocs., Ltd. v. City of
    Greenville, 266 S.C. 81, 86, 221 S.E.2d 773, 775 (1976) (stating
  appellate court will not disturb factual findings in an action at law tried
  without a jury unless there is no evidence reasonably supporting the findings).
The
  only evidence Portside offers as support for its argument that it consented is
  the October 24, 2003 letter purporting to revoke its consent.Â  However, there
  is contradictory evidence. Â The 1992 deed from Beachside to Portside referenced
  the Easement granted to South Beach.Â  Furthermore, the minutes of Portsideâ€™s
  annual meetings on November 2, 1991, November 7, 1992, October 16, 1993, and
  October 8, 1994, indicate Portside was aware of potential title problems to the 50' Tract.Â  The minutes reflect that Portside
  specifically questioned what other rights any other entity had in the 50' Tract, raised questions regarding South Beachâ€™s responsibilities concerning the property, and sought legal counsel to address
  these issues.Â  Portside abandoned these inquiries in 1994.Â  The minutes of the
  October 16, 1999 meeting indicate Portside again questioned its title to the
  property.Â  The minutes of the October 19, 2002 meeting reflect a discussion of
  the encroachments and Easement.Â  Portsideâ€™s president admitted the minutes from
  Portsideâ€™s annual meetings reveal no evidence that Portside ever permitted South
  Beach to use or encroach on the property.Â  We find evidence to support the
  conclusion that Portside did not consent to South Beachâ€™s use.Â  Therefore, we affirm
  the trial courtâ€™s finding that the statute of limitations for the recovery of
  real property commenced at the time the Easement began to run in 1987 for the
  encroachments with the Encroachment Letter and in 1992 with the Easement for South Beachâ€™s use of the 50' Tract.Â  
 
II.  Adverse Possession
Portside
  next argues South Beach did not establish the elements of its affirmative
  defense of adverse possession regarding the tennis court encroachments because South Beach never had exclusive possession of Portsideâ€™s property.Â  Additionally, Portside
  argues South Beach did not establish that its adverse possession was for the
  required number of years.Â  We disagree.
In South Carolina, a party may establish adverse possession after possessing adversely to the
  owner for ten years.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-67-210 (2005).Â  To constitute adverse
  possession, the possession must be actual, open, notorious, hostile,
  continuous, and exclusive for the entire statutory period. Mullis v. Winchester, 237 S.C.
  487, 491, 118 S.E.2d 61, 63 (1961).Â  The question of
  adverse possession is one of fact and only becomes one of law when the evidence
  is undisputed and susceptible of but one inference.Â  Lynch
    v. Lynch, 236 S.C. 612, 622, 115 S.E.2d 301, 306 (1960).Â  Therefore,
  our review is limited to determining whether the circuit courtâ€™s findings are
  without evidentiary support or controlled by an error of law.Â  Auto
    Owners Ins. Co. v. Langford, 330 S.C. 578, 581, 500 S.E.2d 496, 498 (Ct. App. 1998). 
 
A.  Exclusive Possession
Portside
  argues South Beach did not establish exclusive possession of Portsideâ€™s
  property because â€œPortside, as the owner of the entire [50' Tract], and South Beach, as an occupier of the [50' Tract], are both in possession of and share the
  [50' Tract] in its entirety.â€Â  Additionally, Portside
  argues â€œthe physical encroachments on the [50' Tract] by South Beach do not prevent the Portside homeowners from their use of
  the [50' Tract] as a whole.â€ Â Â 
â€œThe
  general rule is that where an owner of property and an occupier are both in
  possession, the possession of the legal owner prevails to the exclusion of the
  other.â€ Â Butler v. Lindsey, 293 S.C. 466, 472, 361 S.E.2d 621,
  624 (Ct. App. 1987).Â  The element of
  exclusivity required to acquire title by adverse possession is not met if
  occupancy is shared with the owner. Â Id.  
However,
  the trial court did not find South Beach established adverse possession with
  respect to the entire 50' Tract but merely as to the encroachments.Â  In
  support of this finding, the circuit court noted â€œ[s]ince the encroachments
  actually occupy a portion of the [50' Tract], South Beachâ€™s possession has been actual and exclusive.â€Â  As to the
  tennis court encroachments, we agree South Beachâ€™s use was not shared with
  Portside and therefore, met the element of exclusivity.Â  The encroachments
  occupy the portions of Portsideâ€™s property on which they are built, so that the
  property may not be used for any other purpose.Â  In addition, there is
  testimony in the record stating the tennis courts were fenced in, there was no
  way to access the tennis courts from the 50' Tract, and they have been in the exclusive possession of South Beach since 1988.Â  Accordingly, we find no error in the trial courtâ€™s finding of exclusivity.Â Â Â Â Â  
 
B. The Statutory Period for
  Adverse Possession
Portside
  also argues South Beach did not prove it adversely possessed the property for
  the required number of years.Â  Portside argues that because South Beach maintains the Encroachment Letter gave it the right to encroach, the encroachment
  was not hostile until after Portside revoked consent in 2003.Â  However, the
  Encroachment Letter was signed by Fraser on behalf of Beachside, not Portside,
  and any consent to encroach granted by Beachside is not attributable to
  Portside as Beachside and Portside are separate corporate entities.Â  Thus, even
  if the encroachment is hostile to Beachside, it could be hostile to Portside.Â  See Hunting v. Elders, 359 S.C. 217, 223, 597 S.E.2d 803, 806 (Ct. App. 2004) (finding corporations are separate entities).Â  We find evidence in the
  record to support a finding of hostility as to Portside.  
The
  only evidence in the record is that South Beachâ€™s possession began in 1988 with
  the construction of the tennis courts.Â  The statutory period for adverse
  possession is ten years.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-67-210 (2005).Â  Portside attempt
  to revoke its consent in 2003 and filed this action in 2004.Â  We agree with the
  trial court that South Beach established its adverse possession for the
  statutory period.Â   
III. Trespass
Portside
  finally contends the trial court erred in failing to find South Beachâ€™s use of the easement constitutes a continuing trespass because South Beach did not receive a valid grant of an easement.Â  We disagree.
Trespass
  is an intentional invasion of the plaintiffâ€™s interest in the exclusive use of
  his property.Â  Hedgepath v. Amer. Tel. & Tel. Co., 348 S.C. 340,
  357, 559 S.E.2d 327, 337 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  Based on our finding that Portside
  is barred by the statute of limitations for the recovery of real property as to
  South Beachâ€™s use of the Easement, we find no trespass.  
CONCLUSION
For the foregoing
  reasons, the order of the circuit court is
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, SHORT, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.

PER CURIAM:Â  The
  State appeals the circuit courtâ€™s order finding additional conditions of

title: In the Matter of Swinney
text:
THIS OPINION
  HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE, IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN
  ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				In the Matter
      of the Care and Treatment of Derrick D. Swinney, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Darlington County
Â J. Michael Baxley, Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-156
Submitted March 3, 2008 â€“ Filed March 12,
  2008Â Â  
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Appellate Defender LaNelle C. Durant, South Carolina Commission,
  of Columbia, for Appellant.
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Attorney General Deborah R. J. Shupe, Assistant
  Attorney General Brandy A. Duncan, all of Columbia; for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM: Derrick D. Swinney appeals his commitment
  to the South Carolina Department of Mental Health (the Department) as a
  sexually violent predator. Â We affirm.[1]
FACTUAL /
  PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
On November 29, 1999, Swinney pled guilty
  to criminal sexual conduct.Â  He was sentenced to imprisonment for a period of
  five years.Â   
Prior
  to Swinneyâ€™s scheduled release from prison, his case was referred to the
  sexually violent predator multi-disciplinary team.[2] Â The multi-disciplinary team
  reviewed Swinneyâ€™s case, determined he satisfied the definition of a sexually
  violent predator as provided in the Sexually Violent Predator Act (the Act),[3] and forwarded the case to the
  prosecutorâ€™s review committee.[4] Â The prosecutorâ€™s review committee reviewed the case and agreed there
  was probable cause to believe Swinney satisfied the criteria for commitment
  under the Act.[5]Â 
  The State subsequently filed a petition in circuit court to commit Swinney to
  the Department for care and treatment as a sexually violent predator.[6] Â After a hearing,[7] the trial court held probable cause
  existed to find Swinney met the criteria for commitment and ordered a mental
  health evaluation by Dr. Pamela Crawford. Â Dr. Crawford evaluated
  Swinney and concluded he did not meet the criteria for commitment under the
  Act.Â  The trial court, therefore, dismissed the Stateâ€™s petition without
  prejudice.Â   
Swinney
  was released to community supervision on December January 29, 2004.Â  Subsequent
  to his release, Swinneyâ€™s community supervision was revoked because he failed
  to attend sex offender counseling and failed to comply with a home detention
  order. Â In addition, in May 2005, Swinney was charged with criminal
  sexual conduct, assault and battery of a high and aggravated nature, and
  kidnapping.Â   
On September
  6, 2005, relying in part on events occurring after Swinneyâ€™s release from
  prison, the State filed its second petition to have Swinney confined to the
  Department. Â The trial court found probable cause existed to find
  Swinney was a sexually violent predator.Â  Again, the trial court ordered that the
  Department conduct a mental health evaluation of Swinney.Â  Dr. Donna Schwartz-Watts
  evaluated Swinney and concluded he met the criteria for civil commitment.Â 
 
The
  matter came to trial on August 2, 2006.Â  Prior to the start of the trial, Swinney moved to dismiss the case on the ground it was barred by the doctrine
  of res judicata.Â  Swinney relied on the first probable cause hearing and
  evaluation and the fact that he had no new convictions. Â The trial court
  denied Swinneyâ€™s motion, finding the prior predator case was dismissed without
  prejudice and the events subsequent to Swinneyâ€™s release constituted a
  substantial change in circumstances that warranted the new action.Â  Following
  the trial courtâ€™s ruling, the case proceeded to a jury trial.Â   
Dr. Schwartz-Watts testified for the State. Â She opined
  Swinney suffers from â€œsexual disorder not other specifiedâ€ that makes him
  likely to sexually assault women with whom he has a sexual relationship.Â  Â Dr.
  Schwartz-Watts stated it was her medical opinion that Swinney is predisposed to
  commit future acts of sexual violence. Â She stated Swinneyâ€™s history of
  substance abuse, history of sexual violence, resistance to seek treatment, refusal
  to admit his offending behavior, and violation of his community supervision
  influenced her opinion. She ultimately concluded Swinney met the requirements
  to be considered a sexually violent predator.  
The jury found beyond a reasonable doubt Swinney
  was a sexually violent predator.Â  The trial court committed Swinney to the
  Department for long-term treatment.Â  Swinney appeals.
LAW / ANALYSIS
I.  Res
  Judicata
Swinney argues the trial court erred in denying his motion to
  dismiss because the Stateâ€™s second petition was barred by res judicata.  
Under
  the doctrine of res judicata, a final judgment on the merits in a prior action
  will bar the parties from initiating a second action based on the same issues.[8]Â  Res
  judicata requires: (1) the judgment to be final, valid, and on the merits; (2)
  the parties in the subsequent action to be identical to those in the first; and
  (3) the second action to involve matter properly included in the first action.[9] Â 
Swinney contends
  the initial probable cause hearing and dismissal without prejudice constituted
  a final judgment on the merits.Â  Â We disagree.
The Act provides
  that the purpose of a probable cause hearing is to determine â€œwhether probable
  cause exists to believe the person is a sexually violent predator.â€[10]Â 
  The Act further provides if the court determines probable cause exists, â€œthe
  court shall conduct a trial to determine whether the person is a sexually
  violent predator.â€[11] Â A probable cause hearing, therefore, does not constitute a final judgment on
  the merits.Â  Instead, a probable cause hearing is simply a preliminary hearing
  for the purpose of determining whether probable cause exists to set the matter
  for trial on the merits.
Furthermore,
  a dismissal without prejudice does not constitute a final adjudication on the
  merits. [12]Â   
Here,
  the trial court dismissed the Stateâ€™s initial petition without prejudice after
  a probable cause hearing and a mental health evaluation.Â  The initial action,
  therefore, did not constitute a final judgment on the merits.Â  Accordingly, res
  judicata did not bar the Stateâ€™s second petition or subsequent trial.
II.  Sexually Violent
  Predator Act
Swinney also argues the trial court erred in allowing the State to
  proceed with its case because the State did not meet the required elements as
  outlined in the Act.Â   
A sexually violent predator is defined in the Act as â€œa person who
  (a) has been convicted of a sexually violent offense; and (b) suffers from a
  mental abnormality or personality disorder that makes the person likely to
  engage in acts of sexual violence if not confined in a secure facility for
  long-term control, care, and treatment.â€[13]Â 
  â€œMental abnormalityâ€ is defined as â€œa mental condition affecting a personâ€™s
  emotional or volitional capacity that predisposes the person to commit sexually
  violent offenses.â€[14]Â 
  The phrase â€œlikely to engage in acts of sexual violenceâ€ is defined as a
  â€œpropensity to commit acts of sexual violence . . . of such a degree as to pose
  a menace to the health and safety of others.â€[15]Â   
Here, Swinney
  pled guilty to criminal sexual conduct, a sexually violent offense under the
  Act.[16]Â  Also, the record shows evidence
  Swinney suffers from a mental abnormality or personality disorder, making him
  likely to engage in additional acts of sexual violence. Â As set forth above,
  Dr. Schwartz-Watts testified Swinney suffers from â€œsexual disorder not other specified,â€ which predisposes him to commit future
  acts of sexual violence. Â Dr. Schwartz-Watts further opined Swinney met the
  criteria for commitment under the SVP Act. Accordingly, Swinneyâ€™s civil
  commitment is
AFFIRMED.  
HEARN, C.J., PIEPER, JJ., and GOOLSBY,
  A.J., concur.

[1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant
  to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-48-40(A)(1)
  (Supp. 2006).
[3]  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-48-10 et seq. (Supp. 2006).
[4]  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-48-50 (Supp.
  2006).
[5]  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-48-60 (Supp.
  2006).
[6]  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-48-70 (Supp.
  2006).  
[7]  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-48-70 (Supp.
  2006).
[8]  Garris v. S.C. Reinsurance Facility, 333 S.C. 432, 449, 511 S.E.2d 48, 57
  (1999).Â   
[9]  Town of Sullivanâ€™s Island v. Felger, 318 S.C.
  340, 344, 457 S.E.2d 626, 628 (Ct. App. 1995).
[10]  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-48-80(B)(3) (Supp. 2006).
[11]  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-48-90 (Supp. 2006).
 
[12] Â See McEachern v. Black, 329 S.C.
  642, 651, 496 S.E.2d 659, 663 (Ct. App. 1998); see alsoÂ  Collins
    v. Sigmon, 299 S.C. 464, 467, 385 S.E.2d 835, 837 (1989) (stating when an
  action is dismissed without prejudice, a plaintiff can reassert the same causes
  of action by curing defects that led to the dismissal).
[13]Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-48-30(1)
  (Supp. 2006).Â  Â 
[14] Â S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  44-48-30(3).Â  Â 
[15]Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-48-30(9).
[16]Â  See SC. Code Ann. Â§ 44-48-30 (2)(b).Â

title: Burr v. Burr
text:
THIS OPINION
  HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE, IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN
  ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Deanna L. Burr, Respondent,
				v.
				Wayne Burr, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Lexington County
Â Richard W. Chewning, III, Family Court
  Judge
Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2008-UP-157
Submitted March 3, 2008 â€“ Filed March 12,
  2008Â  
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				G. RobinÂ  Alley, of Columbia, for Appellant.
				Stevens Bultman Elliott, of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  Deeana
  Burr (Wife) filed for divorce from Wayne Burr (Husband).Â  The family court
  issued an order granting the divorce, apportioning marital property and
  awarding Wife $3,500 in attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Husband
  and Wife were married for approximately one year when they separated in 2004.Â 
  Wife subsequently filed an action for divorce on the grounds of physical
  cruelty. Â In her Complaint, Wife alleged the partiesâ€™ equitably divided all
  marital property at the time of separation, with the exception of a Harley
  Davidson motorcycle.Â  Wife sought a divorce, approval of the division of the
  property, alimony, and attorneyâ€™s fees.Â   
The
  family court held a final hearing on March 14, 2006.Â  Wife testified Husband
  took several items of personal property from the marital home after the
  partiesâ€™ separation. Â Wife offered evidence as to the value of the property.Â 
  Wife also submitted an Affidavit of Attorneyâ€™s Fees.Â  Husband did not appear at
  the hearing or offer any testimony.Â   
The
  family court issued a decree of divorce on April 13, 2006. Â In the decree, the
  family court ordered Husband to return the personal property he removed from
  the marital home and valued the personal property at $35,745.Â  The decree further
  provided if Husband did not return the personal property within ten days he
  must pay $300 per month to Wife until he returned the property or paid for the
  property in full. Â In addition, the family court ordered Husband to pay
  Wife $3,500 in attorneyâ€™s fees.Â   
Husband
  filed a motion to reconsider the family courtâ€™s order pursuant to Rule 59(e),
  SCRCP, asking the family court to decrease the value of the personal property
  and extend the time limit for him to return the personal property. Â In
  addition, Husband argued the family courtâ€™s award of attorneyâ€™s fees was
  excessive in nature.Â  Â The family court denied the motion, and this
  appeal followed.  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
An
  appellate court, in its review of an appeal from family court, has jurisdiction
  to find facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the
  evidence.Â  Scott v. Scott, 354 S.C. 118, 124, 579 S.E.2d 620, 623 (2003).Â  â€œThis,
  however, does not require this Court to disregard the findings of the family
  court.Â  Neither is this Court required to ignore the fact that the family court
  judge, who saw and heard the witnesses, was in a better position to evaluate
  their testimony.â€Â  Murdock v. Murdock, 338 S.C. 322, 328, 526 S.E.2d 241, 245 (Ct. App. 1999).
LAW
  / ANALYSIS
I.  Return of Personal
  Property
Husband argues the
  family court lacked authority to order him to return the personal property
  because the property was non-marital.Â  We disagree.
The family court has
  the power to apportion marital property.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-472
  (Supp. 2007). Â Here, the family court did not find the personal property was
  non-marital, but treated the property as though it was marital.Â  Furthermore, the
  husband failed to raise this issue at trial or in his Rule 59(e), SCRCP,
  motion. Â This issue, therefore, is not preserved for review. Â See Washington v. Washington, 308 S.C. 549,
  551, 419 S.E.2d 779, 781 (1992) (holding when an appellant neither raises an
  issue at trial nor through a Rule 59(e), SCRCP, motion, the issue is not preserved for appellate review).
II.  Valuation
  of Personal Property
Husband argues the
  family courtâ€™s valuation of the personal property was in error.Â  We disagree.
The family court is
  charged with the duty of identifying real and personal
  marital property and determining the propertyâ€™s fair market value.Â  Abercrombie
    v. Abercrombie,  372 S.C. 643, 647, 643 S.E.2d 697, 699 (Ct. App.
  2007). Â â€œIn the absence of contrary evidence, the court should accept
  the value the parties assign to a marital asset.â€ Â Id. Moreover, a
  property owner is competent to offer testimony as to the value of his property.
  Â Cooper v. Cooper, 289 S.C. 377, 379, 346 S.E.2d 326, 327 (Ct. App.
  1986). Â â€œA family court may accept the valuation of one party over another, and
  the courtâ€™s valuation of marital property will be affirmed if it is within the
  range of evidence presented.â€ Â Abercrombie,  372 S.C. at 647, 643
  S.E.2d at 699. 
Here, Wife
  specifically testified and submitted an exhibit as to the value of the personal
  property.Â  The family courtâ€™s valuation approximates the value of the property
  Wife presented.Â  Accordingly, the family court did not err in valuing the
  personal property.Â   
II.  Attorneyâ€™s Fees
Husband argues the
  family court erred in awarding Wife $3,500 in attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Specifically,
  Husband argues the family court failed to set forth the factors the court
  considered in awarding attorneyâ€™s fees.Â   
Rule
  26(a) of the South Carolina Rules of Family Court requires the family court to
  â€œset forth the specific findings of fact and conclusions of law to support the
  courtâ€™s decision.â€ Â Specifically, the family court should consider: (1) the
  nature, extent, and difficulty of the services rendered; (2) the time
  necessarily devoted to the case; (3) counselâ€™s professional standing; (4) the
  contingency of compensation; (5) the beneficial results obtained; and (6) the
  customary legal fees for similar services. Â Glasscock v. Glasscock, 304
  S.C. 158, 161, 403 S.E.2d 313, 315 (1991).Â Â  When the family court fails to set
  forth findings relating to the award of attorneyâ€™s fees, however, the appellate
  court may remand the matter or, where the record is sufficient, make its own
  findings of fact in accordance with the preponderance of the evidence. Griffith v. Griffith, 332 S.C. 630, 646-47, 506 S.E.2d 526, 535 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  The family courtâ€™s award of attorneyâ€™s fees will not be
  overturned absent an abuse of discretion. Â Stevenson v. Stevenson, 295 S.C. 412, 415, 368 S.E.2d 901, 903 (1988).Â Â  
 
Here,
  the record is sufficient for this Court to make the required findings of fact concerning
  the award of attorneyâ€™s fees. Specifically, the record contains Wifeâ€™s attorney
  fee affidavit.Â  See Bowers v. Bowers, 349 S.C. 85, 98-99,
  561 S.E.2d 610, 617-18 (Ct. App. 2002) (holding the record was sufficient
  for the appellate court to make sufficient findings of fact where the record
  contained the wifeâ€™s attorney fee affidavit).Â  Accordingly, we find no abuse of
  discretion in the award.Â   
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., PIEPER, JJ., and GOOLSBY,
  A.J., concur.

title: Brown v. Brown
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT
  BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Robert Brown, Respondent,
				v.
				Mae Ola Brown, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Orangeburg County
Â Dale Moore Gable, Family Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-165
Submitted March 3, 2008 â€“ Filed March 12,
  2008
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Lawrence Keitt, of Orangeburg, for Appellant.
				W. D. Rhoad, of Bamberg, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  In
  this domestic action, Mae Ola Brown (Wife) appeals the family courtâ€™s
  order requiring Robert Brown (Husband) to pay alimony retroactive to April 1,
  2006.Â  Wife argues Husband owes her alimony dating back to a temporary divorce hearing on January 15, 2004.Â  Additionally, Wife argues the family court failed to set forth specific findings of
  fact and conclusions of law in deciding not to award retroactive alimony as
  required under Rule 26(a) of the South Carolina Rules of Family Court.Â  We affirm.[1]Â   
FACTS
Husband and Wife were married on November 7, 1970.Â  After thirty
  two years of marriage, the couple separated in September of 2003.Â  Husband and
  Wife had two children born out of the marriage who are now emancipated.Â  During
  the marriage, Husband worked as a plumber and as of the date of the divorce
  hearing, Husband had been working for himself for ten years.Â  Since 1979, Wife
  has worked for Farmers and Merchants Bank in Holly Hill.Â  Wife and Husband testified
  Husband paid their bills during the marriage, including the house payment until
  he left their marital home.Â  Since Husband left the marriage, Wife testified
  she has supported herself and borrowed money from family members.Â   
On September 3, 2003, Husband filed for divorce on the basis of
  adultery and sought an equitable division of marital property.Â  Wife answered
  and counterclaimed seeking permanent and temporary alimony.Â  Further, she
  denied Husbandâ€™s adultery allegations.Â  Wife alleged adulterous conduct by
  Husband and also sought an equitable division of the marital estate and alimony.Â 
  In a temporary order dated January 26, 2004, the family court did not rule on
  whether to award temporary alimony but held this ruling in abeyance pending a
  final hearing. Â 
In its final decree of divorce on April 17, 2006, the family court
  found Wife proved by clear and convincing evidence that Husband committed
  adultery and granted her a divorce on this ground.Â  The family court found Husband
  failed to prove his allegations of Wifeâ€™s adultery and denied granting him a
  divorce on the basis of Wifeâ€™s adultery or on the ground of one year continuous
  separation.Â  Additionally, the family court ordered Husband to pay $600 per
  month in alimony to Wife, retroactive to April 1, 2006.Â  The family court also
  granted Wife exclusive possession of the marital home and ordered Husband to
  pay $7,000 in attorneyâ€™s fees and costs.Â  This appeal follows.  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
On
  appeal from a family court order, this court has authority to correct errors of
  law and find facts in accordance with our own view of the preponderance of the
  evidence.Â  E.D.M. v. T.A.M., 307 S.C. 471, 473, 415 S.E.2d 812, 814
  (1992).Â  However, â€œ[q]uestions concerning alimony rest with the sound
  discretion of the [family] court, whose conclusions will not be disturbed
  absent a showing of abuse of discretion.â€Â  Kelley v. Kelley, 324 S.C.
  481, 485, 477 S.E.2d 727, 729 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  The family
  court abuses its discretion when factual findings are without evidentiary
  support or a ruling is based upon an error of law. Â Smith v. Doe, 366
  S.C. 469, 474, 623 S.E.2d 370, 372 (2005).
DISCUSSION
I. Denial of retroactive
  alimony 
Wife argues the
  family court abused its discretion in denying her retroactive alimony to the
  date of the temporary hearing on January 15, 2004.Â  We disagree.  
â€œThe
  decision to order retroactive support rests within the sound discretion of the
  family court and should not be reversed absent an abuse of discretion of the
  family court.â€ Â Thornton v. Thornton, 328 S.C. 96, 115, 492
  S.E.2d 86, 96 (1997).Â  â€œAlimony is a substitute for the support which is
  normally incident to the marital relationship.â€ Â Johnson v. Johnson, 296
  S.C. 289, 300, 372 S.E.2d 107, 113 (Ct. App. 1988) Â Factors to be
  considered in making an alimony award include: (1) duration of the marriage;
  (2) physical and emotional health of the
  parties; (3) educational background of the parties; (4) employment history and
  earning potential of the parties; (5) standard of living established during the
  marriage; (6) current and reasonably anticipated earnings of the parties; (7)
  current and reasonably anticipated expenses and needs of the parties; (8)
  marital and nonmarital properties of the parties; (9) custody of children; (10)
  marital misconduct or fault; (11) tax consequences; and (12) prior support
  obligations; as well as other factors the court considers relevant. S.C. Code
  Ann. Â§ 20-3-130(C) (Supp. 2007).Â  Furthermore, when determining an alimony
  award, courts may consider the amount received in equitable distribution.Â  Josey
    v. Josey, 291 S.C. 26, 33, 351 S.E.2d 891, 895-96 (Ct. App. 1986).Â  
 
On
  January 15, 2004, Wife requested alimony during the temporary hearing.Â  The
  family court denied her request based on Husbandâ€™s allegations of adultery, and
  deferred ruling on whether to award retroactive alimony until the final
  hearing.Â  Wife contends two years and three months lapsed between the initial
  hearing and the final hearing, and during that time she borrowed money from her
  family to help support herself.Â   
In
  its temporary order, the family court awarded Wife temporary use and possession
  of the marital home and its contents.Â  Thereafter, in its final decree, the
  family court found â€œthe parties enjoyed a reasonable standard of livingâ€ during
  their marriage.Â  In addition to equitably dividing the marital estate, the
  family court noted none of the marital property had any debt associated with it
  and granted Wife ownership of the marital home.Â  Furthermore, the family court
  found Wife had inherited an interest in three acres of land with her brothers
  from her motherâ€™s estate which was nonmarital property valued at $19,000.Â  The
  family court also awarded Wife $7,000 in attorneyâ€™s fees and costs.
In
  its final ruling, the family court found Wife had a monthly income of $1,375.Â 
  Wife testified she and Husband filed separate tax returns for the past thirteen
  years, and in recent years Wife filed as a single, unmarried person.Â  In
  addition, Wife admitted she and Husband had lived â€œseparate livesâ€ for nearly
  ten years prior to their divorce.Â  Though Wife alleged she borrowed money from
  her family to make ends meet after Husband moved out, nothing in the record
  indicates the total amount loaned or the amount Wife needed to repay.Â  Moreover,
  in regards to Wifeâ€™s monthly expenses at the time the couple separated, Wife
  testified the coupleâ€™s marital home was paid off, but she still incurred
  monthly expenses from electric and insurance bills, laundry and dry cleaning,
  and life and health insurance.[2]Â 
  Specifically, Wife testified her monthly bills included $70 in home insurance
  and between $300 and $350 in utility bills.Â  However, we note Wifeâ€™s financial
  declarations, though discussed in testimony, were not included as part of the
  record on appeal.Â  Wife, as appellant, has the burden of presenting a
  sufficient record to allow review. See, e.g., Helms Realty, Inc. v.
    Gibson-Wall Co., 363 S.C. 334, 339, 611 S.E.2d 485, 447-48 (2005); Harkins
      v. Greenville County, 340 S.C. 606, 616, 533 S.E.2d 886, 891 (2000).Â  
 
We
  find the family court properly considered the factors set forth in section
  20-3-130(C) in deciding to award alimony and determining when payments would
  begin.Â  Therefore, based on the family courtâ€™s consideration of the coupleâ€™s standard
  of living established during the marriage; each partiesâ€™ current and reasonably
  anticipated earnings; marital and nonmarital properties of the parties; and the
  amount each party received in the equitable distribution of marital property,
  we find the family court did not abuse its discretion in denying Wife
  retroactive alimony.Â  Additionally, we note the family court based its alimony
  award â€œupon the length of the marriage, the relative income of the parties and
  those other factors necessary to be considered in awarding alimony . . . .â€Â  Accordingly,
  we affirm the family courtâ€™s order
  requiring Husband pay $600 per month in alimony to Wife, retroactive only to
  April 1, 2006.Â   
II.Â  Rule 26(a) of the South Carolina Rules of Family Court
Wife argues the family
  court failed to set forth specific findings of facts and conclusions of law in
  deciding not to award retroactive alimony as required under Rule 26(a), SCRFC.Â 
  Instead, Wife argues the family court summarily stated it declined to award
  retroactive alimony.Â  We disagree.Â   
Rule 26(a), SCRFC,
  provides: â€œAn order or judgment pursuant to an adjudication in a domestic
  relations case shall set forth the specific findings of fact and conclusions of
  law to support the courtâ€™s decision.â€Â  However, we note not every violation of
  Rule 26(a) requires reversal. Â See,
    e.g., Holcombe v. Hardee, 304
  S.C. 522, 524, 405 S.E.2d 821, 822 (1991); Bowers v. Bowers, 349 S.C.
  85, 98-99, 561 S.E.2d 610, 617 (Ct. App. 2002); Griffith v. Griffith,
  332 S.C. 630, 646-47, 506 S.E.2d 526, 535 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  â€œ[W]hen an order
  from the family court is issued in violation of Rule 26(a), SCRFC, the
  appellate court â€˜may remand the matter to the trial court or, where the record
  is sufficient, make its own findings of fact in accordance with the
  preponderance of the evidence.â€™â€ Griffith, 332 S.C. at 646-47, 506 S.E.2d
  at 535 (quoting Holcombe v. Hardee, 304 S.C. at 524, 405 S.E.2d at 822).
  Â In the case sub judice, we find the record on appeal sufficient
  for this court to make its own findings.  
In
  asserting the family court erred by failing to make the specific findings of
  fact as required by Rule 26(a), Wife references the family courtâ€™s order
  rendered in response to her notice of motion and motion for reconsideration. Â Â The
  order denying Wifeâ€™s motion to reconsider references â€œmatters appearing of
  record in the file . . . .â€Â  Therefore, we find it unnecessary for this order
  to set forth factual findings and conclusions of law in light of the original
  divorce decreeâ€™s specific findings of fact and conclusions of law to support
  its decision.Â  Furthermore, as aforementioned, we found the family court, in
  the final divorce decree, properly considered the factors set forth in section
  20-3-130(C) in its final divorce decree decision of whether to award alimony
  and when payments would begin.Â  For that reason, the family court satisfied
  Rule 26(a), SCRFC, and the divorce decree was part of the record on appeal. Therefore,
  we find sufficient facts in the record support the family courtâ€™s order denying
  Wife retroactive alimony.Â  Accordingly, we affirm the family courtâ€™s order in
  response to Wifeâ€™s motion for reconsideration.Â   
CONCLUSION
We find the
  family court properly considered the alimony factors set forth by statute and
  case law in setting an alimony award and in determining when such payments
  should begin.Â  Therefore we find the family court did not abuse its discretion
  in denying Wife retroactive alimony to the date of the temporary hearing.Â 
  Additionally, we believe the family court satisfied Rule 26(a), SCRFC in its
  final decree of divorce, which was part of the record on appeal.Â  Accordingly,
  the order of the family court is  
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, SHORT and THOMAS, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] Wife testified she took out a loan from the bank to
  â€œhelp pay my bills,â€ but indicated the loan had only one year remaining before
  she paid it off.Â

title: Professional Wiring Installers v. Sims
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO
  PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Professional
      Wiring Installers, Inc., Randy Cochran and Denise Cochran, Respondents,
				v.
				Thomas Sims,
      III, and Communication Components, Inc., Defendants,
				of whom Thomas
      Sims, III is the Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Richland County
Â JosephÂ  M. Strickland, Master In Equity
Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-173
Submitted March 3, 2008 â€“ Filed March 12,
  2008Â Â Â  
REVERSED and REMANDED


	
		
			
				Tucker S. Player, Esquire; Debra C. Galloway, of Columbia, for
  Appellant.
				S. Jahue Moore, of W. Columbia, for Respondents.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â 
  Thomas Sims, III alleges the Master in Equity committed error in granting the Respondents
  (PWI) a preliminary injunction, which enjoined him from violating the terms of
  a non-compete agreement between him and PWI and in failing to require PWI to
  post a bond pursuant to Rule 65, SCRCP. Â We reverse and remand.[1]  
FACTS
PWI is in
  the communications business, and Sims worked for them.Â  In July of 2005, PWI
  presented a non-compete agreement to Sims, which Sims signed.Â  The agreement
  provided: â€œWhile I am employed by the Company, and for 3 yearsâ€¦ afterward, I
  will not compete with the business of the Company . . ., within a radius of 600
  miles from the present location of the Company.â€Â  Sims continued to work for
  PWI until March 10, 2006.Â  After his employment with PWI ended, he began
  working for Computer Components, Inc. (CCI), one of PWIâ€™s largest customers.Â 
  Sims performed similar services for CCI as those he previously provided CCI
  while employed by PWI.Â  As a result of Sims activities, PWI allegedly no longer
  received business from CCI.
On
  August 7, 2006, PWI and its owners, Randy and Denise Cochran, filed suit against
  Sims and CCI seeking monetary damages and both preliminary and permanent
  injunctive relief to enforce the terms of the agreement not to compete.Â  By
  order signed December 11, 2006, the Master granted a preliminary injunction
  against Sims, enjoining him â€œfrom violating the employee non-compete agreement
  to the extent that he shall not solicit or attempt to solicit any business or
  trade from [PWIâ€™s] customers or clients until further Order of this Court.â€ Â The
  Master also refused to set a bond as required by Rule 65(c), SCRCP.Â  This
  appeal follows. Â Â Â 
STANDARD OF
  REVIEW
â€œThe granting of temporary injunctive relief is within
  the sound discretion of the trial court and will
  not be overturned absent an abuse of that discretion.â€ City of Columbia v. Pic-A-Flick Video, Inc., 340 S.C. 278, 282, 531 S.E.2d 518, 520-21 (2000).
  â€œAn abuse of discretion occurs when a trial courtâ€™s decision is unsupported by
  the evidence or controlled by an error of law.â€ County of Richland v. Simpkins, 348 S.C. 664, 668, 560 S.E.2d 902, 904 (Ct. App. 2002).
LAW/ANALYSIS
The
  Supreme Court of South Carolina recently addressed injunctive relief:

	The power of
  the court to grant an injunction is in equity. The court will reserve its
  equitable powers for situations when there is no adequate remedy at law. The
  party seeking an injunction has the burden of demonstrating facts and
  circumstances warranting an injunction. The remedy of an injunction is a
  drastic one and ought to be applied with caution. In deciding whether to grant
  an injunction, the court must balance the benefit of an injunction to the
  plaintiff against the inconvenience and damage to the defendant, and grant an
  injunction which seems most consistent with justice and equity under the
  circumstances of the case. 
	For a preliminary injunction to be granted, the plaintiff must establish
  that (1) it would suffer irreparable harm if the injunction is not granted; (2)
  the party seeking injunction will likely succeed in the litigation; and (3)
  there is an inadequate remedy at law. 


    Strategic Resources Co. v. BCS Life Ins. Co., 367 S.C. 540, 544, 627
  S.E.2d 687, 689 (2006) (internal citations omitted).Â  This court has also
  addressed injunctive relief, noting:  

	[i]t is well settled that, in determining whether a
  temporary injunction should issue, the merits of the case are not to be
  considered, except in so far as they may enable the court to determine whether
  a prima facie showing has been made. When a prima facie showing has been made
  entitling plaintiff to injunctive relief, a temporary injunction will be
  granted without regard to the ultimate termination of the case on the merits.


    MailSource, LLC v. M.A. Bailey & Assocs., 356 S.C. 363, 368, 588
  S.E.2d 635, 638 (Ct. App. 2003) (internal citations omitted).
We are aware that in determining whether a temporary
  injunction should be granted, the merits of the case should not be considered beyond
  determining whether a prima facie showing has been made.Â  However, as noted by
  the Supreme Court in Strategic Resources, the party seeking injunctive
  relief must establish it will likely succeed on the merits.Â  Accordingly, we
  review whether PWI has made a prima facie showing of the likelihood of succeeding
  on the merits.Â  Following our review, we have concluded that PWI failed to make
  this showing. Â Â Â This
  Court addressed the enforceability of covenants not to compete in Faces
    Boutique, Ltd. v. Gibbs, where we stated:

	Covenants
  not to compete contained in employment contracts are generally disfavored and
  will be strictly construed against the employer. Â A restriction against competition must be narrowly drawn to
  protect the legitimate interests of the employer. Â A covenant not to compete
  will be upheld only if it is:
	(1) necessary for the protection of the legitimate
  interest of the employer;
	(2)
  reasonably limited in its operation with respect to time and place;
	(3) not
  unduly harsh and oppressive in curtailing the legitimate efforts of the
  employee to earn a livelihood;
	(4)
  reasonable from the standpoint of sound public policy; and
	(5)
  supported by valuable consideration.
	Moreover, each case concerned
  with the enforceability of covenants not to compete contained in employment contracts
  must be decided on its own facts. If a covenant not to compete is defective in
  one of the above referenced areas, the covenant is totally defective and cannot
  be saved.

318 S.C. 39, 41-42, 455 S.E.2d 707, 708-09 (Ct.
  App. 1995) (internal citations omitted).
In
  the case sub judice, we are troubled by the broad geographical scope and effective
  time period of the non-compete agreement.Â  The terms of the agreement restrict
  Simsâ€™ business activities within a 600 mile radius of Lexington, South Carolina, for three years following the completion of his employment with PWI.Â  The
  agreement, if enforceable, would bar Simsâ€™ business activities in thirteen
  states fully and in parts of nine other states.Â  While the agreement bars Sims
  activities in at least part of twenty-two states, PWI only conducted business
  in five states.Â  For these reasons, we are doubtful of the enforceability of
  this agreement.Â  See Â Poole v. Incentives Unlimited, Inc., 345 S.C. 378, 548 S.E.2d 207 (2001) (holding that a covenant not to compete is
  enforceable if it is not detrimental to the public interest, is reasonably limited as to time and territory, and is supported by valuable
  consideration).Â   
To be entitled to injunctive relief, PWI must establish it would
  suffer irreparable harm without such relief.Â  We find no such showing.Â  Generally,
  pure economic loss is not sufficient to satisfy the requirement of showing an
  irreparable harm where an adequate remedy is available at law.Â  See MailSource, LLC,
  356 S.C. at 370, 588 S.E.2d at 639 (stating the â€œgeneral rule is that an
  injunction should be granted only where some irreparable injury is threatened
  for which there is no adequate remedy at lawâ€).Â  However, this Court has recognized an irreparable harm
  where economic loss threatens the plaintiffâ€™s business as a whole. See Peek v. Spartanburg Regional Healthcare System, 367 S.C. 450, 455-56, 626 S.E.2d 34,
  37 (Ct. App. 2005) (holding â€œthe complete loss of a professional practice
  can be an irreparable harmâ€).Â   
PWI
  failed to allege any irreparable harm arising from Simsâ€™ business activities.Â  Randy Cochran, one of PWIâ€™s owners and its president, testified PWI
  no longer conducted business with CCI, one of its largest customers, as a
  result of Simsâ€™ activities.Â  Cochran alleged the lost business represented
  approximately thirty percent of PWIâ€™s overall business.Â  However, PWI failed to
  allege or present any evidence that Simsâ€™ activities could cause the complete
  loss of business for PWI.Â   
The
  only allegation of irreparable harm in this case is contained in the
  non-compete agreement itself.Â  The agreement states:  

	3.Â 
  Injunctive Relief. Â I acknowledge and
  agree that in the event of a violation or threatened violation of any
  provisions of this agreement, the Company will sustain irreparable harm and
  will have the full right to seek injunctive relief, in addition to any other
  legal remedy available, without the requirement of posting bond.

We are not satisfied that language
  in the challenged agreement alone constitutes a sufficient showing of
  irreparable harm, particularly when considering the overly broad scope of the
  agreement. Â See Faces Boutique, Ltd. 318 S.C. at 42, 455 S.E.2d
  at 709 (holding: â€œIf a covenant not to compete is defective in one . . . area[],
  the covenant is totally defective and cannot be saved.â€).Â  Accordingly, we find
  the Master erred in finding PWI had satisfied the requirement of showing
  irreparable harm, and therefore, the preliminary injunction should not have
  been granted.  
Sims also claims the Master committed error in failing to require
  PWI to pay a bond pursuant to Rule 65(c), SCRCP.Â  We agree.Â   

	Rule 65(c), SCRCP, provides:
	
		no restraining order or temporary
  injunction shall issue except upon the giving of security by the applicant, in
  such sum as the court deems proper, for the payment of such costs and damages
  as may be incurred or suffered by any party who is found to have been
  wrongfully enjoined or restrained.
	

PWI argues the â€œdeems properâ€
  language of Rule 65, SCRCP, provides the Master with discretion to set no bond
  at all.Â  PWI also argues the language of the non-compete argument, which states
  PWI has a right to seek injunctive relief â€œwithout the requirement of posting
  bond,â€ justifies the Masterâ€™s refusal to set bond.Â  We are not persuaded by
  either argument.Â Â Â   
In Atwood Agency
  v. Black, 374 SC 68, 646 S.E.2d 882, (2007), the Supreme Court of
  South Carolina recently addressed the issue of the discretion provided to trial
  courts by Rule 65, SCRCP.Â  Atwood Agency is a vacation rental business on Edisto Island, South Carolina.Â  Elaine Shaw was employed by Atwood Agency for fifteen
  years.Â  When Shawâ€™s employment with Atwood Agency ended, she went to work for
  another vacation rental business, Edisto Sales and Rental Realty, Inc.Â  Atwood Agency
  filed suit against Shaw and her new employer.Â  The circuit court granted Atwood
  Agency a temporary injunction, restraining Shaw and her employer from
  contacting or contracting with Atwoodâ€™s clients.Â  The court set bond in the
  amount of $250.Â   
Shaw
  and her employer challenged the underlying temporary injunction and argued the
  amount of bond was inadequate. Â The Supreme Court reversed and remanded, explaining:
  â€œ[t]he circuit courtâ€™s order requiring only a nominal security bond does not
  satisfy Rule 65(c) because it erroneously assumes the injunction is proper
  instead of providing an amount sufficient to protect appellants in the event
  the injunction is ultimately deemed improper.â€Â  374 SC 68, 78, 646 S.E.2d 882,
  884. Â The Supreme Court ruled Shaw and her employer had been improperly
  enjoined and remanded the matter back â€œto the circuit court to award the
  appropriate amount of costs and damages incurred as a result of the temporary
  injunction.â€ Id.  
We find that if
  setting nominal bond is not within the discretion of the trial court, setting
  no bond is likewise beyond the trial courtâ€™s discretion.Â  Furthermore, to allow
  the language of the non-compete argument to control whether a bond is required
  would impose the same flawed reasoning upon Sims as that rejected in Atwood:
  to â€œerroneously assume[] the injunction is proper instead of providing an
  amount sufficient to protect appellants in the event the injunction is
  ultimately deemed improper.â€Â  Id.  
CONCLUSION
For the reasons
  stated above, we reverse the Masterâ€™s grant of a preliminary injunction and
  remand the matter back to the Master for further proceedings to determine if
  Sims has incurred any cost or suffered any damages as a result of the improper
  injunction and to award appropriate relief.Â  Accordingly, the order of the
  Master is
REVERSED and
  REMANDED.
ANDERSON, SHORT,
  and THOMAS JJ., concur. 

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.

  appeals claiming the magistrate erred in ruling the videotape of a breathalyzer

  failure to suppress the videotape from the incident site of the alleged DUI
  pursuant to Rule 220(b)(2), SCACR, and the following authorities: see State v. Miller,
  289 S.C. 426, 346 S.E.2d 705 (1986) (stating a criminal defendant may not
  appeal until sentence is imposed); South Carolina
  Code Section 14-3-330 (1976) and Rule 201(a), SCACR (stating only final
  judgments and limited interlocutory orders are appealable); Good v. Hartford Acc. & Indemn. Co., 201 S.C. 32, 21 S.E.2d 209, 212 (1942) (â€œa final judgment is one which operates to divest some right in
  such a manner as to put
  it beyond the power of the Court making the order to place the parties in their
  original condition after the expiration of the term; that is, it must put the
  case out of Court, and must be final in all matters within the pleadingsâ€); Mid-State
    Distributors, Inc. v. Century Importers, Inc., 310 S.C. 330, 334, 426
  S.E.2d 777, 780 (1993) (stating orders involving the merits â€œmust finally
  determine some substantial matter forming the whole or a part of some cause of
  action or defenseâ€ and orders affecting a substantial right must â€œdiscontinue
  an action, prevent an appeal, grant or refuse a new trial, or strike out an
  action or defenseâ€).
We deny the Stateâ€™s
  appeal regarding suppression of the breathalyzer
  results and videotape of the breathalyzer test pursuant to Rule 220(b)(2),
  SCACR, and the following authorities: see State v. Pichardo,
  367 S.C. 84, 96, 623 S.E.2d 840, 846-47 (Ct. App. 2005) (â€œthe Stateâ€™s right to
  appeal in a criminal case is a judicially created rightâ€); State v. Belviso,
  360 S.C. 112, 115, 600 S.E.2d 68, 70 (Ct. App. 2004) (citing State v.
    McKnight, 287 S.C. 167, 337 S.E.2d 208 (1985)) (â€œ[a] pre-trial order
  granting the suppression of evidence which significantly impairs the
  prosecution of a criminal case is directly appealable under S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  14-3-330(2)(a) (1976)â€); State v. Kinner, 301 S.C. 209, 210, 391 S.E.2d
  251, 252 (1990) (noting testimony of defendantâ€™s erratic driving and strong
  odor of alcohol support a conviction of driving under the influence).Â   
Accordingly the
  order of the trial court is affirmed and the case is remanded for trial.
ANDERSON, SHORT, and THOMAS, JJ., concur.

title: State v. Rivera
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO
  PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				The State, Respondent,
			
		
	

v.

	
		
			
				Marlon Rivera, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Greenville County
Â C. Victor Pyle, Jr., Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-187
Heard March 6, 2008 â€“ Filed March 18, 2008
REVERSED and REMANDED


	
		
			
				Deputy Chief Attorney for Capital Appeals Robert M. Dudek, of Columbia; for Appellant.
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, Assistant
  Attorney General S. Creighton Waters, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Robert M.
  Ariail, of Greenville, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  Marlon
  Rivera appeals his murder conviction, arguing the trial judge erred in (1)
  admitting his statement to police, (2) admitting hearsay testimony, (3)
  refusing to allow an unsequestered witness to testify, and (4) failing to
  charge accident and involuntary manslaughter.Â  We reverse and remand.Â   
FACTS
This case involves the killing of Wilfredo Solis Monge.Â 
  At approximately 12:30 a.m. on July 18, 2005, police officers arrived at the
  scene of a reported shooting in Greenville County.Â  There were a number of
  people at the scene, most of whom only spoke Spanish.Â  When police arrived, Monge
  was lying on the ground.Â  After the paramedics took Monge to the hospital, detectives
  were called to the scene.Â   
Police attempted
  to speak with witnesses at the scene and one witness informed the police the
  shooter was two blocks away in a nearby bar. Â Police accompanied the witness to
  the bar, where the witness subsequently identified Rivera as the person who
  shot Monge.Â  Officers then placed Rivera in custody.Â   
Officers took
  Rivera to the law enforcement center to be interviewed.Â  Although Rivera does
  not speak English, a Spanish-speaking officer was present to inform Rivera of
  his rights and translate his statements.Â  The officer explained Riveraâ€™s
  rights, and Rivera subsequently signed a written waiver of rights form.Â  During
  the interview, Rivera gave a statement to police. Â The translated version of
  the statement indicates Rivera admitted to shooting Monge.Â  After the
  interview, the Spanish-speaking officer and Investigator Smith escorted Rivera
  to the detention center.  
At
  trial, the State offered evidence supporting Riveraâ€™s guilt, including Riveraâ€™s
  confession to police. Â The trial judge admitted the statement following a
  hearing on its admissibility.Â  The State also offered evidence of the statement
  made by Rivera while officers were escorting him to the detention center.Â  
 
Additionally,
  the State offered the testimony of Nelson Castro, Riveraâ€™s cousin, who
  testified that on the night of the shooting, Rivera arrived at his residence
  and informed him he had killed someone.Â  Castro further testified Rivera told
  him he was wrestling with someone else and the firearm â€œjust went off by
  itself.â€  
Upon taking the
  stand, Rivera denied shooting Monge.Â  He also offered the testimony of several
  witnesses, including Carlos Freeman, who had been serving as his interpreter to
  corroborate the testimony of other witnesses.Â  The trial judge refused
  to allow Freeman to testify because he had been in the courtroom for the
  entirety of the trial in violation of the sequestration order which Rivera
  himself requested.Â   
After all of the
  evidence had been presented, Rivera requested the jury be charged on
  self-defense, accident, and involuntary manslaughter.Â  The trial judge denied
  Riveraâ€™s request.Â  Rivera was convicted of murder and sentenced to thirty years
  imprisonment.Â  This appeal followed.  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Rivera
  argues the trial judge erred by ruling Rivera was not entitled to a jury
  instruction on involuntary manslaughter.Â  We agree.
â€œThe law to be charged must be determined from the evidence
  presented at trial.â€Â  State v. Patterson, 367 S.C. 219, 231, 625
  S.E.2d 239, 245 (Ct. App. 2006).Â  â€œIf any evidence supports a requested jury charge, the trial court should
  grant the request.â€ Â State v. Ward, 374 S.C. 606, 614, 649 S.E.2d 145, 149 (Ct.
  App. 2007) (citing State v. Brown, 362 S.C. 258, 262, 607 S.E.2d 93, 95
  (Ct. App. 2004)). Â â€œDue
  process requires that a lesser included offense be charged when the evidence
  warrants it but only if the evidence would permit a jury rationally to find the
  defendant guilty of the lesser offense.â€Â  State v. Small, 307 S.C. 92,
  94, 413 S.E.2d 870, 871 (Ct. App. 1992).Â  â€œTo warrant reversal, a trial court's
  refusal to give a requested jury charge must be both
  erroneous and prejudicial to the defendant.â€ Â Patterson, 367 S.C. at 232, 625 S.E.2d at 245. 
 
Rivera
  relies upon the testimony of Nelson Castro, a witness for the prosecution, who
  stated Rivera had told Castro the shooting occurred while Rivera was wrestling
  with another man and the gun accidentally discharged.Â  During his testimony,
  Castro stated specifically: â€œHe said that when they were wrestling both of them
  were grabbing the pistol.Â  And what he told me is that the other one, one had
  grabbed the pistol away from him.Â  And in that the shot went off.â€Â  This
  testimony is substantially different from that of Rivera himself.Â  Rivera
  testified that during the fight the gun slipped inside of his pants and started
  falling down his pant leg until it fell out onto the ground.Â  He then testified
  that both he and the assailant went after the gun, but he got it first and shot
  twice toward the ground in order to scare the assailant.Â  He further stated
  that at that point another man whom he knew as â€œSkinnyâ€ grabbed the gun and
  shot one time in the direction of Mauricio and then gave the gun back.Â  Once
  they realized someone had been hit by the gunfire they ran from the scene.
Riveraâ€™s
  testimony at trial not only differs from Castroâ€™s testimony but also differs
  substantially from the statement Rivera originally gave to investigating
  officers.Â  Riveraâ€™s statement to the officers admits to grabbing the weapon, pointing
  it at his assailant, and firing it two times.Â  In his statement to
  investigators, Rivera fails to mention or identify anyone other than himself
  firing the weapon.
While
  Riveraâ€™s testimony at trial differed from his signed statement, defense witnesses
  Courtney Robles and Norberto Ortiz corroborated Riveraâ€™s trial testimony.Â  Robles
  testified that a guy in a striped shirt was fighting a guy in a white shirt.Â 
  Then a guy in a black shirt got the gun from the guy in the striped shirt and
  fired it towards the guy in the white shirt.Â  She further stated that she could
  not remember specifics about these three menâ€™s appearances other than their
  general characteristics and the clothes they were wearing.Â  Ortiz, an
  acquaintance of Rivera, testified that Rivera only fired the weapon towards the
  ground and that another guy whom he did not know grabbed the weapon and fired
  it towards the man who had been fighting with Rivera.  
Involuntary manslaughter is defined as (1) the unintentional killing of
  another without malice, but while engaged in an unlawful activity not naturally
  tending to cause death or great bodily harm; or (2) the unintentional killing
  of another without malice, while engaged in a lawful activity with reckless
  disregard for the safety of others. Â State v. Pittman, 373 S.C. 527,
  571, 647 S.E.2d 144, 167 (2007).Â   
While there are several inconsistent explanations for the fatal
  shot in this case, including the testimony by Rivera that he was not the actual
  shooter, Castroâ€™s testimony would support a jury finding the weapon discharged
  during a struggle over the weapon.Â  Despite the disparity of evidence and
  conflicting versions of the facts presented by Rivera, all of the evidence
  including Riveraâ€™s inconsistent statements must be viewed in the light most
  favorable to the defendant.Â  See State v. Knoten, 347 S.C.
  296, 555 S.E.2d 391 (2001).Â  Moreover, Rivera admits to firing the weapon
  towards the ground.Â  The discharge of a firearm in a public area is evidence of
  recklessness in the absence of self-defense.Â  â€œThe fact that there may have been evidence showing the shooting was
  intentional did not negate the other inferences that could be drawn from all
  the evidence.â€Â  State v. Mekler, 368 S.C. 1, 16, 626 S.E.2d 890,
  898 (Ct. App. 2005), cert. granted (2007).Â  Evidence a weapon
  discharged during a struggle is sufficient for submission of an involuntary
  manslaughter instruction to the jury. Â Casey v. State, 305 S.C. 445,
  447, 409 S.E.2d 391, 392 (1991).Â  If the jury believed the testimony of
  Castro, it could find the gun was fired during a struggle between Rivera and
  another party and conclude Rivera was guilty of involuntary manslaughter. â€œTo
  warrant a courtâ€™s eliminating the offense of manslaughter, it should very
  clearly appear that there is no evidence whatsoever tending to reduce the crime
  from murder to manslaughter.â€ State v. Cole, 338 S.C. 97, 101, 525
  S.E.2d 511, 513 (2000).Â  It is not our province on review to decide which
  testimony to believe; the jury must determine the facts and resolve any issues
  of credibility.
Here,
  there is some evidence supporting an involuntary manslaughter charge.Â  The
  failure to submit this charge to the jury prejudiced Rivera and warrants a new
  trial.
CONCLUSION
The trial judge erred
  in failing to instruct the jury on involuntary manslaughter and Rivera was
  prejudiced by this error; thus, he is entitled to a new trial.Â  Furthermore, in
  light of our disposition of the issue pertaining to the trial judgeâ€™s refusal
  to charge the jury on involuntary manslaughter, the remaining issues on appeal are
  not dispositive and need not be addressed.Â  See Whiteside v. Cherokee County School Dist. No. One, 311 S.C. 335, 340, 428 S.E.2d 886, 889 (1993) (appellate
  court need not address remaining issues when resolution of prior issue is dispositive).Â  Accordingly, Riveraâ€™s conviction is
REVERSED and
  REMANDED.
HEARN, C.J.,
  PIEPER, J., and CURETON, A.J. concur.
