REVERSED AND REMANDED 



	
		
			
				Chief Attorney Joseph L. Savitz, III, of Columbia, for Appellant.
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
  General John W. McIntosh, and Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J.
  Zelenka, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Harold W. Gowdy, III, of Spartanburg,
  for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  David
  Dwight Smith (Smith) was convicted of murder and possession of a firearm during
  the commission of a violent crime.Â  He asserts on appeal the trial judge erred
  in refusing to instruct the jury on: 1) voluntary manslaughter, 2) involuntary
  manslaughter, and 3) accident.Â  We reverse and remand.
FACTS


Smith was indicted for murder and possession of a firearm during the
  commission of a violent crime.Â  The charges arose from the January 12, 1997
  shooting of Robert Finley (Finley). At trial, the jury found Smith guilty of
  both charges and the judge sentenced him to life imprisonment for murder and
  five years, concurrent, for possession of a firearm during the commission of a
  violent crime.
  
  
  
Smith
  unsuccessfully appealed his case and then filed an application for
  post-conviction relief (PCR) alleging (1) ineffective assistance of counsel and
  (2) failure to call an expert witness.Â  After a hearing, the judge granted
  Smith post-conviction relief. 
  
  
Smith was
  retried on October 31, 2005.Â  The jury found him guilty of both charges. The
  judge sentenced him to imprisonment for thirty-five years for murder and five
  years, concurrent, for possession of a firearm during the commission of a
  violent crime. 
  
  
At trial,
  testimony revealed that at approximately 2:30 a.m. on the night in question
  Finley walked to Otis Hyderâ€™s (Hyder) mobile home to use his phone.Â  Finley
  wanted to purchase some crack cocaine and called a dealer, Rodney Smith
  (Rodney).[1] Â Rodney refused to help Finley, but Rodneyâ€™s sister, Angie Smith (Angie),
  volunteered to set up a drug buy between Finley and another dealer, Smith.Â 
  Smith picked Angie up at home and the two drove to meet Finley at Otis Hyderâ€™s
  mobile home. 
  
  
Initially,
  Smith stayed in the car while Angie entered Hyderâ€™s trailer. She attempted to
  facilitate the drug deal, but Finley wanted to deal with Smith directly. Â Angie
  returned to the car and informed Smith of the situation.Â  Smith walked into the
  trailer; once inside Smith realized Finley did not have money for the deal and
  that Finley insisted on keeping the drugs.Â  Smith testified that Finley tried
  to rob him.Â  The situation escalated into a fight and struggle over control of
  a firearm that was in Smithâ€™s possession.Â  During the fight, the firearm
  discharged striking Finley in the left eye killing him. 
  
  
During the first trial, Judge Derham Cole charged the jury on the law
  of voluntary manslaughter, involuntary manslaughter, and accident, the three
  charges at issue in this appeal.Â  In the case at hand, Judge Jack Early charged
  the jury on murder and self-defense. In addition, Smith requested charges on voluntary
  manslaughter, involuntary manslaughter, and accident, which the judge denied.

  
  STANDARD OF REVIEW
  â€œIn
    criminal cases, the appellate court sits to review errors of law only.â€ State
      v. Wilson, 345 S.C. 1, 5-6, 545 S.E.2d 827, 829 (2001); State v.
        Wood, 362 S.C. 520, 525, 608 S.E.2d 435, 438 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  Generally,
    the trial judge is required to charge only the current and correct law of South Carolina.Â  Sheppard v. State, 357 S.C. 646, 665, 594 S.E.2d 462, 472-73
    (2004); State v. Brown, 362 S.C. 258, 261-62, 607 S.E.2d 93, 95 (Ct.
    App. 2004). â€œThe law
    to be charged must be determined from the evidence presented at trial.â€Â  State
      v. Patterson, 367 S.C. 219, 231, 625 S.E.2d 239, 245 (Ct. App. 2006).Â 
    If any evidence supports a jury charge, the trial judge should grant the
    request.Â  Brown, 362 S.C. at 262, 607 S.E.2d at 95.Â  â€œDue process
    requires that a lesser included offense be charged when the evidence warrants
    it but only if the evidence would permit a jury rationally to find the
    defendant guilty of the lesser offense.â€Â  State v. Small, 307 S.C. 92,
    94, 413 S.E.2d 870, 871 (Ct. App. 1992).Â  â€œTo warrant reversal, a trial court's
    refusal to give a requested jury charge must be both
    erroneous and prejudicial to the defendant.â€ Â Patterson, 367 S.C. at 232, 625 S.E.2d at 245.
    Â 
  DISCUSSION
  ISSUE:
  Did the trial judge err in refusing to charge
    voluntary manslaughter, involuntary manslaughter, and accident?
  Voluntary Manslaughter
  First, Smith contends that his murder conviction should be
    reversed and remanded for a new trial based on the trial judgeâ€™s failure to
    charge the jury on the law of voluntary manslaughter.Â  We agree.
  Voluntary manslaughter is defined as the â€œunlawful
    killing of a human being in the sudden heat of passion upon sufficient legal
    provocation.â€ State v. Knoten, 347 S.C. 296, 302, 555 S.E.2d 391,
    394 (2001).Â  Both heat of passion and sufficient legal provocation must be
    present for the killing to constitute voluntary manslaughter. Id. at
    302, 555 S.E.2d at 394; State v. Cole, 338 S.C. 97, 101-02, 525
    S.E.2d 511, 513 (2000).
  â€œ[T]o warrant the
    Court in eliminating the offense of manslaughter it should very clearly appear
    that there is no evidence whatsoever tending to reduce the crime from murder to
    manslaughter.â€ State v. Gardner, 219 S.C. 97, 64 S.E.2d 130, 134
    (1951) (citing State v. Norton, 28 S.C. 572, 6 S.E. 820 (1888)).
    Moreover, South Carolina case law consistently holds that a request to charge a
    lesser included offense is properly refused only when there is no evidence that
    the defendant committed the lesser rather than the greater offense. Â See State v. Goldenbaum, 294 S.C. 455, 457, 365 S.E.2d 731, 732
    (1988).Â  â€œIn determining
    whether the evidence requires a charge on voluntary manslaughter, this Court
    must view the facts in the light most favorable to
    the defendant.â€ Cole, 338 S.C. at 101, 525 S.E.2d at 512-13 (citing State
      v. Byrd, 323 S.C. 319, 474 S.E.2d 430 (1996)).
  The
    record supports a charge on the law of voluntary manslaughter.Â  Smith claims the
    victim was attempting to rob him thereby provoking the altercation which he
    ultimately claims caused the alleged accidental shooting.Â  Smith specifically
    testified that Finley â€œwas coming toward me, the expression on his face and
    everything was a real serious demeanor, and I, you know, I didnâ€™t know what to
    expect from him next: . . . [h]e looked like he was on something.â€ Â Smith
    further stated, â€œ[a]s I said, he had this look about him, and he was
    approaching me.Â  So, I took the gun out of my pocket hoping that if he saw it,
    that maybe he would cease.â€ Â Smith also testified that Finley â€œtries to knock
    the gun out my hand.Â  He hit me with the left, with the left arm and grabbed me
    in my collar of the jacket . . . I thought I was gonna lose the gun.Â  He had
    hit it and I got the grip on the gun and heâ€™s got me . . . I went to defend
    myself.Â  I threw my left arm over his, over his arm that he had me grab, and I
    hit him with the butt of the gun. . . . I was trying to get out of there . . . He
    was coming up on me, I was afraid. . . . I was hitting him with the gun and it
    went off and hit him in the face.â€Â   
  This testimony, coupled with the testimony of Angie who described
    the encounter right before the shot was fired as two men scuffling and falling
    out of the trailer door, sufficiently depicts a fight between Finley and Smith immediately
    preceding the shooting and after Smith claimed Finley was trying to rob him.Â  Thus,
    the record contains testimony from Smith that Finley initiated the physical
    confrontation by trying to rob him and aggressively approaching him.Â  Smith
    testified he was trying to escape the situation and feared Finley would gain
    possession of the firearm.Â  Moreover, Smith testified that the discharge of the
    pistol was a â€œ[f]luke accident.Â  I was hitting him with the gun and it went off
    and hit him in the face.â€Â  Smith testified â€œI didnâ€™t intend to use it, and I
    never pointed it at him.â€  
  The trial judge, in denying Smithâ€™s request to charge voluntary
    manslaughter, determined that there was insufficient evidence to show sudden
    heat of passion although Smith claimed Finley tried to rob him and that they
    were fighting.Â  In State v. Davis, 278 S.C. 544, 298 S.E.2d 778 (1983), the
    court found that a voluntary manslaughter charge was appropriate where â€œa
    witness testified that appellant and the victim had been â€˜fighting.â€™ From this
    circumstance of â€˜provocationâ€™ and â€˜heat of passion,â€™ guilt of voluntary
    manslaughter could be fairly and logically deduced and was thus a proper matter
    for jury determination.â€ Id. at 546, 298 S.E.2d at 779 (citing State
      v. Kahan, 268 S.C. 240, 233 S.E.2d 293 (1977)).
  Viewing the case at hand in the light most favorable to Smith, the
    requested charge is appropriate.Â  Cole, 338 S.C. at 101, 525 S.E.2d at
    513.Â  The trial judge charged self-defense[2] but declined to also charge voluntary manslaughter. If the trial judge
    concluded, as the solicitor argued, that the element of legal provocation could
    not be simultaneously used in support of both self-defense as well as voluntary
    manslaughter, that conclusion nonetheless constitutes legal error.  
  
	Both self-defense and the lesser included offense of voluntary
    manslaughter should be submitted to the jury if supported by the evidence. 
	State
      v. Linder, 276 S.C. 304, 278 S.E.2d 335 (1981). The rationale for
    this rule is that the jury may fail to find all the elements of self-defense
    but could find sufficient legal provocation and heat of passion to conclude the
    defendant was guilty of voluntary manslaughter. Id.

  State v. Gilliam, 296 S.C. 395, 396-97, 373 S.E.2d 596, 597 (1988).Â  
	 
  Further,
    any concern about whether the defendant was acting with presumed malice (or a
    mandatory presumption of malice) as a matter of law because of the alleged
    commission of a felony has recently been answered and revisited by our supreme
    court in Lowry v. State, Op. No. 26436 (S.C. Sup. Ct. filed Feb. 11,
    2008). In Lowry, the supreme court rejected the presumed malice (substantive
    rule of law) approach to the felony murder rule as unconstitutionally shifting
    the stateâ€™s burden of proof on the issue of malice.Â  The court continues to
    adhere to precedent regarding the alternative inference of malice approach
    suggested in State v. Norris, 285 S.C. 86, 92, 328 S.E.2d 339, 342
    (1985) (overruled on other grounds by State v. Torrence, 305 S.C. 45,
    406 S.E.2d 315 (1991).Â Â  Any implication of malice arising from an act
    occurring during the commission of a felony may be accepted or rejected by the
    jury as it deems appropriate.
  We,
    therefore, respectfully find the trial judge should have instructed the jury on
    voluntary manslaughter and that Smith was prejudiced by the failure to charge
    the lesser offense.Â  Because we reverse on the issue of voluntary manslaughter,
    we need not address the remaining issues presented. Whiteside v. Cherokee County School Dist.
      No. One, 311 S.C. 335,
    340, 428 S.E.2d 886, 889 (1993) (appellate court need not address remaining
    issues when resolution of prior issue is dispositive).
  CONCLUSION
  We respectfully conclude the trial court
    erred in refusing to instruct the jury on voluntary manslaughter; we also find
    that Smith was prejudiced by this error. Â Therefore, we reverse the conviction
    and remand the case to the circuit court for a new trial.Â  Furthermore, in
    reversing Smithâ€™s murder conviction, we must also reverse the conviction for
    possession of a firearm during the commission of a violent crime because the
    former conviction is a prerequisite to the latter.Â  E.g., S.C. Code Ann.
    Â§ 16-23-490(E) (2003) (noting the additional punishment for possession of a
    firearm during the commission of a violent crime may not be imposed unless the
    defendant is convicted of the underlying violent crime); State v. Taylor, 356 S.C. 227, 235 n.4, 589 S.E.2d 1, 5 n.4 (2003) (noting defendant's
    conviction for possession of a weapon during the commission of a violent crime
    must be reversed where the court was reversing defendant's murder conviction). Â Based
    on the foregoing, Smithâ€™s convictions are hereby
  REVERSED
    AND REMANDED.
  HUFF
    and PIEPER, JJ., and CURETON, A.J., concur.


[1] Since the appellant is referred to as â€œSmithâ€
  throughout this order and there are two key witnesses named Rodney Smith and
  Angie Smith, these witnesses will be referred to as Rodney and Angie
  respectively to avoid any confusion.
[2] No issues on appeal have been argued as to the
  judgeâ€™s charge of self-defense.

title: MidFirst Bank v. Brooks
text:
I


THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT
  BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				MidFirst Bank, Respondent,
				v.
				Marie Brooks, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Sumter County
Â Linwood S. Evans, Jr., Master-in-Equity
Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-196
Submitted March 4, 2008 â€“ Filed March 20,
  2008
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Marie Brooks, of Sumter, pro se.
				Dean Anthony Hayes, of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  This
  is a foreclosure case.Â  The trial court granted summary judgment to MidFirst
  Bank, Inc., holding the mortgagor, Marie Brooks was precluded from asserting
  certain defenses and counterclaims.Â  Brooks appeals.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS AND PROCEDURAL HISTORY
In 1990, Brooks executed and delivered a
  mortgage note to First Carolina Mortgage Corporation in which she promised to
  pay a principal sum of $71,025.00.Â  In order to secure payment of the note, Brooks
  also executed and delivered to First Carolina a mortgage of real property
  located in Sumter County.
On April 14, 1998, MidFirst, the current assignee of the note and
  mortgage, filed a foreclosure action against Brooks, alleging Brooks failed to
  make the payments required by the note. Â Brooks was served on May 29, 1998.Â  On
  July 17, 1998, without responding to the summons and complaint in the
  foreclosure action, Brooks filed a Chapter 13 bankruptcy petition in the United
  States District Court for South Carolina, thereby staying the foreclosure
  action.
Brooks included the mortgage debt in her Chapter 13 payment plan,
  noting the payments were $280 or more per month plus 8.25% interest.Â  By
  settlement order dated January 23, 2001, the bankruptcy judge set forth the
  payments that Brooks was to make and further provided that, in the event she
  failed to comply with the order, MidFirst would automatically be entitled to
  relief from the bankruptcy stay by filing an affidavit with the bankruptcy
  court.
On
  September 10, 2002, the bankruptcy court issued an order finding Brooks defaulted
  on the terms of the settlement order.Â  As a result, the automatic bankruptcy stay
  was lifted, enabling MidFirst to proceed with the foreclosure.Â  In January
  2003, MidFirst filed an amended summons and complaint in the foreclosure
  action.Â  On April 11, 2003, Brooks filed a responsive pleading, inÂ  which she
  denied MidFirst was entitled to the relief it requested and counterclaimed for
  relief under the South Carolina Tort Claims Act, setoff for payments allegedly
  made, slander, and intentional infliction of emotional distress.
On
  November 13, 2005, the parties entered into a consent dismissal under Rule
  40(j), SCRCP.Â  In 2005, they agreed to have the matter restored to the active roster.Â 
  The matter was then referred to the Sumter County Master-in-Equity.
On
  August 8, 2005, MidFirst filed a motion for summary judgment, including with
  the motion an affidavit stating the total debt, excluding costs of the action,
  was $86,585.71.Â  In response, Brooks submitted an affidavit alleging (1)
  MidFirst failed to give her credit for numerous payments; (2) the bankruptcy
  trustee wrongfully returned a number of payments that would have significantly
  reduced her debt: (3) because of numerous assignments of her loan, she was not
  given timely credit for all payments made; (4) MidFirst had made fraudulent
  representations to her regarding its investigation of her account; and (5)
  MidFirstâ€™s alleged mishandling of her account forced her to file bankruptcy,
  thus harming her credit rating and financial reputation.
A hearing on the motion took place on October 12, 2005. Â By order
  dated November 16, 2005, the Master granted summary judgment to MidFirst,
  holding Brooks could not pursue her counterclaims because of lack of standing,
  judicial estoppel, and res judicata.Â  This appeal follows.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œIn reviewing an order of summary judgment, an appellate
  court applies the same standard as that which the circuit court applied in
  determining whether to enter the order.â€Â  Helms Realty, Inc. v. Gibson-Wall
    Co., 363 S.C. 334, 340, 611 S.E.2d 485, 488 (2005).Â  â€œSummary judgment is
  appropriate â€˜if the pleadings, depositions, answers to interrogatories, and
  admissions on file, together with the affidavits, if any, show that there is no
  genuine issue as to any material fact and that the moving party is entitled to
  a judgment as a matter of law.â€™ â€ Id. (citing Rule 56, SCRCP).Â  Nevertheless,
  when an appellate court affirms the grant of summary judgment on a particular basis,
  it need not discuss the remaining grounds.Â  Fuller-Ahrens Pâ€™ship v. S.C.
    Depâ€™t of Highways and Pub. Transp., 311 S.C. 177, 182, 427 S.E.2d 920, 923
  (Ct. App. 1987).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Brooks
  argues that, notwithstanding that her inadvertent failure to list certain
  claims and defenses in her Chapter 13 bankruptcy action, equitable factors and principles
  allow her to them against MidFirst in the foreclosure action.Â  She further maintains
  the evidence she presented to the Master regarding these claims and defenses is
  sufficient to create a genuine issue of material fact as to whether MidFirst is
  entitled to judgment.Â  Assuming without deciding that Brooks has adequately
  preserved this issue for appellate review,[2] we hold the equitable factors and principles on which she relies do not allow
  her to proceed on her counterclaims and defenses.
Once a debtor files
  for bankruptcy in the federal court, an estate is created that is comprised of
  â€œall legal or equitable interests of the debtor in property as of the
  commencement of the case.â€Â  11 U.S.C.A. Â§541(a)(1) (2004).Â  Upon filing, the
  debtor is required to file a list of all creditors and a schedule of assets and
  liabilities, unless the bankruptcy court orders otherwise.Â  Id. Â§
  521(a)(1)(A)-(B)(i) (Supp. 2007).Â  â€œLegal or equitable interestsâ€ has been broadly
  defined to include causes of action. Â In re Educators Group Health Trust,
  25 F.3d 1281, 1283-84 (5th Cir. 1994) (citation omitted).Â  â€œIf a cause of
  action belongs to the estate, then the trustee has exclusive standing to assert
  the claim.â€Â  Id. at 1284.Â   
When
  bankruptcy proceedings close, â€œany assets, including
  claims, that were scheduled by the debtor but not disposed of are deemed
  abandoned and revert to the debtor.â€ Â Tyler House Apartments, Ltd. v.
    U.S., 38 Fed. Cl. 1, 6 (1997).Â  Unscheduled claims, however, remain under
  the control of the bankruptcy trustee.Â  Id. â€œIf a cause of action
  belongs to the estate, then the trustee has exclusive standing to assert the
  claim.â€Â  Educators Group Health Trust, 25 F.3d at 1284.
In
  the present case, Brooks concedes she failed to include in her Chapter 13
  Bankruptcy Schedule B the defenses and counterclaims she sought to enforce
  against MidFirst in the foreclosure action, but contends this failure was
  inadvertent.Â  She further argues her responsive pleadings â€œwere a matter of
  record prior to the bankruptcy and the simple mistake of not listing should not
  result in the complete loss of [her] right to contest a foreclosure and
  specific defenses of tendered payment when evidence exists the allegations of
  nonpayment are not true.â€Â  As we have noted in the facts and procedural
  background, however, Brooks did not file responsive pleadings until April 11,
  2003, seven months after the bankruptcy stay was lifted. Â Her assertion, then,
  that MidFirst had record notice of her defenses and counterclaims is incorrect
  and cannot support her reliance on equitable factors and principles as grounds to
  pursue the claims and defenses she seeks to pursue in the foreclosure proceeding.Â 
 
We
  therefore hold the grant of summary judgment was proper based on the
  determination that Brooks lacked standing to assert the defenses and
  counterclaims that she raised in her responsive pleadings.Â  Because this basis
  is sufficient to support the Masterâ€™s decision, we do not address the other
  grounds for his decision concerning judicial estoppel and res judicata.Â  See Weeks v. McMillan, 291 S.C. 287, 292, 353 S.E.2d 289, 292 (Ct. App.
  1987) (â€œWhere a decision is based on alternative grounds, either of which independent
  of the other is sufficient to support it, the decision will not be reversed
  even if one of the grounds is erroneous.â€).
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, SHORT, and THOMAS, JJ., concur.


[1]Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant
  to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]Â  MidFirst acknowledges Brooks raised the issue in her
  memorandum submitted in opposition to the summary judgment motion, but points
  out the Master did not rule on it in his order. Â Although Brooks filed a motion
  for reconsideration, the motion itself is not included in the record on
  appeal.Â  The order denying the motion, which is included in the record does not
  specifically address the argument concerning equitable factors and principles
  that Brooks presents in this appeal.

title: Rolfe v. Rolfe
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO
  PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.

	
		
			
				THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
				In The Court of Appeals
				William Eric
      Rolfe, Respondent,
				v.
				Abigail J. Rolfe, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Darlington County
Â James A. Spruill, III, Family Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-197
Submitted February 1, 2008 â€“ Filed March
  20, 2008Â Â Â  
REVERSED IN PART AND REMANDED IN PART


	
		
			
				Marian D. Nettles, Philip Bryan Atkinson, of Florence, for
  Appellant.
				Robbie Forrester Gardner, III, of Hartsville, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  In
  this domestic action, Abigail Rolfe (Wife) appeals the family courtâ€™s
  order reducing alimony payments of William
  Eric Rolfe (Husband) and the failure to award attorneyâ€™s fees and costs.Â  We reverse
  in part and remand in part.
FACTS
Husband and Wife were married for twenty-six
  years.Â  During the marriage, Husband worked as a mechanic with Sonoco Products
  Corporation (Sonoco), and on the side, he also had a heating and air
  conditioning business.Â  The family court found Husband was the primary source
  of income for the family, but Wife contributed indirectly to the marriage
  through â€œher services as a house wife, mother, and bookkeeper for [Husbandâ€™s]
  heating and air conditioning business.â€Â  After a no-fault divorce proceeding in
  1995, the family court ordered Husband to pay Wife $1,200 per month in
  permanent, periodic alimony based on Husbandâ€™s income potential of $6,000 per
  month.Â   
After the divorce was finalized, Husband quit his job with Sonoco and became self-employed in the heating
  and air conditioning repair business.Â  Additionally, Husband remarried on June 29, 1998.Â  In
  November 1999, Husbandâ€™s second wife was diagnosed with breast cancer, and she
  underwent treatment for approximately three years.Â  In May 2005, Husbandâ€™s second
  wife suffered a relapse.Â  Husband petitioned the family court for a reduction
  in the payment of permanent, periodic alimony based on a substantial change in
  circumstances.[1]Â 
  The family court reduced Husbandâ€™s alimony payments from $1,200 to $900 per
  month based on his decreased income, Wifeâ€™s unemployment, and the medical
  condition of Husbandâ€™s second wife.Â  Wife appeals.  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
On
  appeal from a family court order, this Court has authority to correct errors of
  law and find facts in accordance with our own view of the preponderance of the
  evidence.Â  E.D.M. v. T.A.M., 307 S.C. 471, 473, 415 S.E.2d 812, 814
  (1992).Â  However, â€œ[q]uestions concerning alimony rest with the sound
  discretion of the [family] court, whose conclusions will not be disturbed
  absent a showing of abuse of discretion.â€Â  Kelley v. Kelley, 324 S.C.
  481, 485, 477 S.E.2d 727, 729 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  An abuse of discretion occurs
  when the family courtâ€™s factual findings are without
  evidentiary support or are based upon an error of law. Â Id.
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Modification of
  Alimony 
Wife
  contends the family court abused its discretion in reducing Husbandâ€™s alimony
  payment based on (1) Husbandâ€™s underemployment; (2) Wifeâ€™s unemployment; and (3)
  the medical situation of Husbandâ€™s second wife.  
1. Underemployment
  of Husband
Wife
  first argues the family court erred in failing to impute income to Husband due
  to his voluntary underemployment.Â  We agree.Â   
The
  party seeking the change in alimony has the burden to prove an unforeseen change
  in circumstances warranting a modification.Â  Id. at 486, 477 S.E.2d at
  729.Â  â€œSeveral considerations relevant to the initial determination of alimony
  may be applied in the modification context as well, including the partiesâ€™
  standard of living during the marriage, each partyâ€™s earning capacity, and the
  supporting spouseâ€™s ability to continue to support the other spouse.â€Â  Penny
    v. Green, 357 S.C. 583, 589, 594 S.E.2d 171, 174 (Ct. App. 2004).
The
  South Carolina Supreme Court has emphasized it â€œwill closely scrutinize the
  facts of any case wherein a husband . . . voluntarily changes employment so as
  to lessen his earning capacity . . . .â€ Camp v. Camp, 269 S.C. 173, 174,
  236 S.E.2d 814, 815 (1977); see also Kelley, 324 S.C. at 488, 477
  S.E.2d at 731 (â€œ[V]oluntary changes in employment which impact a payor spouseâ€™s
  ability to pay alimony are to be closely scrutinized.â€).Â  In Camp the
  South Carolina Supreme Court, stated â€œWhere the husband has voluntarily
  relinquished a well-paying practice and has taken a position at a modest
  salary, the court may base the amount of alimony upon his capacity to earn
  money, or upon his prospective earnings.â€Â  Camp, 269 S.C. at 175, 236
  S.E.2d at 815 (internal quotations and citations omitted).Â   
Recently,
  the South Carolina Supreme Court held the motive behind voluntary
  underemployment may be a factor when courts consider earning capacity.Â  Arnal
    v. Arnal, 371 S.C. 10, 13, 636 S.E.2d 864, 866 (2006) (â€œThe motive behind any purported
  reduction in income or earning capacity should be considered, but prior South
  Carolina appellate decisions do not preclude a finding of voluntary underemployment
  in instances where a spouse reduces his earning capacity without doing so in
  bad faith.â€).Â 
  However, in Arnal, our Supreme Court limited its holding by stating,
  â€œ[A] parent seeking to impute income to the other parent need not establish a
  bad faith motivation to lower a support obligation in order to prove voluntary
  underemployment.â€Â  Arnal, 371 S.C. at 13, 636 S.E.2d at 866.Â  Although
  the facts in Arnal involved reduction of child support payments, because
  voluntary underemployment occurs in the alimony arena as well, we find the situation
  analogous to alimony.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 20-3-130 (C)(4) and (C)(6) (Supp. 2007) (requiring
  the family court to consider â€œthe employment history and earning potential of each spouseâ€ and â€œthe current and reasonable anticipated earnings of
  both spousesâ€ when awarding alimony) (emphasis added);Â  Messer v. Messer, 359 S.C. 614, 629,
  598 S.E.2d 310, 318 (Ct. App. 2004) (holding â€œa spouse obligated to pay alimony
  may not voluntarily or intentionally change his employment or economic
  circumstances so as to curtail his income and thereby avoid paying alimony or
  child supportâ€); see also Luthi v. Luthi, 289 S.C.
  489, 494, 347 S.E.2d 102, 105 (Ct. App. 1986) (â€œA party may not escape
  liability for alimony by intentionally refusing or failing to work.â€).
Here,
  Husbandâ€™s substantial change in circumstances occurred because of his decision
  to terminate his employment with Sonoco at the age of fifty-one.Â  As a result
  of his early retirement, Husband received $763.90 per month from Sonoco instead
  of $1,292.33 per month, which he would have received had he retired at age
  sixty.Â  Additionally, when Husband quit his job with Sonoco and became self-employed,
  the family court found he had the ability to earn $6,000 per month.Â  Since Husbandâ€™s
  divorce decree, he has advertised little, if at all, and the hours he works per
  week vary between ten to forty hours.Â  When asked if he could work the same
  hours he used to work, Husband responded, â€œI probably could, but I just donâ€™t
  feel like it, to tell the truth.â€Â  Husband cannot escape his current alimony
  obligation based on a desire not to work or an intentional refusal to work less
  than full-time.Â  SeeÂ  Id., 289 S.C. at 494, 347 S.E.2d at 105.Â  
 
In
  addition to his underemployment, Husband openly admitted to under-reporting his
  income on his tax returns and work log.Â  Specifically, Husband admitted, â€œIf
  somebody pays you in cash, you just kind of donâ€™t write it down sometimes.â€Â 
  Additionally, Husband stated his tax returns would not reflect those cash
  payments, and his tax returns are inconsistent with his financial declarations.Â 
  In his financial declarations, Husband estimated $2,763.90 as his total net
  monthly income and $1,400 as his total monthly expense; therefore, he is financially able to pay his previous alimony obligation,
  especially in light of his under-reporting.Â  Moreover, Husband admitted the
  home where he and his second wife currently reside is in his motherâ€™s name.Â  He
  testified he purchased the home with money he saved from working at Sonoco, and
  the reason the home is titled to husbandâ€™s mother is so he would not lose it if
  he went through another divorce.Â  By Husbandâ€™s estimate, the home is worth
  $80,000, and he does not make house payments on it.Â   
The
  family court reduced Husbandâ€™s alimony because his early retirement was a goal
  of both parties throughout their marriage.Â  However, we find Husband is
  voluntarily underemployed due to his decision to voluntarily terminate his
  employment with Sonoco and his decision not to work at full capacity in the
  heating and air conditioning business.Â  See Messer, 359 S.C. at 629,
  598 at 318 (holding â€œa spouse obligated to pay alimony may not voluntarily or
  intentionally change his employment or economic circumstances so as to curtail
  his income and thereby avoid paying alimony or child supportâ€); Kelley,
  324 S.C. at 486, 477 S.E.2d at 729-30 (â€œThe following
  circumstances, without more, have been found insufficient to warrant
  modification of alimony: unwarranted debts, inflation, increased or decreased
  income of the payor spouse, a payee spouseâ€™s anticipated employment, and the straitened
  financial situation[s] which are a normal consequence of divorce.â€) (internal
  quotations and citations omitted).
2.  Wifeâ€™s Unemployment
Wife
  next contends the family erred by taking her unemployment into account in its decision to reduce alimony.Â  We agree.Â  
 
Alimony is a substitute for support which is normally
  incidental to the martial relationship.Â  Johnson v. Johnson, 296 S.C.
  289, 300, 372 S.E.2d 107, 113 (Ct. App. 1988). Â Generally, the purpose of
  alimony is to place the supported spouse, to the extent possible, in the
  position she enjoyed during the marriage.Â  Id.Â  In Brown v. Brown,
  the South Carolina Supreme Court refused to reduce alimony payments when a former
  wife accepted a full-time employment position after the divorce.Â  278 S.C. 43,
  44, 292 S.E.2d 297, 297 (1982).Â  The Brown court noted the former wifeâ€™s
  employment was anticipated and, therefore, did not amount to a change in
  circumstances warranting modification in alimony.Â  Id.
In
  the present case, the family court found alimony was a â€œperfect disincentiveâ€
  for Wifeâ€™s employment.Â  Specifically, the family court stated Wife made no
  serious attempt to gain employment but worked several days a week volunteering.Â 
  However, we find Wife is entitled to the level of support she enjoyed prior to
  her divorce from Husband.Â  During the partiesâ€™ twenty-six year marriage, Wife
  did not work outside the home for a number of years even though she has two degrees
  from Coker College.[2]Â  During their marriage, Wife and Husband enjoyed a comfortable
  lifestyle, and they were able to acquire assets without incurring substantial
  debt.Â   
We
  find Wife is entitled to live in the manner she enjoyed prior to her divorce
  from Husband, and permanent, periodic alimony is designed to ensure Wife can maintain
  that lifestyle.Â  See Johnson, 296 S.C. at 300, 372 S.E.2d at 113 (â€œOrdinarily, the purpose of alimony is to
  place the supported spouse, as nearly as is practical, in the position of
  support she enjoyed during the marriage.â€).Â  Since
  her divorce, Wife has accrued debt and borrowed $50,000 on the marital home she
  received in the divorce.Â  Moreover, as stated in her financial declaration in
  2005, Wifeâ€™s net monthly income, prior to the family courtâ€™s decrease in
  alimony, was $1,794.16 and her expenses totaled $2,530.07.Â  Consequently, even
  with the previous alimony payment of $1,200, Wife was in a strained financial
  situation.Â  Accordingly,
  we find the family court abused its discretion by considering Wifeâ€™s
  unemployment in its decision to reduce alimony.Â   
3.Â  Medical Condition and Lack of Insurance for Second
  Spouse
Wife next asserts
  the family court erred in concluding the medical condition of Husbandâ€™s second
  wife and her lack of medical insurance justify a reduction in alimony.Â  As
  explained above, Husbandâ€™s
  second wife was diagnosed with breast cancer, and she underwent treatment for
  approximately three years.Â  In May 2005, Husbandâ€™s second wife suffered a
  relapse.Â  Husbandâ€™s second wife testified
  her current outstanding medical bills amount to approximately $15,000, and that
  she is making small payments.Â  Second wife stated that she has been able to
  obtain write offs or receive â€œcare adjustmentsâ€ for her medical expenses.Â  The
  family court found Husbandâ€™s second wifeâ€™s cancer constituted a substantial
  change in condition, noting, â€œthe cost of treatment will be very substantial
  and that the [Husband] will not be able to pay all of the costs associated with
  the treatment.â€Â   
There
  has been no showing in the record by Husband that he has or will incur any debt
  as a result of his current wifeâ€™s medical condition.Â  Thus, the family court
  improperly considered the medical condition of Husbandâ€™s second wife in
  altering alimony.Â  See Spivey ex rel. Spivey v. Carolina Crawler,
  367 S.C. 154, 160, 624 S.E.2d 435, 438 (Ct. App. 2005) (holding an
  appellate court examines justiciable controversies, which are real and substantial
  controversies, which are ripe and appropriate for judicial determination instead
  of merely contingent, hypothetical, or abstract disputes and issues that are
  not ripe are not appropriately before this Court).Â  We decline to express an
  opinion on whether it was proper for the family court to assign weight to second
  wifeâ€™s medical condition in altering Husbandâ€™s alimony payments when Husband
  has neither paid nor obligated himself to pay any of second wifeâ€™s medical
  expenses.Â  See Sloan v. Greenville County, 356 S.C. 531, 552, 590
  S.E.2d 338, 349 (Ct. App. 2003) (â€œThe function of appellate courts is not to
  give opinions on merely abstract or theoretical matters, but only to decide
  actual controversies injuriously affecting the rights of some party to the
  litigation.â€).Â   
II.Â  Attorneyâ€™s Fees and
  Costs
Finally,
  Wife argues the family court erred in failing to award her attorneyâ€™s fees and
  costs.Â  We agree.Â   
The
  family court has discretion in deciding whether to award attorneyâ€™s fees, and
  its decision will not be overturned absent an abuse of that discretion.Â  Patel
    v. Patel, 359 S.C. 515, 533, 599 S.E.2d 114, 123 (2004).Â  Â Â In deciding
  whether to award attorneyâ€™s fees, the family court should consider: (1) each
  partyâ€™s ability to pay his or her own fee; (2) the beneficial results obtained
  by the attorney; (3) the partiesâ€™ respective financial conditions; and (4) the
  effect of the fee on each partyâ€™s standard of living.Â  Id.  
The
  family court required each party to pay their own attorneyâ€™s fees and costs
  based on the above-mentioned factors.Â  Based on our reversal of the family
  courtâ€™s modification of alimony, Wifeâ€™s beneficial result has changed.Â 
  Furthermore, Wife was forced to defend an existing award of alimony because of Husbandâ€™s
  action for modification, which required representation of an attorney.Â 
  Therefore, we find it proper to award Wife attorneyâ€™s fees, and we remand this
  issue back to the family court for a determination of an appropriate amount
  based on the factors as set forth in Patel, 359 S.C. at 533, 599 S.E.2d at
  123.[3]Â  See Epperly v. Epperly, 312 S.C. 411, 416, 440 S.E.2d 884, 886-87
  (1994) (remanding case to family court for reconsideration of attorneyâ€™s fees
  when wife succeeded in part on appeal); Sexton v. Sexton, 310 S.C. 501,
  504, 427 S.E.2d 665, 666 (1993) (reversing and remanding the issue of
  attorneyâ€™s fees when substantive results achieved at trial level were reversed
  on appeal).Â   
CONCLUSION
Accordingly, we reverse
  the family courtâ€™s decision to reduce Husbandâ€™s alimony obligation due to a substantial and material change in his circumstances.Â 
  Additionally, we find it appropriate to award Wife attorneyâ€™s fees and costs
  and remand this issue to the family court to determine costs and
  attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Therefore, the family courtâ€™s order is  
REVERSED IN PART
  AND REMANDED IN PART.[4]
HUFF,
  KITTREDGE, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.


[1] In 1999, Husband petitioned the family court for a
  reduction in alimony, which the family court denied because husband â€œfailed to
  make out a clear showing that there has been a material change in the
  circumstances that would justify and require this court to reduce his payment of
  alimony to [Wife].â€Â   
[2] However, Wife did keep books for Husbandâ€™s heating and air
  conditioning business.Â   
[3] Testimony from the record indicates Wife owes $3,250
  in attorneyâ€™s fees based on twenty six hours of time billed at a $150 an hour.Â 
  Wifeâ€™s attorney submitted an affidavit to the family court to support
  attorneyâ€™s fees and costs with a statement concerning former Wifeâ€™s attorneyâ€™s
  age, background, and years of practice.Â  However, this affidavit is not part of
  the record on appeal.Â  Therefore, rather than determining attorneyâ€™s fees and
  costs at this level, we find it more appropriate for the family court to make a
  determination of a proper award.Â   
[4] We decide this case without oral arguments pursuant
  to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: Hines v. Hines
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO
  PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Karen
      Allen-Hines, Appellant,
				v.
				Franklin Hines, Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal From Darlington County
Â Roger E. Henderson, Family Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-198
Heard March 4, 2008 â€“ Filed March 20, 2008Â Â  
AFFIRMED IN PART and REMANDED


	
		
			
				Cynthia Barrier Patterson, of Columbia and Robert N. Rosen, of Charleston, for Appellant.
				Robert F. Gardner and J. Anthony Floyd, both of Hartsville, for
  Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  In
  this divorce action, Karen Allen-Hines (Wife) appeals the family courtâ€™s order
  denying her a special equity interest in Franklin Hinesâ€™ (Husband) businesses and
  awarding her one yearâ€™s rehabilitative alimony and partial attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  We
  affirm in part and remand.[1]Â  
 
FACTS
Husband and Wife (collectively the Hineses) married on February
  14, 1998.Â  Both Husband and Wife had been married previously.Â  The Hineses had
  no children together, though each had children from their previous
  relationships.Â  Husband had owned and operated a funeral home and cemetery
  since 1996.Â  The Hineses met when Wife utilized Husbandâ€™s services following
  her previous husbandâ€™s death.
Husband earned a bachelorâ€™s degree in education.Â  Husband began
  working at the familyâ€™s funeral home in 1973 and inherited it from his mother
  in 1996.Â  Before settling into his familyâ€™s funeral home business, he attended
  college, served in the military, taught school, and worked for the United
  States Postal Service.Â  In addition to the funeral home and cemetery, Husband
  owned several other properties, including a 75% interest in his home.Â  Husband
  was 70 years old at the time of trial.
Wife earned a bachelorâ€™s degree in sociology and a masterâ€™s degree
  in public administration.Â  In 1974, Wife worked as a social worker, but she had
  no degree in that area.Â  During her previous marriage, Wife raised the children
  and did not regularly work outside the home after 1989.Â  Her previous husband
  handled all the familyâ€™s finances until his death.Â  Wifeâ€™s net inheritance from
  her previous husband totaled approximately $1.5 million and included her home.Â 
  This inheritance supported Wife and her two dependent sons.Â  At the time of
  trial, this inheritance was severely depleted, and Wife possessed less than
  $500,000, most of which lay in home equity and personal property.Â  Wife
  was 49 years old at the time of trial.Â   
During their marriage, the Hineses lived primarily in Wifeâ€™s home
  from her former marriage.Â  Husband maintained his own separate home and kept
  his clothes at his house until Wife constructed a closet in her home to accommodate
  his clothes.Â  The Hineses also maintained separate bank accounts, except for
  one joint checking account they used to pay household bills.Â  Both Husband and
  Wife agreed to fund this account.Â  Despite an agreement to split household
  costs evenly, Husband often failed to deposit money into the joint account.Â  As
  a result, Wifeâ€™s funds paid most of the household bills.Â  Wife had poor
  money-management skills and frequently purchased extravagant items with her
  funds.Â  Wife met with a financial consultant who helped her create a budget,
  but she did not adhere to it.Â  Wife attempted unsuccessfully to gain outside
  employment during and after the marriage.Â   
During the marriage, Wife helped out at the funeral home and
  cemetery.Â  She did not make financial contributions to Husbandâ€™s business.Â  The
  funeral home compensated Wife for staffing and managing the floral department.Â 
  Without compensation, she also drove the limousine four or five times, attended
  funerals, redecorated the funeral home locations at Hartsville and Lamar,
  decorated the office at the cemetery, prepared lunches for Husband and his
  employees, delivered flowers, and generally helped out where needed.Â  Wife also
  made public appearances on behalf of the funeral home.Â  Furthermore, she
  introduced Husband to nationally known religious events in which she already
  participated.Â  When the funeral home later began sponsoring these events, Wife
  arranged television broadcasts of the events.Â  During the marriage, the funeral
  home and cemeteryâ€™s gross sales increased by approximately $342,058,[2] and the overall value of the funeral
  home increased by $396,444.Â   
The Hineses separated and reconciled five times during the
  marriage, usually due to financial stress.[3]Â 
  After their final separation, Wife filed an action for separate maintenance.Â 
  The family court tried this matter in June of 2004.Â  On August 5, 2004, the
  family court entered an order granting divorce on the ground of one yearâ€™s
  continuous separation and reserving jurisdiction to determine all other issues
  separately.Â  On January 10, 2005, the family court entered an order awarding
  Wife one year of rehabilitative alimony and partial attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  The order
  also denied Wife a special equity interest in Husbandâ€™s funeral home and
  cemetery.Â  Wife filed a motion to alter or amend the judgment, which was
  denied.Â  This appeal followed.  
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.  Special Equity
Wife
  argues the family court erred in declining to award her a special equity
  interest in Husbandâ€™s business.Â  We disagree.Â  Â Â 
The
  family court has jurisdiction to apportion marital property.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  20-7-472 (Supp. 2007).Â  In determining the most equitable apportionment of
  marital property, the family court must weigh all fifteen statutory factors.Â  Id.Â  Property acquired before the marriage or after entry of a divorce order is not
  marital property and, therefore, is not subject to apportionment.Â  S.C. Code
  Ann. Â§ 20-7-473(2) (Supp. 2007).Â  However, â€œany increase in value in nonmarital
  property[,] to the extent that the increase resulted directly or indirectly
  from efforts of the other spouse during marriage,â€ is apportionable marital
  property.Â  Â§ 20-7-473(5). Â The increase in value need not derive from the
  non-owner spouseâ€™s financial contributions.Â  Johnson v. Johnson, 296 S.C.
  289, 299, 372 S.E.2d 107, 113 (Ct. App. 1988).Â  The non-owner spouse is
  entitled to an equitable apportionment of any increase in value that results
  from the employment of his or her â€œlabor and skills.â€Â  Id. at 299, 372
  S.E.2d at 113.Â Â   
We
  find Wife is not entitled to a special equity interest in Husbandâ€™s funeral
  home and cemetery businesses.Â  Husband owned and operated these businesses
  prior to the marriage; thus, the businesses themselves are nonmarital
  property.Â  Although Wife presented evidence that she performed uncompensated
  services in support of the business, she failed to establish a causal connection between her efforts and any
  portion of the increased value of Husbandâ€™s businesses.Â  Therefore, Wife is not
  entitled to a special equity interest in the increased value of those
  businesses.
II.  Spousal Support 
Wife
  argues the family court erred in awarding her one year of rehabilitative
  alimony instead of permanent periodic alimony.Â  We remand this issue to the
  family court to make additional findings as to what special circumstances exist
  to support its award of rehabilitative alimony, or, in the absence of special
  circumstances, to award permanent periodic alimony instead.Â   
An
  award of alimony rests within the sound discretion of the family court and will
  not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Allen v. Allen,
  347 S.C. 177, Â­Â­Â­183-84, 554 S.E.2d 421, 424 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  An abuse of
  discretion occurs when the conclusions of the family court either lack
  evidentiary support or are controlled by an error of law.Â  Bryson v. Bryson,
  347 S.C. 221, 224, 553 S.E.2d 493, 495 (Ct. App.2001).
Alimony
  is a substitute for the support normally incident to marriage.Â  Allen,
  347 S.C. at 184, 554 S.E.2d at 424.Â  The purpose of alimony is to place the
  supported spouse in a position as near as possible to the position he or she
  enjoyed during the marriage.Â  Id. at 184, 554 S.E.2d at 424.Â  In
  awarding alimony, the family court must weigh all nine statutory factors.Â  S.C.
  Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-130(C) (Supp. 2007).Â  How much weight to accord each factor is
  within the family courtâ€™s sound discretion.Â  Id.Â  The family court has
  discretion to determine the amount of any alimony award.Â  S.C. Code Ann.
  Â§ 20-3-130(B)(1) (Supp. 2007).Â  All types of alimony contemplated by
  statute are modifiable and terminable.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-130 (Supp.
  2007)Â Â  Furthermore, the family court may impose whatever â€œterms and
  conditionsâ€ on an alimony award â€œas the court may consider just, as appropriate
  under the circumstances.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-170 (Supp. 2007).Â   
Where
  alimony is appropriate, South Carolina favors permanent periodic alimony over
  the other types of alimony described by statute.Â  Jenkins v. Jenkins,
  345 S.C. 88, 95, 545 S.E.2d 531, 535 (Ct. App. 2001).Â Â Â  Despite this
  preference, South Carolina does recognize rehabilitative alimony in certain
  circumstances. Rehabilitative alimony encourages a dependent spouse to become
  self-supporting after divorce and permits a former spouse to develop his own
  life free from obligations to the dependent spouse.Â  Belton v. Belton,
  325 S.C. 456, 459-60, 481 S.E.2d 174, 176 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  â€œRehabilitative
  alimony may be awarded only upon a showing of special circumstances justifying
  a departure from the normal preference from permanent periodic support.â€Â  Jenkins,
  345 S.C. at 95, 545 S.E.2d at 535.Â   
An
  award of one year of rehabilitative alimony without a finding of special
  circumstances meriting departure from permanent periodic alimony was improper.Â 
  In finding Wife entitled to spousal support, the family court carefully weighed
  the statutory factors, noting in particular the brief term of the marriage,
  numerous separations, and the partiesâ€™ advanced degrees.Â  The family court
  awarded one year of rehabilitative alimony based upon Wifeâ€™s antiquated work
  experience, â€œher degrees, her intelligence and her sophistication.â€Â  However,
  neither party made the showing of special circumstances required for such an
  award, and Wife did not request rehabilitative alimony.Â  The family court
  observed, â€œthere was no testimony as to what type of training may be required
  to enable [Wife] to become successful in the job market.â€Â  Indeed, no evidence
  of an educational program or plan, a timetable, a projected cost of retraining
  Wife, or an estimate of Wifeâ€™s likely earnings exists to support this award.Â  
 
Given
  the lack of specific findings of special circumstances warranting a departure
  from permanent periodic alimony, we find the family court erred in awarding one
  year of rehabilitative alimony.Â  Accordingly, we remand this issue for the
  family court to determine whether special circumstances exist to support its
  award of rehabilitative alimony, or, in the absence of special circumstances,
  to award permanent periodic alimony instead of rehabilitative alimony.
III.  Attorneyâ€™s Fees
Wife
  argues the family court erred in awarding her an insufficient amount of
  attorneyâ€™s fees and costs.Â  We agree.Â   
In a
  family court matter, â€œ[t]he award of attorneyâ€™s fees . . . will only be
  disturbed upon a showing of abuse of discretion.â€Â  Upchurch v. Upchurch,
  367 S.C. 16, 28, 624 S.E.2d 643, 648 (2006).Â  â€œA decision lacking a discernible
  reason is arbitrary and constitutes an abuse of discretion.â€Â  Johnson,
  296 S.C. at 304, 372 S.E.2d at 115.Â   
The
  family court has jurisdiction to award reasonable attorneyâ€™s fees where a claim
  for attorneyâ€™s fees is well-founded.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 20-3-120 through -140,
  Â§ 20-7-420(38) (Supp. 2007).Â  The decision whether to award attorneyâ€™s fees is
  within the discretion of the family court.Â  Upchurch, 367 S.C. at 28,
  624 S.E.2d at 648. Â In determining whether to award attorneyâ€™s fees, the family
  court should consider each partyâ€™s ability to pay his or her own fees, the
  beneficial results obtained, the partiesâ€™ respective financial conditions, and
  the effect of the fee on the partiesâ€™ standards of living. Â E.D.M. v. T.A.M.,
  307 S.C. 471, 476-77, 415 S.E.2d 812, 816 (1992).Â  The reasonableness of an
  attorneyâ€™s fee lies in â€œ(1) the nature, extent, and difficulty of the case; (2)
  the time necessarily devoted to the case; (3) professional standing of counsel;
  (4) contingency of compensation; (5) beneficial results obtained; and (6)
  customary legal fees for similar services.â€Â  Glasscock v. Glasscock, 304
  S.C. 158, 161, 403 S.E.2d 313, 315 (1991).Â  Other factors to consider in
  awarding attorneyâ€™s fees are â€œthe abilities of the parties to pay, their
  respective financial conditions and the effect of the attorneyâ€™s fees on each
  partyâ€™s standard of living.â€Â  Mitchell v. Mitchell, 283 S.C. 87, 93, 320
  S.E.2d 706, 710 (1984).Â  The factors enunciated by the court, and not the
  amount of any other monies awarded in the suit, determine the appropriate
  amount of an award of attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Williamson v. Middleton, 374
  S.C. 419, 431, 649 S.E.2d 57, 64 (Ct. App. 2007).
We
  find Wife is entitled to attorneyâ€™s fees pursuant to the factors of E.D.M.Â 
  The family court found Wife had incurred a total of $68,103.46 in attorneyâ€™s
  fees and costs, and Husband had incurred $14,853.25 in fees and costs.Â  The
  family court then required Husband to pay $7,500.00 to one of Wifeâ€™s attorneys,
  presumably in addition to the $5,000.00 previously ordered.Â  Although it
  recognized Husbandâ€™s uncooperative behavior during discovery increased the
  difficulty of Wifeâ€™s case, the family court failed to set forth sufficiently
  specific findings to illuminate a discernible reason for requiring Husband to
  pay such a small portion of Wifeâ€™s bill.Â  We are unable to determine why the
  family court awarded Wife only $12,500.00 when her total attorneyâ€™s fees and
  costs exceeded Husbandâ€™s by $53,250.21.Â  We are concerned the order in this
  matter failed to address the impact of this award on either party.Â 
  Accordingly, we find the family court erred in failing to support its award
  with specific findings that suggest a discernible reason.Â   
The
  family court did not err in refusing to require Husband to pay all of Wifeâ€™s
  attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Although Wife argues she should receive full fees, the cases
  to which she cites are distinguishable from the one at bar.Â  In Johnson,
  a mentally and physically abusive husband filed suit to enforce an invalid
  antenuptial agreement.Â  296 S.C. at 292, 372 S.E.2d at 109.Â  Furthermore, he
  refused to answer discovery, filed a grossly misleading financial declaration,
  and contested every issue.Â  Id. at 303-04, 372 S.E.2d at 115.Â  In Taylor v. Taylor, a husband sued his former wife three different times, she
  prevailed each time, and he appealed, only to dismiss his appeal later.Â  333
  S.C. 209, 220, 508 S.E.2d 50, 56 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  Unlike his former wife, the
  husband was able to afford lengthy lawsuits and intentionally prolonged and
  complicated each suit.Â  Id., 508 S.E.2d at 56.Â   
In
  the case at bar, only one lawsuit exists between the parties.Â  Wife filed for separate
  maintenance, and both parties requested and received a divorce on the ground of
  one yearâ€™s continuous separation, the so-called â€œno-faultâ€ ground.Â  The family
  court found it â€œdifficult to determine what actually caused the dissolution of
  the marriage.â€Â  Unlike the hapless wives in Johnson and Taylor,
  Wife initiated this suit, through which both parties obtained relief.Â 
  Therefore, an award of full fees to Wife would be inappropriate.Â Â   
Consequently,
  we remand the issue of attorneyâ€™s fees to the family court for an order incorporating specific findings as to the factors expressed in E.D.M., Glasscock,
  and Mitchell and awarding appropriate relief.Â   
CONCLUSION
As
  to the issue of Wifeâ€™s special equity interest in the increased value of
  Husbandâ€™s businesses, we find Wife failed to establish a causal connection
  between her actions and any increase in the value of Husbandâ€™sÂ  businesses.Â 
  Therefore, we affirm the family courtâ€™s denial of a special equity interest in
  the increased value of those businesses.
As
  to the issue of spousal support, we find the family court erred in awarding
  Wife one year of rehabilitative alimony without a showing of special
  circumstances meriting this award.Â  Neither party appealed the family courtâ€™s
  finding that Wife is entitled to alimony.Â  Therefore, we find Wife is entitled
  to permanent periodic alimony, unless a showing is made of special
  circumstances justifying rehabilitative alimony.Â  Accordingly, we remand this
  issue to the family court for further proceedings in accordance with this
  opinion.Â Â Â   
Finally,
  as to the issue of attorneyâ€™s fees, we find the family court erred in failing
  to support its award with sufficiently specific findings to explain its
  decision.Â  We also find Wife was not entitled to an award of full attorneyâ€™s
  fees.Â  Therefore, we remand the issue of
  attorneyâ€™s fees to the family court for
  an order incorporating specific findings in accordance with this opinion and awarding appropriate relief.Â  
 
Accordingly,
  the order of the family court is  
AFFIRMED
  IN PART AND REMANDED.Â   
ANDERSON, SHORT,
  and THOMAS JJ., concur.


[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] From 1998 to 2002, the approximate term of the
  marriage, the funeral homeâ€™s gross sales increased from about $380,000 to about
  $624,000, an increase of about $244,000.Â  During that same time
  period, the cemeteryâ€™s gross sales increased from $36,942 to about $135,000, an
  increase of about $98,058.
[3] One
  separation occurred when Wife insisted Husband leave the house because he had
  been drinking.Â

Appeal From Charleston County

Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-199
Heard February 5, 2008 â€“ Filed March 20,
  2008
REVERSED


	
		
			
				Kirsten Leslie Barr, of Mount Pleasant, for Appellant.
				John S. Nichols, of Columbia and Matt Jackson, of North Charleston, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  WorkForce
  appeals the circuit courtâ€™s decision affirming the Appellate Panel of the
  Workersâ€™ Compensation Commissionâ€™s order awarding benefits to Lawrence
  Brayboy.Â  We reverse.
FACTS
In 1970, Brayboy joined the Navy and
  worked as a deck hand.Â  While onboard a naval ship, Brayboy fell, slid on the
  deck, and hit a rail.Â  Following the fall, Brayboyâ€™s back was sore for a few
  weeks.Â  Doctors took an x-ray and prescribed acetaminophen.Â  Brayboy received
  no other treatment.Â  Subsequently, Navy doctors diagnosed Brayboy as having a
  missing piece of bone, which Brayboy described as a birth deformity.Â  As a
  result of this accident, Brayboy received approximately $85 a month in benefits
  for thirty years to date.
In 1996, Brayboy was involved in a work-related accident while
  employed by McCrory Construction (McCrory).Â  While Brayboy was in a thirty to
  forty foot hole, the sides collapsed.Â  As a result of this accident, Brayboy
  injured his middle to lower back and right ankle.Â  Â After filing a claim for
  benefits under the South Carolina Workerâ€™s Compensation Act (the Act), Brayboy received
  approximately $8,500 to $8,700 as a settlement.Â  Further, Brayboy received a
  five percent impairment rating for both his back and his ankle.Â  Brayboy
  testified his claim with McCrory was the only workersâ€™ compensation claim he
  had ever filed.
Following his employment with the Navy and McCrory, WorkForce
  hired Brayboy.Â  As part of the pre-employment process, WorkForce required
  Brayboy to fill out an application.Â  In the application, Brayboy answered questions
  regarding his medical history, whether he previously filed for workersâ€™
  compensation claims, and whether he had any current disabilities.Â  In answering
  these questions, Brayboy represented he had never been treated for any disease
  or condition. Â During the application process, Brayboy also signed the
  following statement:

	If I do not give accurate and truthful information in this
  Medical History Questionnaire, which forms the second and final part of my
  employment agreement, the entire employment shall be considered null and void. 
	
	MISREPRESENTATIONS AS TO PREEXISTING PHYSICAL OR MENTAL
  CONDITIONS MAY CAUSE FORFEITURE OF YOUR WORKERSâ€™ COMPENSATION BENEFITS.

On April 18, 2003, while at work, Brayboy was injured while pulling
  up a chain-link fence. Â Brayboy believed he had pulled a major muscle in his
  lower back.Â  After informing his supervisor, Brayboy sought medical treatment.Â 
  As a result of this accident, Brayboy has impaired mobility and walks with a
  crutch.Â  He experiences pain in his legs and lower back, and he takes medication
  for the pain.
Brayboy notified his employer and timely filed a workersâ€™
  compensation claim.Â  Brayboyâ€™s misrepresentations in his job application became
  the basis for WorkForceâ€™s denial of his entitlement to compensation.Â 
  Specifically, WorkForce argued Brayboyâ€™s misleading answers in its pre-employment
  questionnaire vitiated the partiesâ€™ employment relationship and
  precluded Brayboy from receiving benefits under the Act.Â  The single commissioner
  presided over a hearing and concluded Brayboy was a WorkForce employee when he
  sustained his back injury.Â  WorkForce appealed the single commissionerâ€™s
  findings to the Appellate Panel which affirmed the order of the single commissioner.Â Â 
  Thereafter, WorkForce appealed the order of the Appellate Panel to the circuit
  court, which affirmed the Appellate Panelâ€™s order.Â  This appeal followed.Â 
 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œThe
  employee relationship is a jurisdictional issue for the purposes of workersâ€™
  compensation benefits and thus, our review is governed by the preponderance of
  the evidence standard.â€Â  Vines v. Champion Bldg. Products, 315 S.C. 13,
  16, 431 S.E.2d 585, 586 (1993).
LAW/ANALYSIS
The
  sole issue presented on appeal is whether the circuit court erred as a matter
  of law in summarily concluding Brayboy was a WorkForce employee. For the
  reasons set forth below, we find Brayboyâ€™s misrepresentations vitiated the partiesâ€™ employment relationship and precluded Brayboy from
  receiving benefits under the Act.Â  Accordingly,
  we reverse.
In Cooper v. McDevitt
  & Street Co., 260 S.C. 463, 468,
  196 S.E.2d 833, 835 (1973), the Supreme Court of South Carolina adopted a three-part
  test for determining when a
  false statement in an employment application will bar benefits. Â This test, as explained in Givens v. Steel Structures, Inc., provides the employment relationship will:

	be vitiated where false statements were made on a job application
  in the presence of three factors: (1) knowing and wilful nature of the false
  representation as to physical condition;
  (2) reliance by the employer upon the false representation as a substantial
  factor in the hiring; (3) causal connection between the false
  representation and the injury.Â  

279
  S.C. 12, 13-14, 301 S.E.2d 545, 546-7 (1983).Â  We note the test in Cooper is an â€œandâ€ test, meaning an employer must prove all three of its factors
  before an employee is barred from receiving workersâ€™ compensation benefits.Â 
  Therefore, if an employer fails to prove any of these factors, a claimant will
  still be considered an employee under the Act. Â See Vines, 315
  S.C. at 16, 431 S.E.2d at 586 (â€œAll factors must be present for the employer to
  avoid paying benefits.â€).Â   
1)  Knowing and Willful False Representation
    of a Physical Condition
Under the first
  prong of Cooper, not only must an employee have made a misrepresentation
  of a physical condition on an employment application, this falsity must be
  known and the misrepresentation must have been willfully made.Â   
Undoubtedly, Brayboy
  made numerous misrepresentations on his employment application.Â  Specifically,
  Brayboy checked â€œnoâ€ in the section of the application questioning whether he
  had ever been treated for foot injuries, spinal injuries, or backaches.Â 
  Additionally, Brayboy indicated he had not experienced â€œ[o]ne or more back
  injuries or a disease process of the back resulting in a disability.â€Â  Brayboy
  also denied ever filing a workersâ€™ compensation claim.Â  However, the record
  shows Brayboy had experienced an injury while working for the Navy, for which
  he has received thirty years of benefits.Â  Brayboy was also involved in a
  work-related accident while employed with McCrory.Â  As a result of this
  accident, he sought recovery under the Act and received a settlement of approximately $8,500 to $8,700 and a five percent impairment
  rating for both his back and his ankle.Â   
Given the record
  before us, we are convinced that Brayboy knew the falsity of his statements and
  willfully made the misrepresentations. Â Â 
2.  Employerâ€™s Reliance Upon the False Representation as a
  Substantial Factor in Hiring
Under
  the second prong of Cooper, WorkForce bears the burden of proving it
  relied on Brayboyâ€™s misrepresentations in its decision to hire him.Â  Â Â 
Brian Ingles, a
  sales manager for WorkForce, testified WorkForce requires new applicants to
  fill out employment and medical history questionnaires to protect the applicant
  and the company.Â  Ingles stated WorkForce tries not to put workers in
  potentially harmful situations by carefully taking into consideration an applicantâ€™s
  previous injuries.Â Â  Additionally, Ingles claimed information provided by an
  applicant regarding a previous injury would be a substantial factor in the
  hiring process.Â  Ingles also testified Brayboy was hired as a trim carpenter,
  and â€œthe job he was hired on really [wasnâ€™t] that physically demanding in
  nature.â€Â  Finally, Ingles admitted there was a possibility Brayboy would have
  been eligible to work as a trim carpenter had he honestly filled out the employment
  application.Â   
Christopher Lee,
  a previous WorkForce employee, testified he had reviewed Brayboyâ€™s employment
  application and medical history questionnaire.Â  Lee stated he had relied upon
  Brayboyâ€™s statements in deciding to hire Brayboy and claimed the
  representations were a substantial factor in his hiring decision.Â  Lee
  testified WorkForce uses the questionnaires: â€œTo protect us as employers and to
  protect the person going to work, both, so that we know what a person is
  capable of doing, so we donâ€™t put them into a situation where they could hurt
  themselves.â€Â Â  Â Lee also stated he would have taken into account Brayboyâ€™s
  prior injuries in determining what type of work to give Brayboy.Â  When asked
  whether knowledge of Brayboyâ€™s previous injuries would have prevented him from
  hiring Brayboy, Lee stated: â€œIt wouldnâ€™t prevent me from hiring him.Â  It would
  just lead to further analysis or lead to possibly finding something that was
  more suited to his capabilities.â€Â   
Given the
  testimony of these two witnesses, we are convinced that, although it may have
  still hired Brayboy even if it knew of his previous injuries, Workforce relied
  on his false representations in assigning his job duties. Therefore, the second
  prong of Cooper is satisfied.Â  SeeÂ  Jones v. Georgia-Pacific
    Corp., 355 S.C. 413, 418-19, 586 S.E.2d 111,114 (2003) (holding the
  second prong of Cooper was satisfied where â€œRespondentâ€™s Human Resource Managerâ€¦
  testified that the fact that Claimant had prior physical ailments would not
  have barred her from working for Respondent. Rather, Respondent would have attempted to find a job for Claimant that would not subject a pre-existing physical
  impairment to further deterioration.â€).Â   
3.  Causal Connection Between the False Representation and the Injury
Under the third
  prong of Cooper, WorkForce must prove a causal connection existed between
  Brayboyâ€™s false representations and the injury sustained.  
WorkForce
  argues the issue of a causal connection is undisputed because the Appellate
  Panel found, â€œ[Brayboy] had a longstanding lower back pain, which was exacerbated
  after his injury.â€ Â However, the employee relationship is a jurisdictional issue.Â 
  Accordingly, we must conduct our own review of the record.  
Brayboy
  sought and received an increase in his Department of Veterans Affairs
  impairment rating from twenty percent to forty percent due to â€œan injury on
  April 18, 2003 that further aggravated [his] serviceâ€ injury.Â  Furthermore,
  Brayboyâ€™s patientâ€™s progress notes from the Department of Veterans Affairs state
  that he suffered from â€œlongstandingâ€ lower back pain which was â€œexacerbated
  after an injury.â€Â  Given this evidence, we find a causal connection has been
  established, satisfying the third prong of Cooper. Â See Givens
    v. Steel Structures, Inc., 279 S.C. 12, 14, 301 S.E.2d 545, 547 (1983)
  (â€œExpert medical testimony clearly indicated that claimantâ€™s condition was oneâ€¦
  reflecting the cumulative effect of successive injuries. The only reasonable
  inference to be drawn from th[e] record was that a causal connection had been
  established sufficient for the purposes of Cooper.â€).
CONCLUSION
For the foregoing
  reasons, we find WorkForce has proven all three prongs of the Cooper test.Â  Accordingly, the order of the trial court is 
 
REVERSED.
ANDERSON, SHORT,
  and WILLIAMS JJ., concur.
