title: MBNA v. Baumie
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT
  BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE
  239(d)(2), SCACR.

	
		
			
				THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
				In The Court of Appeals
				MBNA America
      Bank, N.A., Respondent,
				v.
				Joseph E.
      Baumie, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Spartanburg County
Â J. Derham Cole, Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-205
Submitted March 4, 2008 â€“ Filed March 25,
  2008
REVERSED


	
		
			
				Joseph E. Baumie, of Inman, for Appellant.
				Eric C. Hale and Roy W. Boggs, of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  A
  credit card holder, Joseph E. Baumie, argues the circuit court erred in
  confirming an arbitration award issued by the National Arbitration Forum in
  favor of MBNA America Bank, N.A., the issuer of Baumieâ€™s credit card. 
  Specifically, Baumie argues MBNA failed to produce evidence of an arbitration
  agreement between the parties.  We reverse.[1]
FACTS
MBNA filed an arbitration claim against
  Baumie in the National Arbitration Forum (Forum) alleging it had issued Baumie a
  credit card and he subsequently defaulted on their agreement.Â  Baumie contested
  arbitration several times in writing to the Forum, asserting he never agreed to
  arbitrate.Â  Despite Baumieâ€™s assertions, the Forum went forward with the
  arbitration and determined the parties entered into an arbitration agreement. Â The
  Forum found in favor of MBNA in the amount of $11,241.84.Â   
MBNA filed a complaint in circuit court
  seeking confirmation of the arbitration award.Â  Baumie answered and filed a counterclaim
  and a motion to dismiss.Â  MBNA filed a motion to confirm the arbitration
  award, and Baumie filed a motion opposing the confirmation.Â  Following a
  hearing, the circuit court took the matter under advisement, and subsequently
  issued an order confirming the award and entering judgment against Baumie in
  the amount of $11,241.84.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Unless the parties otherwise provide, the question of
  the arbitrability of a claim is an issue for judicial determination. Â Zabinski
    v. Bright Acres Assocs., 346 S.C. 580, 596, 553 S.E.2d 110, 118 (2001). Â Determinations
  of arbitrability are subject to de novo review, but if any evidence reasonably
  supports the circuit courtâ€™s factual findings, this court will not overrule
  those findings.Â  Stokes v. Metropolitan Life Ins. Co., 351 S.C. 606, 609-10,
  571 S.E.2d 711, 713 (Ct. App. 2002).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Baumie
  argues the circuit court erred by confirming the arbitration award because MBNA
  had not produced sufficient evidence of an arbitration agreement.Â  We agree.Â 
 
The Federal
  Arbitration Act requires courts to enforce privately negotiated arbitration
  agreements according to their terms.Â  Zabinski v. Bright Acres Assocs., 346
  S.C. 580, 592, 553 S.E.2d 110, 116 (2001).Â  However, â€œarbitration is a matter of contract, and a
  party cannot be required to arbitrate any dispute which he has not agreed to
  arbitrate.â€ Chassereau v. Global Sun Pools, Inc., 373 S.C. 168, 171-2,
  644 S.E.2d 718, 720 (2007) (citing Zabinski at 596, 553 S.E.2d at
  118).Â   
If a
  party challenges the enforcement of an arbitration award on the grounds that
  there was not an arbitration agreement between the parties, it naturally
  follows the court must first ascertain whether the agreement actually existed.Â 
  The party seeking enforcement of the award, then, must present evidence of the
  agreement itself because â€œ[t]he burden is on a party pleading a fact to prove
  it.â€Â  Jackson v. Frier, 146 S.C. 322, 144 S.E. 66,
  68, (1928); Hammond v. Halsey, 287 S.C. 46, 49, 336 S.E.2d 495,
  497 (Ct. App. 1985).
In the instant
  case, the only evidence of the arbitration agreement provided by MBNA was a photocopy
  of a seven-page pamphlet entitled â€œCredit Card Agreement Additional Terms and
  Conditions,â€ outlining the terms and conditions of an agreement.Â  However, MBNA
  offers no evidence to authenticate the pamphlet or show it was in fact sent to Baumie.Â  Furthermore, while the pamphlet explains the terms of an arbitration
  agreement, its language merely refers to some other agreement.Â  Outside of the
  pamphlet, MBNA did not provide any evidence whatsoever of any actual agreement
  between itself and Baumie, nor did it produce any evidence that Baumie in fact
  agreed to arbitration.Â  Accordingly, because MBNA failed to produce any
  evidence of an actual arbitration agreement between the parties, the circuit
  court erred in confirming the arbitration award.
We
  note several other jurisdictions[2] have arrived at similar decisions regarding whether consumers agreed to
  arbitration with MBNA. See, e.g., MBNA Am. Bank, N.A. v. Boata,
  893 A.2d 479 (Conn. App. 2006); MBNA Am. Bank, N.A. v. Rogers, 838
  N.E.2d 475 (Ind. App. 2005); MBNA Am. Bank, N.A. v. Hart, 710 N.W.2d 125
  (N.D. 2006); MBNA Am. Bank, N.A. v. Terry, 2006 WL 513952 (Ohio Ct. App.
  2006); MBNA Am. Bank, N.A. v. Berlin, 2005 WL 3193850 (Ohio Ct. App.
  2005); MBNA Am. Bank, N.A. v. Perese, 2006 WL 398188 (Texas App. 2006).Â 
  In a similar case involving MBNA, the Kansas Supreme Court addressed this very
  issue and found:

	MBNA
  failed to attach a copy of the arbitration agreement to its motion to confirm
  the award. Â This violated the Federal Arbitration Act for which MBNA
  intermittently expresses respect. . . . This alone would have justified the district
  court in its decision to deny MBNAâ€™s motion to confirm the award.Â  

MBNA Am. Bank, N.A. v.
  Credit, 132 P.3d 898, 901 (Kan. 2006) (citing 9 U.S.C.
  Â§ 13 (2000)).Â  According to 9 U.S.C.A. Â§ 13 (2000):

	The
  party moving for an order confirming, modifying, or correcting an award shall,
  at the time such order is filed with the clerk for the entry of judgment
  thereon, also file the following papers with the clerk: (a) The agreement; the selection or
  appointment, if any, of an additional arbitrator or umpire; and each written
  extension of the time, if any, within which to make the award.

While the language of the
  statute requires the clerk to file the agreement with the judgment and does not
  address the documents to be filed when commencing an action to confirm the award,
  it does not relieve MBNA of the burden of showing an agreement to arbitrate existed.Â 
  As stated by the Kansas Supreme Court, â€œ[g]iven MBNAâ€™s casual approach to this
  litigation, we are not surprised that [a national trend in which consumers are
  questioning MBNA and whether arbitration agreements exist] may be growing.â€Â  Credit,
  132 P.3d at 902.
CONCLUSION
Because MBNA failed
  to produce evidence showing an arbitration agreement between itself and Baumie,
  the circuit court erred in confirming the arbitration award.Â  Accordingly, the
  order of the circuit court is  
REVERSED.
ANDERSON, SHORT, and THOMAS, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] This court has also recently addressed this issue in MBNA Am. Bank, N.A. v. Christianson, Op. No. 4349 (S.C. Ct. App. Filed March 4, 2008)
  (Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 10 at 74).

title: Pools Plus v. Timmons
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO
  PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Pools Plus,
      Inc., Respondent,
				v.
				Angela Timmons, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Sumter County
Howard P. King, Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-206
Submitted March 4, 2008 â€“ Filed March 25,
  2008Â Â Â  
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				John E. Miles, of Sumter, John S. Nichols, of Columbia, for
  Appellant.
				Michael M. Jordan, of Sumter, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  This
  case arises from a contract between Pools Plus, Inc. and Angela Timmons for
  Pools Plus to construct an in-ground swimming pool on Timmonsâ€™s property. Â Timmons
  withheld partial payment after determining the pool was unsatisfactory.Â 
  Timmons appeals the trial courtâ€™s introduction of the contract into evidence
  and the award of prejudgment interest to Pools Plus.Â  We affirm.[1]
1.  Timmons
  contracted with Pools Plus to install an in-ground swimming pool on her
  property.Â  Upon completion of the pool,
  Timmons was dissatisfied, claiming the pool leaked, filled with dirt during
  heavy rain, and had other malfunctions.Â  Timmons refused to pay the
  approximately $8800 remaining due on the contract.Â  Pools Plus filed a lawsuit
  seeking to recover the money owed.Â  At trial, Pools Plus offered into evidence
  a contract detailing the agreement between the parties.Â  The contract was only
  signed by an employee of Pools Plus.Â  The trial court admitted the contract
  over the objection of Timmons, who argued the contract could not represent the
  agreement as it lacked Timmonsâ€™s signature.Â  The jury found for Pools Plus and
  awarded them $8801.60.
Timmons now argues the trial court erred in failing to grant a new
  trial after erroneously admitting the contract into evidence.Â  â€œThe admission of evidence is a matter left to the
  discretion of the trial judge and, absent clear abuse, will not be disturbed on
  appeal.â€Â  Carlyle v. Tuomey Hosp., 305 S.C. 187, 193, 407 S.E.2d 630,
  633 (1991).Â  Likewise, the grant or denial of a new
  trial motion falls within the trial courtâ€™s discretion, and the trial courtâ€™s
  decision will only be disturbed on appeal if it is controlled by an error of
  law or wholly unsupported by the evidence.Â  Sabb v. South Carolina
    State Univ., 350 S.C. 416, 427, 567 S.E.2d 231, 236 (2002).
Under
  the facts of this case, the trial court did not abuse its discretion in
  admitting the contract, even though the contract lacked Timmonsâ€™s signature.Â 
  Our courts have held that â€œ[a] contract does not always require the signature
  of both parties; it may be sufficient, if signed by one and accepted and acted
  on by the other.â€Â  Jaffe v. Gibbons, 290 S.C. 468, 473, 351 S.E.2d 343,
  346 (Ct. App. 1986); see also Peddler, Inc. v. Rikard, 266
  S.C. 28, 32, 221 S.E.2d 115, 117 (1975).
In
  her answer, Timmons admitted to entering into a contract with Pools Plus.Â  At
  trial, Timmons acknowledged the contract offered into evidence, even though
  unsigned by her, accurately reflected the basic terms of the contract.Â  Further,
  Timmons stated she owed about $8800 on the pool.Â  Therefore, the trial court
  did not abuse its discretion as evidence existed supporting the contractâ€™s
  admission and no error of law was made.Â  Accordingly, a new trial was not
  warranted.
2.  Timmons additionally
  disputes the trial courtâ€™s award of prejudgment interest.Â  Prejudgment interest
  is appropriate â€œon obligations to pay money from the
  time when, either by agreement of the parties or operation of law, the payment
  is demandable, if the sum is certain or capable of being reduced to certainty.â€Â  Butler Contracting, Inc. v. Court Street, LLC, 369 S.C. 121,
  133, 631 S.E.2d 252, 258 (2006).Â  â€œThe right of a
  party to prejudgment interest is not affected by rights of
  discount or offset claimed by the opposing party. Â It is the character of the
  claim and not the defense to it that determines whether prejudgment interest is
  allowable.â€Â  Id. at 133-34, 631 S.E.2d at 259.
At
  trial, Timmons stated, â€œI still owe the $8800.â€Â  She additionally said, â€œI
  refused to pay the portion that was due until the pool was satisfactory.â€Â  Timmons
  simply refused to pay as she was dissatisfied with her pool; however, Timmonsâ€™s
  disappointment does not shield her from prejudgment interest.Â  Here, the amount
  owed was in fact reduced to
  certainty for Timmons acknowledged her remaining obligation.Â  Consequently, the
  amount awarded to her was properly subject to prejudgment interest.  
Accordingly,
  the judgment of the trial court is  
AFFIRMED.
HUFF, KITTREDGE, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1]  We decide this case without oral
  argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: Horton v. Pyramid Masonry Contractors
text:
THIS OPINION
  HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN
  ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Joey D. Horton, Respondent
				v.
				Pyramid Masonry
      Contractors, Inc. and Hartford Accident Insurance Company, Appellants.
			
		
	


Appeal From Fairfield County
Â Kenneth G. Goode, Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2008-UP-208
Submitted February 1, 2008 â€“ Filed March
  27, 2008
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Richard B. Kale, Jr. and L. Brenn Watson, both of Greenville, for Appellants.
				Barry B. George, of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  Pyramid
  Masonry Contractors, Inc. and Hartford Accident Insurance Company (collectively,
  Employer) appeal the circuit courtâ€™s finding that Joey D. Horton (Employee) is
  entitled to recover workersâ€™ compensation benefits for injuries he sustained during
  a motor vehicle accident that occurred while he traveled from his home in
  Lancaster to Employerâ€™s job site in Columbia. Â We affirm.[1]
FACTS
On
  January 7, 2004, Employer hired Mark Hinson (Foreman) to supervise masons and
  laborers on construction sites.Â  Employer paid Foreman $23 per hour for the hours
  he worked on the job site.Â  Employer also paid Foreman a â€œtruck allowanceâ€ of
  $150 per month.[2]Â 
  Employer authorized Foreman to hire brick masons and laborers to work on the
  job sites he supervised.Â  A few weeks later, Foreman went to Employeeâ€™s home and
  offered him a job with Employer.Â  Employee accepted a masonâ€™s job paying $18
  per hour.[3]
After
  Employee started working for Employer, Foreman and Employee always traveled together
  in Foremanâ€™s personal vehicle to and from their homes in Lancaster to job sites
  in Charlotte and Columbia.Â  Employee testified he worked for Employer only on
  the days he rode to job sites with Foreman.Â  In November 2004, upon Employeeâ€™s
  recommendation, Foreman hired another Lancaster man, James Clark, to work as a
  laborer for Employer. Â Clark testified he also worked for Employer only on days
  he rode to Employerâ€™s job sites with Foreman.Â   
On the
  morning of November 17, 2004, Employee, Clark, and Foreman were traveling in
  Foremanâ€™s vehicle from Lancaster to a job site in Columbia. Â While driving on
  Interstate 77 in Fairfield County, Foremanâ€™s car slammed into the rear of a
  vehicle moving approximately twenty-five miles per hour.Â  The impact threw Employee
  from the car; a helicopter transported him to Richland Memorial Hospital where he recovered until his release on December 10, 2004.[4]Â 
  As a result of the accident, Employee sustained injuries to his head, back,
  heart, spleen, pelvis, left leg, left hip, appendix, and teeth.Â  Employee now
  walks with a cane and is under the continuing care of a physician for injuries sustained
  in the accident, including headaches, seizures, and an inability to control his
  left foot.Â  Employee has not worked since the accident, and his physician
  indicates Employeeâ€™s physical limitations will prevent him from working as a
  brick mason in the future.Â   
PROCEDURAL HISTORY
In
  May 2005, Employee filed a Form 50 claiming entitlement to workersâ€™ compensation
  benefits for injuries he sustained in the November 17, 2004 accident.Â  Employee
  alleges his injuries are compensable because he â€œwas performing services
  arising out of and in the course of employment at the time of the accident.â€Â 
  Employer filed a Form 51 denying Employeeâ€™s injuries were compensable. Â 
On
  September 8, 2005, a single commissioner conducted a hearing.Â  The commissioner
  found â€œ[t]he provision of transportation to and from work was not [E]mployerâ€™s
  normal company policy and testimony from [Employerâ€™s] witnesses was that
  [Foreman] acted outside of general company policy in this regard.â€Â  However, the
  commissioner ultimately determined:  

	The
  greater weight of evidence supports that, as a condition of [Employeeâ€™s]
  employment, [Foreman] provided transportation to and from work. . . .Â  [T]hrough
  course of conduct and other evidence [Foreman] had actual authority to, and
  did[,] negotiate these transportation terms as a condition of [Employeeâ€™s]
  employment binding [Employer] to the terms of the contract with [Employee]. Evidence
  of this arrangement was proven by [Employeeâ€™s] testimony that [Foreman] showed
  him checks from [Employer] for transporting him. I base this finding on the
  testimony of [Employee], James Clark, and Laura Noah [Employeeâ€™s mother].

Additionally,
  the commissioner concluded Employeeâ€™s injuries were compensable because he had
  â€œproven an exception to the â€˜going and coming ruleâ€™ discussed in Byrd v.
    Stackhouse Sheet Metal Works, 317 S.C. 35, 451 S.E.2d 405 (Ct. App. 1994)
  since his employer provided transportation to and from job sites and said
  transportation was a condition of [Employeeâ€™s] employment.â€Â  The commissioner
  ordered Employer to pay Employee temporary total benefits and all of his causally-related medical
  expenses.Â   
Following a review hearing on June 28, 2006, the Commissionâ€™s
  Appellate Panel (Panel) determined the commissionerâ€™s findings of fact and
  rulings of law were correct and incorporated them by reference into the Panelâ€™s
  ruling affirming the commissionerâ€™s order in its entirety.[5]Â  The Panel noted as â€œadditional
  reasoning for the Hearing Commissionerâ€™s decisionâ€ that the Dead Manâ€™s Statute
  did not apply because Employeeâ€™s witnesses were not testifying against a
  survivor of the now-deceased Foreman.Â  The Panel also (1) ruled Foreman had
  â€œeither actual authority or apparent authority to both hire [Employee] and
  provide transportationâ€ and (2) overruled Employerâ€™s hearsay objections under
  Rule 801(d)(2) of the South Carolina Rules of Evidence.  
Following a hearing on January 4, 2007, the circuit court,
  applying the substantial evidence standard of review, found the Panel did not
  err in finding Employeeâ€™s case fell within an exception to the going and coming
  rule because testimony in the record could â€œreasonably be viewed as
  establishing [Employee] had been hired by a supervisor [Hinson] who was driving
  the automobile in which [Employee] was injured at the time of the accident when
  [Foreman] had actual and/or apparent authority to hire [Employee] and negotiate
  the terms of his employment, including the provision of transportation to and
  from the job site, especially in light of the fact that [Employee] did not have
  a driverâ€™s license.â€Â  Additionally, the circuit court affirmed the Panelâ€™s
  conclusion that testimony regarding Foremanâ€™s statements to Employee was properly
  admitted because the statements were neither hearsay nor barred by the Dead
  Manâ€™s Statute.Â  The circuit court affirmed the Panelâ€™s order in its entirety.Â 
  This appeal followed.  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The
  Administrative Procedures Act governs judicial review of all non-jurisdictional
  decisions of the workersâ€™ compensation commission. Â Gray v. Club Group, Ltd.,
  339 S.C. 173, 182, 528 S.E.2d 435, 440 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  â€œThe [reviewing] court
  may not substitute its judgment for the judgment of the agency as to the weight
  of the evidence on questions of fact.Â  The court may affirm the decision of the
  agency or remand the case for further proceedings.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  1-23-380(A)(5) (Supp. 2006).Â  However, the reviewing court

	may
  reverse or modify the decision if substantial rights of the appellant have been
  prejudiced because the administrative findings, inferences, conclusions, or
  decisions are: (a) in violation of constitutional or statutory provisions; (b)
  in excess of the statutory authority of the agency; (c) made upon unlawful
  procedure; (d) affected by other error of law; (e) clearly erroneous in view of
  the reliable, probative, and substantial evidence on the whole record, or (f)
  arbitrary or capricious or characterized by abuse of discretion or clearly
  unwarranted exercise of discretion. 

Id.Â  This court will set aside a decision by the workersâ€™
  compensation commission only where the determination is unsupported by â€œsubstantial
  evidence.â€ Â Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 276 S.C. 130, 276 S.E.2d 304 (1981). Â Substantial
  evidence is evidence that, considering the record as a whole, would allow
  reasonable minds to reach the conclusion reached by the Appellate Panel.Â  Rodney
    v. Michelin Tire Corp., 320 S.C. 515, 466 S.E.2d 357 (1996).Â  The
  possibility of drawing two inconsistent conclusions from the evidence does not
  mean the agencyâ€™s conclusion is unsupported by substantial evidence.Â  Ellis
    v. Spartan Mills, 276 S.C. 216, 277 S.E.2d 590 (1981).Â   
â€œConversely,
  where the [Panelâ€™s] s decision is controlled by an error of law, this courtâ€™s
  review is plenary.â€Â  Lizee v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Mental Health, 367 S.C. 122,
  126, 623 S.E.2d 860, 862 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  An appellate court may reverse the Panel
  when its decision is affected by an error of law.Â  Callahan v. Beaufort County Sch. Dist., 375 S.C. 92, 651 S.E.2d 311 (2007).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.  Actual or Apparent Authority 
Employer
  argues Employeeâ€™s injuries are not compensable because Employer did not
  authorize Foreman to offer Employee transportation to and from work.Â  We
  disagree.
An
  employee may recover workersâ€™ compensation benefits for injuries sustained by an
  accident â€œarising out of and in the course of employment.â€ Â S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  42-1-160 (Supp. 2006).Â  Generally, injuries an employee sustains while traveling
  to and from the workplace are not compensable.Â Eadie
    v. H.A. Sack Co., 322 S.C. 164, 168, 470 S.E.2d 397, 399 (Ct. App. 1996); see
      also Gray v. Club Group, Ltd., 339 S.C. 173, 188, 528 S.E.2d 435,
  443 (Ct. App. 2000) (â€œAs a general rule, an employee going to or coming from the place
  where his work is to be performed is not engaged in performing any service
  growing out of and incidental to his employment, and, therefore, an injury
  sustained by accident at such time does not arise out of and in the course of
  his employment.â€). Â Â 
South
  Carolina recognizes five exceptions to the going and coming rule: 1)
  the employer provides the means of transportation or pays travel time; 2) the
  employee performs duties during his commute; 3) the route used is inherently
  dangerous; 4) the place where the injury occurs is in such close proximity to
  the workplace that it is brought within the scope of employment; and 5) the
  injury occurs while the employee is on a special errand for the employer.Â  Eadie,
  322 S.C. at 168-69, 470 S.E.2d at 400.Â   
Here,
  Employeeâ€™s injuries are compensable, under an exception to the going and coming
  rule, only if substantial evidence supports the Panelâ€™s finding that Employer
  either (1) provided the means of Employeeâ€™s transportation, or (2) paid
  Employee for his travel time to and from work.Â  Employeeâ€™s own testimony
  confirmed Employer did not pay for his travel time to and from the job site.Â  Accordingly,
  Employeeâ€™s injuries will be compensable only if substantial evidence supports
  the Panelâ€™s finding that Employer, through its agent, Foreman, provided
  the means of Employeeâ€™s transportation to work.Â   
An
  agency relationship may be established by evidence of actual or apparent
  authority.Â  R & G Const., Inc. v. Lowcountry Regâ€™l Transp. Auth.,
  343 S.C. 424, 432, 540 S.E.2d 113, 117 (Ct. App. 2000).Â Â  In a principal -
  agent relationship, â€œapparent authority is considered to be a power which a principal
  holds his agent out as possessing or permits him to exercise under such
  circumstances as to preclude a denial of its existence.â€ Â Id. at 433,
  540 S.E.2d at 118.Â   

	When a
  principal, by any such acts or conduct, has knowingly caused or permitted
  another to appear to be his agent, either generally or for a particular
  purpose, he will be estopped to deny such agency to the injury of third persons
  who have in good faith and in the exercise of reasonable prudence dealt with
  the agent on the faith of such appearances. Â The apparent authority of an agent results from conduct or
  other manifestations of the principalâ€™s consent, whereby third persons are
  justified in believing the agent is acting within his authority. Â Such
  authority is implied where the principal passively permits the agent to appear
  to a third person to have the authority to act on his behalf.

Id. at 433-34, 540 S.E.2d at 118 (citations omitted).Â  â€œThe
  doctrine of apparent authority provides that a principal may be bound by the acts of its agent when the
  principal has placed the agent in a position such that third parties are
  reasonably led to believe the agent has certain authority and they in turn deal
  with the agent in reliance on this manifestation.â€ Â Eadie, 322 S.C. at 171,
  470 S.E.2d at 401. Â 
In Eadie,
  H.A. Sack employed Harold Eadie to supervise its construction projects, paid
  him a mileage allowance to drive his personal vehicle to and from work, and authorized
  him to hire crew members.Â  Id. at 167, 470 S.E.2d at 399.Â  Eadie hired Don
  Stanley to work with him on a Hilton Head project.Â  Eadie and Stanley both
  lived in Hampton and routinely rode to work together.Â  Later, Eadie hired Phillip
  Nix, also from Hampton, and offered him rides to Hilton Head with Eadie and
  Stanley.Â  Eadie testified he offered transportation to Stanley and Nix as an
  inducement to accept a job with H.A. Sack.Â  Id. at 170, 470 S.E.2d at 400.Â 
  On their way to work, Eadie, Stanley, and Nix were involved in an automobile
  accident.Â   
H.A.
  Sack argued the Panel erred in finding Stanleyâ€™s and Nixâ€™s workersâ€™ compensation
  claims were compensable under an exception to the going and coming rule.Â  Id. at 168, 470 S.E.2d at 399.Â  H.A. Sack conceded it provided transportation for
  Eadie; however, H.A. Sack alleged Stanleyâ€™s and Nixâ€™s injuries were not
  compensable because â€œEadie lacked authority to obligate the company to pay
  transportation costs for his crew.â€Â  Id. at 170, 470 S.E.2d at 400.Â  Our
  court affirmed the Panel, finding Eadie had apparent authority
  to offer transportation to Stanley and Nix on behalf of H.A. Sack and this
  authority was binding upon H.A. Sack.Â  Id. at 171, 470 S.E.2d at 401.Â  
 
Here,
  as in Eadie, Employee testified regarding the circumstances under which
  he was hired: â€œ[Foreman] c[a]me to the house and asked me if I needed a job,
  and I told him I didnâ€™t have a way back and forth, and [Foreman] said the
  company would provide transportation.â€Â  Employee stated Foreman picked him up
  at home and drove him to and from job sites in Charlotte and Columbia.Â 
  Employee testified he only went to work when Foreman went to work and if
  Foreman had to stay home, Employee stayed home as well.Â  Employee also
  testified Foreman showed him a check for $150 that Foreman said Employer was paying
  him to transport Employee to work in Foremanâ€™s personal vehicle.Â   
Laura
  Noah, Employeeâ€™s mother, testified to being present when Foreman offered a job
  to Employee.Â  She testified she asked Foreman: â€œ[h]ow is [Employee] going to
  get back and forth to Charlotte and Columbia with no car and no driverâ€™s
  license?â€Â  She also testified Foreman answered: â€œPyramid Masonry was going to
  furnish transportation for [Employee] back and forth to work.â€ Â Â 
David
  Mauney, a regional vice president with Employer for twenty-four years,
  testified Employer does not provide transportation to its employees and that it
  is the employeeâ€™s â€œresponsibility to find [his] own way to work.â€Â  He stated Employerâ€™s
  job description for a mason specifically states the employee â€œmust have means
  of transportation to and from project.â€Â  However, Employee testified he had not
  seen the job description prior to the hearing.Â  When asked whether Foreman
  could have told Employee that Employer would provide his transportation to
  work, Mauney responded: â€œThat would have been outside the scope of his
  authority.â€Â   
Mauney
  testified Employer gave each of its foremen a truck allowance of $150 per month
  for using their personal vehicles â€œduring the course of the workday on the job
  site, and if they have to go pick up incidentals, such as ice or gasoline or
  small tools . . . .â€Â  Mauney testified Employerâ€™s written policy for the truck
  allowance had not changed since 1989.Â  The policy states: â€œThis pertains only
  for picking up or delivering incidentals and not to be interpreted as mileage.â€[6]Â 
  Mauney stated Foreman began receiving the truck allowance on the day he began
  work; however, the allowance did not change when Foreman began transporting
  Employee a few weeks later, or several months later, when Foreman hired Clark
  and began transporting him to the job sites as well.[7]Â 
  Â Â Â 
It
  is uncontested that Employer hired Foreman to supervise its construction
  projects in Charlotte and Columbia.Â  It is also not disputed that Employer gave
  Foreman actual authority to hire masons and laborers to work on these projects.Â 
  Employer testified it expressly authorized Foreman to offer an hourly wage to
  the crew members he hired.Â  Employee testified that only Foreman, on behalf of
  Employer, discussed the terms of his employment with him.Â  Employeeâ€™s mother
  testified she was present and heard Foreman tell Employee that Employer would
  provide transportation to and from the job sites.Â  Accordingly, we find Employee
  and his mother could have reasonably believed that Foreman, as Employerâ€™s
  agent, had the authority to negotiate all of the terms of employment, including
  Employerâ€™s provision of Employeeâ€™s transportation to work.[8]Â   
Employer
  argues the facts in Eadie distinguish it from the facts of this case
  because in Eadie, the employer paid Eadie a mileage allowance for his
  travel to and from work.Â  We find this distinction to be unpersuasive. Â The Eadie court affirmed that Stanleyâ€™s and Nixâ€™s injuries were compensable because substantial
  evidence in the record supported its finding that H.A. Sack had â€œplaced Eadie
  in a position impliedly manifesting his authority to dictate the employment termsâ€
  to the crew members he hired. Â The courtâ€™s decision turned on its finding that
  Eadie acted with actual or apparent authority when he offered crew members transportation
  to and from work.Â  That authority bound H.A. Sack to the terms Eadie negotiated
  with the crew members.  
Here,
  there is evidence to support the Commissionâ€™s decision that Employerâ€™s agent,
  Foreman, acting with actual or apparent authority, told Employee that Employer
  would provide transportation as a condition of his employment.Â  While Foremanâ€™s
  offer of transportation may have exceeded the scope of the actual authority
  Employer conferred upon him, there is sufficient evidence in the record to
  support Employeeâ€™s belief that Foreman had apparent authority to negotiate the
  terms of his employment, including Employerâ€™s provision of transportation.Â 
  Employer is bound by Foremanâ€™s representations to Employee concerning the
  conditions of his employment.Â  Accordingly, the Commissionâ€™s decision that Employeeâ€™s
  injuries are compensable because they fall within an established exception to
  the going and coming rule is supported by substantial evidence and is therefore
  affirmed.Â   
II.  Admission By Party Opponent
Employer additionally
  argues testimony regarding Foremanâ€™s alleged statements to Employee concerning
  the conditions of his employment offer constituted inadmissible hearsay.Â  We
  disagree.
While
  relied upon by the Panel and the circuit court, the South Carolina Rules of
  Evidence do not apply in proceedings before the Workersâ€™ Compensation
  Commission. S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-330(1) (2005). Â We further note that great
  liberality is exercised in permitting the introduction of evidence in proceedings
  under the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act.Â  See Hamilton v. Bob Bennett
    Ford, 339 S.C. 68, 70, 528 S.E.2d 667, 668 (2000) (citing Ham v. Mullins
      Lumber Co., 193 S.C. 66, 7 S.E.2d 712 (1940)).Â  Â Accordingly, hearsay
  testimony may be admissible if corroborated by facts, circumstances, or other
  evidence.Â  Hamilton, 339 S.C. at 70, 528 S.E.2d at 668. Â We find
  sufficient facts and circumstances in the record to support a finding of
  corroboration. Â It is undisputed that Employer and Foreman were in an employer-employee
  relationship when Foreman offered Employee a job with Employer.Â  It is also
  undisputed that Employer had authorized Foreman to hire masons and laborers to
  work at job sites Foreman supervised.Â  The record contains not only testimony
  from Employee about his inability to drive and the circumstances surrounding
  his offer of employment, but also testimony from Employeeâ€™s mother who stated
  she was present at the time the statements by Employerâ€™s agent were made.[9]
Thus,
  we find the record contains sufficient evidence from which the Commission and
  the circuit court properly considered the statements by Employeeâ€™s agent.[10]Â Â   
CONCLUSION
For
  the foregoing reasons, the decision of the circuit court is  
AFFIRMED.
HEARN,
  C.J., PIEPER, J., and CURETON, A.J., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] Employer testified it provides a monthly truck
  allowance to each of its foremen.Â  Employerâ€™s written policy states the truck
  allowance is for â€œthe intended use of reimbursement for the use of personal
  vehicles on the job site.Â  This pertains only for picking up or delivering
  incidentals and not to be interpreted as mileage.â€Â   
[3] Foreman and Employee lived in Lancaster and had
  known each other for many years prior to Foreman offering Employee a job with
  Employer.Â  Employee testified he had worked for ten to fifteen years with
  Foreman in Foremanâ€™s fatherâ€™s construction company.Â  Later, Foreman started his
  own business, and Employee worked for him.Â  Employee did not have a car or a
  driverâ€™s license the entire time he worked for Foremanâ€™s family.Â  Consequently,
  Foreman or Foremanâ€™s father drove Employee to and from the job sites during the
  ten to fifteen year period that preceded Employerâ€™s hiring of Employee in
  January 2004. Â 
[4] Foreman died from the injuries he sustained in
  the accident.Â   
[5] Two Panel members voted to affirm the commissionerâ€™s
  ruling and one member voted to reverse.Â   
[6] Mauney pointed out that if viewed as a mileage
  allowance, Employerâ€™s truck allowance of $150 a month would only cover a few
  days of travel.Â   
[7] Donald Williams, a foreman with Employer for eighteen
  years, testified he also received a $150 truck allowance from Employer; however,
  he had never taken employees to work in his vehicle.Â  When asked if Employer
  provides transportation to employees to the job site, Williams responded:
  â€œNo.â€Â  Williams testified Employer provided the truck allowance â€œfor
  miscellaneous on-the-job, getting ice or anything pertaining to the job.â€Â Â  
 
[8] â€œIf the servant is doing some act in furtherance of
  the masterâ€™s business, he will be regarded as acting within the scope of his
  employment, although he may exceed his authority.â€Â  Crittenden v.
    Thompson-Walker Co., Inc., 288 S.C. 112, 116, 341 S.E.2d 385, 388 (Ct. App.
  1986).
[9] We accept for purposes of argument by Employer that
  the statements were hearsay and have considered whether the Panel erred in the
  admission of this evidence outside of the Rules of Evidence.Â  If Rule 801(d)(2)
  is considered only by analogy, we think the evidence would clearly qualify as
  non-hearsay and would be admissible as an admission by party-opponent.
[10] While asserted before the Commission, neither party
  addressed S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 19-11-20 (Supp. 2006) [the Dead Manâ€™s Statute] on
  appeal to this court and that issue is, therefore, deemed abandoned.Â  Rule
  208(b)(1)(B), SCACR;Â  See Hampton v. Dodson, 240 S.C. 532, 539,
  126 S.E.2d 564, 568 (1962) (finding issues were deemed abandoned when party
  failed to argue the issues in their brief).

title: Plowden Construction v. Richland-Lexington Riverbanks Park District
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO
  PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Plowden
      Construction Co., Respondent-Appellant,
				v.
				Richland-Lexington
      Riverbanks Park District and The LPA Group Incorporated, Appellants-Respondents.
			
		
	


Appeal From Lexington County
Alexander S. Macaulay, Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-207
Submitted March 4, 2008 â€“ Filed March 25,
  2008Â Â Â  
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Daniel T. Brailsford and Charles H. McDonald, of Columbia, for
  Appellants-Respondents.
				Thomas Elihue Dudley, III, of Greenville, for
  Respondent-Appellant.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  This
  case arises out of a construction contract between Richland-Lexington Riverbanks Park District
  (â€œRiverbanksâ€) and Plowden Construction Company, Inc. (â€œPlowdenâ€) for Plowden
  to build a road for Riverbanks.Â  During construction, Plowden encountered
  excess rock and brought the underlying action against Riverbanks and the
  project engineer, the LPA Group, Inc., (â€œLPAâ€).Â  Riverbanks and LPA appeal the
  trial courtâ€™s ruling for Plowden, and Plowden cross-appeals for prejudgment
  interest on its award.Â  We
  affirm.[1]
1.  Riverbanks hired LPA to assist with the construction
  of a new entrance from Highway 378 to the Riverbanks Zoo and Botanical Gardens
  in Columbia.Â  LPA designed the entrance, prepared bid packages and contract
  documents for prospective contractors, and acted as Riverbanksâ€™ representative
  during construction.Â  Initially, the bid packages were â€œunclassifiedâ€ with
  regard to the amount of rock excavation that would be encountered on the job.[2]Â 
  However, the packages were changed to reflect an estimate of 1,000 cubic yards of
  rock to be excavated.Â  At a pre-bid meeting, potential bidders were assured by
  LPA that if the encountered rock became a huge problem, they were â€œmore than
  willing to worth with [the bidders].â€
Plowden
  was ultimately awarded the job.Â  Soon after construction began, Plowden
  encountered bedrock, which required blasting in order to be removed.Â  Plowden
  proceeded with the work, but eventually the amount and size of rocks being
  excavated began to interfere with the project.Â  The rocks became too large and numerous
  to leave at the construction site, and Plowden finally halted construction on
  the project.Â  This resulted in a delay while a location to deposit the rocks
  was sought by LPA.
Pursuant
  to a provision in the contract, Plowden sought a change in the contract price
  to reflect the quality and quantity of rock removal associated with the
  project.Â  The project manager denied the requested changes finding the contract
  indicated quantities were approximate, Plowden was responsible for examining
  the physical conditions of the property before bidding, and the work stoppage
  was unnecessary.Â  Plowden brought the underlying action against Riverbanks and
  LPA.Â  The trial court found Riverbanks and LPA jointly and severally liable for
  $225,270.17, the cost of the additional work, and $66,000 in delay costs.Â 
  Riverbanks and LPA appeal the trial courtâ€™s ruling, and Plowden cross-appealed
  for prejudgment interest.
2.  LPA argues the trial
  court erred in finding LPA liable when LPA lacked privity in the contract
  between Riverbanks and Plowden and LPA followed the standard of care for design
  professionals.Â  The trial court found LPA liable for breaching its duty to
  follow the standard of care of design professionals.Â  In Tommy L. Griffin
    Plumbing & Heating Co. v. Jordan, Jones & Â Goulding, Inc.,
  320 S.C. 49, 55, 463 S.E.2d 85, 88-89 (1995), the South Carolina Supreme Court
  held an engineer who designed the project and supervised construction owed a
  duty to the contractor not to design or to supervise the project negligently because
  design professionals owe a professional duty, which is separate from
  contractual duties.Â  Therefore, LPAâ€™s liability is grounded in negligence, not
  contract principles.Â  Accordingly, LPAâ€™s privity to Riverbanks and Plowdenâ€™s
  contract is irrelevant.
Next,
  we turn to whether evidence supports the trial courtâ€™s finding LPA violated its
  professional duty.Â  â€œIn an action at law, when a case is tried without a jury,
  the trial courtâ€™s findings of fact will be upheld on appeal when they are
  reasonably supported by the evidence.â€Â  Butler Contracting, Inc. v.
    Court St., LLC, 369 S.C. 121, 127, 631 S.E.2d 252, 255 (2006).Â  â€œWhere
  professional negligence is alleged, expert testimony is usually necessary to
  establish both the standard of care and the professionalâ€™s deviation from that
  standard, unless the subject matter is within the area of common knowledge and
  experience of the layman so that no special learning is needed to evaluate the
  professionalâ€™s conduct.â€Â  City of York v. Turner-Murphy Co., Inc., 317
  S.C. 194, 196, 452 S.E.2d 615, 617 (Ct. App. 1994).
At
  trial, Herman Snyder, qualified as an expert in road construction in South Carolina, testified it is within industry standards for a contractor to rely on
  geotechnical information when preparing bids and it is the designerâ€™s
  responsibility to reflect accurately the anticipated scope of work in its
  report to assist the bidder.
Additionally,
  Carroll Crowther was qualified as an expert in geotechnical engineering and
  construction consulting.Â  Crowther testified the normal practice in the
  construction industry is to rely on geotechnical reports when computing bids.Â 
  Crowther further testified the method used by LPA to produce its report was
  superficial and required a â€œleap of faithâ€ for the report to provide information
  regarding the locationâ€™s rock profile.Â  Lastly, Crowther testified LPAâ€™s
  actions only minimally reduced the risk of a contractor encountering unknown
  situations.
Snyder
  and Crowther established a basis for the factfinder to conclude that the standard
  in the industry is for a design professional to provide reasonably accurate
  estimates, because it is the norm for bidders to rely on the provided
  information.Â  Furthermore, Crowtherâ€™s testimony clearly intimates that LPA was
  negligent in providing bidders with only superficial information about the rock
  associated with the project.Â  Consequently, the record supports the trial
  courtâ€™s finding of professional negligence on the part of LPA.
3.  Riverbanks and LPA
  allege Plowden expressly or primary impliedly assumed the risk the unit price
  for rock excavation was inadequate.Â  â€œExpress assumption of risk applies when
  the parties expressly agree in advance, either in writing or orally, that the
  plaintiff will relieve the defendant of his or her legal duty toward the
  plaintiff.â€Â  Davenport v. Cotton Hope Plantation Horizontal Prop.
    Regime, 333 S.C. 71, 79, 508 S.E.2d 565, 569 (1998).Â  Whereas, primary
  implied assumption of risk focuses on the defendantâ€™s duty of care and whether
  the plaintiff impliedly assumed risks inherent in the specific activity.Â  Id. at 81, 508 S.E.2d at 570.
Riverbanks
  and LPA point to areas in the contract where the bid scheduleâ€™s quantity of
  work is described as approximate and the contractor represents to have studied
  all reports on the site.Â  Section 11.9.3 in the contract undermines Riverbanks
  and LPAâ€™s argument as it provides:

	Where
  the quantity of any item of Unit Price Work performed by CONTRACTOR differs materially
    and significantly from the estimated quantity of such item indicated in the
  Agreement and there is no corresponding adjustment with respect to any other
  item of Work and if CONTRACTOR believes the CONTRACTOR has incurred additional
  expense as a result thereof, CONTRACTOR may make a claim for an increase in the
  Contract Price in accordance with Article 11 if the parties are unable to agree
  as to the amount of any such increase. 

(emphasis added).Â  Therefore,
  any risk Plowden assumed did not rise to the level of assuming responsibility
  for a rock quantity materially and significantly differing from the provided
  estimate.Â  Given the drastic difference between the estimated quantity of rock
  and the amount Plowden encountered, the trial courtâ€™s reliance on section
  11.9.3 was clearly justified.Â  Further, as discussed above, Plowden established
  LPA owed Plowden a duty of care.Â  Accordingly, there is evidence to support the
  trial courtâ€™s rejection of this defense.
4.  Riverbanks and LPA
  appeal the trial courtâ€™s finding that the no-damage-for-delay provision in the
  contract was not enforceable.Â  â€œGenerally,
  no-damage-for-delay provisions are valid and enforceable so long as they meet
  ordinary rules governing the validity of contracts.â€Â  U.S. for Use and
    Benefit of Williams Elec. Co., Inc. v. Metric Constructors, Inc., 325 S.C. 129,
  132, 480 S.E.2d 447, 448 (1997).Â  South Carolina recognizes several exceptions
  to this general rule, including â€œdelay caused by fraud, misrepresentation, or
  other bad faith; active interference; delay which amounts to an abandonment of
  the contract; and gross negligence.â€Â  Id. at 137, 480 S.E.2d at 451.
The
  trial court found the no-damage-for-delay clause unenforceable due to active
  interference and gross negligence by LPA, while acting as Riverbanksâ€™
  representative, in failing to locate a site to move the excess rocks.Â  In
  August 2000, Plowden informed LPA the rock estimation had already doubled and
  requested LPA provide a location where Plowden could deposit the excess rock.Â 
  The record includes a chronology and many letters where Plowden repeatedly asked
  for a rock disposal location because the lack of such a site slowed the
  projectâ€™s progress and eventually caused construction to cease.Â  During this
  time, LPA repeatedly claimed to be working on finding a site.Â  LPA took
  approximately three months to locate a site.
Because
  there is evidence in the record which supports the trial courtâ€™s decision, we
  are constrained by our standard of review to affirm the trial courtâ€™s holding
  that the no-damage-for-delay clause was not enforceable.
5.  Riverbanks and LPA next argue the trial court erred in
  calculating the damages awarded Plowden because of lack of proof of damages and
  the damages exceeded the original unit price for the non-excessive quantities
  of rock.Â  Plowden provided evidence of the additional costs created, which the
  trial court adopted less the money previously paid Plowden.Â  This evidence
  reasonably supports the trial courtâ€™s award.Â  As previously discussed, section
  11.9.3 of the contract provided for Plowden to seek an increase in the contract
  price if â€œthe quantity of any item of Unit Price Work performed by CONTRACTOR
  differs materially and significantly from the estimated quantity of such item
  indicated in the Agreement.â€Â  Plowden established the quantity of rock differed
  materially and significantly warranting adjusted compensation.Â  Thus, no error
  occurred when the trial court awarded Plowden $225,270.17 for the cost of the
  additional work.
6.  Finally, Plowden
  cross-appeals seeking prejudgment interest.Â  â€œ[P]rejudgment
  interest is allowed on a claim of liquidated damages; i.e., the sum is certain
  or capable of being reduced to certainty based on a mathematical calculation previously agreed to by the parties.
  Prejudgment interest is not allowed on an unliquidated claim in the absence of
  an agreement or statute.â€Â  Butler Contracting, Inc. v. Court
    Street, LLC, 369 S.C. 121, 133, 631 S.E.2d 252, 258-59 (2006)).Â  Plowden
  seeks prejudgment interest on the increased cost of work.Â  As discussed above,
  the contract set forth a process for Plowden to recover the increased cost if
  the amount of work materially and significantly differed from the estimated
  work.Â  This allowance of an adjustment in contract
  price speaks to the uncertainty regarding the nature and extent of work
  contemplated by the contract.Â  See Vaughn Dev., Inc. v. Westvaco Dev.
    Corp., 372 S.C. 576, 580-81, 642 S.E.2d 757, 760-61 (Ct. App. 2007)
  (declining to award prejudgment interest where the extent of work on sewer
  installation or how the work would be accomplished was not dictated by the
  terms of the contract).Â  The contract did not set forth a formula to determine
  such an adjustment.Â  Therefore, Plowdenâ€™s damages were not capable of being
  reduced to certainty until the determination by the trial court.Â  The trial
  court properly declined to award prejudgment interest.
7.  We
  conclude the record reasonably supports the trial courtâ€™s findings LPA breached
  its standard of care as a design professional; Plowden did not assume the risk
  of the rock removalâ€™s increased costs; the no-damage-for-delay provision was
  unenforceable; and the damage award was proper.Â  Further, the trial court
  properly declined to award prejudgment interest.Â  Accordingly, the judgment of the trial court is
 
 AFFIRMED.
HUFF, KITTREDGE, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  We decide this
  case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] Unclassified generally means the contractor is
  responsible for excavating whatever rock is encountered.

title: Aunt and Uncle v. Mother and Father
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT
  BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Aunt and Uncle, Appellants,
			
		
	

v.

	
		
			
				Mother and
      Father, Respondents.
				In the Interest of Child (DOB: 03/03/02), a minor child.[1]Â  Â 
			
		
	


Appeal From Aiken County
Â Peter R. Nuessle, Family Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-210
Heard February 5, 2008 â€“ Filed March 31, 2008Â Â Â  

AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND
  REMANDED 


	
		
			
				Jeffrey M. Butler, of Walterboro, for
  Appellants.
				David W. Miller, of Aiken and John D. Elliott, of Columbia, for Respondents.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  Aunt
  and Uncle appeal from the family courtâ€™s order, which (1) denied their petition
  to terminate the parental rights of Mother and Father, (2) granted Mother
  additional and more extensive visitation with Child, and (3) required Aunt and
  Uncle to pay Fatherâ€™s and Childâ€™s guardian ad litem (GAL) fees. Â We affirm in
  part, reverse in part, and remand.  
FACTS
Shortly after Childâ€™s birth on March 3,
  2002, Father was hospitalized due to a drug overdose.Â  Thereafter, Mother and
  Father (collectively Parents) tested positive for cocaine, and the Department
  of Social Services (DSS) placed Child with her maternal grandmother
  (Grandmother).Â  DSS also imposed a safety plan which prohibited Parents from any
  unsupervised contact with Child.Â  After Parents violated the safety plan, law
  enforcement removed Child from Grandmotherâ€™s custody and took her into
  emergency protective custody (EPC).Â  On April 25, 2002, DSS placed Child in foster
  care.Â

  and failure to keep his home safe for his daughter within . . . twelve (12)
  months.â€  
[5] We note, â€œRule 2(a), SCRFC, specifically excludes
  Rule 50, SCRCP (directed verdict motions), from family court proceedings.â€Â  Owens
    v. Owens, 320 S.C. 543, 544 n.1, 466 S.E.2d 373, 374 n.1 (Ct. App. 1996).Â 
  Therefore, Motherâ€™s motion was at most a motion for involuntary nonsuit
  pursuant to Rule 41(b), SCRCP, which is not excluded by Rule 2(a), SCRFC.Â  See id. (finding the partyâ€™s motion for a directed verdict in family court
  was at most an involuntary nonsuit motion).Â   
[6] We recognize an issue may be tried by consent despite
  a party failing to raise the issue in the pleadings.Â  See Rule 15(b),
  SCRCP (â€œWhen issues not raised by the pleadings are tried by express or implied
  consent of the parties, they shall be treated in all respects as if they had
  been raised in the pleadings.â€).Â  However, we cannot conclude the parties tried
  a completely separate ground for termination in this case.Â  The family court
  record provides no evidence which would indicate the parties believed the
  family court was considering section 20-7-1572(2) as a ground for terminating
  Motherâ€™s parental rights.Â   
[7] 18 U.S.C.A. Â§ 922(g)(1) (West 2008).

title: State v. Gordon
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO
  PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				The State, Respondent,
			
		
	

v.

	
		
			
				Joshua Devar
      Gordon, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Edgefield County
Â John C. Few, Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2008-UP-211
Submitted March 3, 2008 â€“ Filed March 31,
  2008
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Appellate Defender Eleanor D. Cleary, South Carolina Commission,
  of Columbia, for Appellant.
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott,
  Senior Assistant Attorney General Harold M. Coombs, Jr., Office of the Attorney
  General, of Columbia; and Solicitor Donald V. Myers, of Lexington, for
  Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM: Joshua
  Gordon (Gordon) appeals his conviction for trafficking in crack cocaine and
  resisting arrest.Â  On appeal, Gordon argues the trial court erred in admitting
  into evidence crack cocaine seized at the time of his arrest because the State
  failed to establish a complete chain of custody.Â  We affirm.Â Â   
FACTS
Investigator
  Roosevelt Young (Young) of the Edgefield County Sheriffâ€™s Department arrested
  Gordon pursuant to an arrest warrant. Subsequent to the arrest, Young took
  possession of a substance believed to be crack cocaine from Gordonâ€™s mouth and
  pocket.Â  The items recovered from Gordon were placed in a â€œbest kitâ€ along with
  a form detailing all pertinent information.[1]Â 
  A best kit is a tamper evident[2] plastic bag, in which evidence
  obtained from a crime scene is placed.  
After
  the evidence was placed within the best kit, Investigator Warren Miller sealed
  the best kit.Â  According to Agent Nathan McCoy
  (McCoy), a chemical analyst in the field of drug analysis for SLED, once
  sealed the best kit could not be opened without tearing it.Â  Thus, it would be
  apparent if an individual attempted to tamper with the best kit.Â   
After
  Gordonâ€™s arrest, Young transported the best kit from the crime scene to an
  evidence safe in Youngâ€™s office.Â  From there, Young hand-delivered the best kit
  to the SLED Drug Identification Unit in Columbia.Â  Young testified the best kit
  and its contents were not changed or altered, and no one else had access to it
  from the time when the kit was sealed at the crime scene to when it was
  delivered to Columbia.Â  Upon arriving at SLED, Young gave the kit to a SLED
  administrative employee so the evidence could be logged into SLEDâ€™s computer.Â 
  The employee returned the kit back to Young, and Young placed the kit into the
  evidence box.
McCoy testified he subsequently retrieved the kit from the
  evidence box.Â  After performing an inspection of the best kit, McCoy concluded no one had tampered with the best kit.Â  McCoy also determined the seal was intact.Â  After breaking
  the seal, McCoy performed chemical tests on the contents of the best kit and
  concluded the substance in the best kit was crack cocaine.Â   
Gordon objected to McCoyâ€™s testimony regarding the substance to be
  crack cocaine, arguing the State failed to prove the chain of custody of the best
  kit because the administrative employee was not identified.Â  The trial court
  denied this objection and allowed the evidence to come in at trial.Â  Consequently,
  Gordon was convicted of trafficking in crack cocaine and resisting arrest and
  sentenced to twenty-five years for the trafficking charge and one year for the
  resisting arrest charge.Â  This appeal follows.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The admission of evidence rests in the sound discretion of the
  trial court.Â  State v. Johnson, 318 S.C. 194, 196, 456 S.E.2d 442, 443
  (Ct. App. 1995).Â  The trial courtâ€™s decision will not be overturned unless
  controlled by an error law resulting in undue prejudice.Â  Id.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
 
LAW/ANALYSIS
The sole issue on appeal is whether the State established a
  complete chain of custody of the best kit.Â  Specifically, Gordon contends the
  testimony of everyone who handled the evidence, including that of the administrative employee who received the best kit to
  log it into SLEDâ€™s computer, was necessary to establish the chain of custody.Â 
  We disagree.  
Â If a party wishes to offer into evidence fungible items such as
  drug samples, that party must establish a chain of custody as far as
  practicable.Â  State v. Taylor, 360 S.C. 18, 22-23, 598 S.E.2d 735, 737
  (Ct. App. 2004).Â  If the analyzed substance has passed through several hands,
  the evidence must not leave it to conjecture as to who had it and what was done
  with it between the taking of the evidence and its analysis.Â  Id.Â  However,
  the proof of chain of custody need not negate all possibility of tampering; rather,
  it must establish a complete chain of evidence as far as practicable.Â  Id.Â  
 
In the present case, there is sufficient evidence to conclude the
  trial court did not abuse its discretion in ruling the State had established a
  complete chain of custody of the best kit.Â  Young testified he took the crack
  cocaine from Gordonâ€™s person and placed it in the best kit.Â  Miller testified
  that the best kit was thereafter sealed.Â  Young then locked the best kit in an
  evidence locker and later transported the best kit to SLED.Â  Young testified the best kit was neither changed nor
  altered from the time the kit was sealed at the crime scene and brought to SLED.
Young hand-delivered the best kit to an administrative employee who received the best kit to
  log it into SLEDâ€™s computer.Â  Young then personally placed the best kit in the
  evidence box.Â  McCoy testified he retrieved the kit
  from the evidence box.Â  McCoy also stated the
  best kit had not been tampered with and the seal was intact.Â  The
  foregoing testimony clearly demonstrates the State established a chain of
  custody of the crack cocaine seized from Gordon until it was analyzed by McCoy.Â 
  We do not find the Stateâ€™s failure to produce the administrative employee to
  testify fatal.Â  See S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Cochran, 364
  S.C. 621, 629-30, 614 S.E.2d 642, 646-47 (1995) (holding every individual
  associated with the evidence need not be identified nor be available to testify
  in order to establish a chain of custody and affirming the family courtâ€™s
  determination that a chain of custody of blood samples had been established
  even though the identity of the courier who transported the samples from the
  collection site to the testing facility was unknown when samples arrived at the
  testing facility sealed and intact).Â Â  Â 
CONCLUSION
Accordingly,
  the trial courtâ€™s decision is  
AFFIRMED.[3] 
HUFF,
  KITTREDGE, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] According to testimony, this information includes: a
  control number used throughout the chain of custody, the name of the suspect
  from which the evidence was retrieved, a description of the contents recovered,
  and the name of the law enforcement officer who recovered the evidence.Â  
 
[2] Tamper evident means that if the best kit has been
  tampered with, for example, by a person attempting to gain access to the bag,
  the kit will show signs of tampering.Â   
[3] We decide this case without oral arguments pursuant
  to Rule 215, SCACR.
